Title: Meet the 2016 Gold Rush Squad: Ashlee and Brooke
Headline: Throughout the season we will introduce you to all 40 members of the 2016 Gold Rush Squad. Today meet Ashlee a rookie member from Orem, Utah and Brooke a third-year member from Castro Valley, Calif.

CustomEntity.Title: Gold Rush Off The Field: Favorite Charity

ExtendedFields.Author: matthew.asher
ExtendedFields.Description: Get to know the 49ers 2016 Gold Rush squad!

NeutralCustomEntity.Title: Gold Rush Off The Field: Favorite Charity

ExtendedFields.Author: matthew.asher
ExtendedFields.Description: Get to know the 49ers 2016 Gold Rush squad!

Body.Content:
*Each week, 49ers.com gets to know two members of the 49ers Gold Rush. This week, we meet rookie Ashlee from Orem, Utah, and Brooke, a third-year member from Castro Valley, Calif.*  

**What have you learned from being a member of the Gold Rush? **
 <table cellspacing="5" cellpadding="5" border="0" align="left" width="310"> <tbody> <tr>

### **ASHLEE** **ASHLEE: **As a member of the Gold Rush you represent the entire 49ers organization. This comes with so many different opportunities that I am really looking forward to this season. I have gained so many new found friendships that I know will last a lifetime. **BROOKE: ** I think the most important thing I have learned is how valuable a smile or simple gesture can be. You can make someone‚Äôs day by saying ‚ÄúHello!‚Äù or shooting him or her a smile. **What's something our fans would be surprised to learn about you?** **ASHLEE: **I am full of random trivia facts. I have a photographic memory for useless knowledge, yet I can‚Äôt remember where I park my car when I go shopping. **BROOKE: **I‚Äôm a big golfer. **What do you like most about being a member of the Gold Rush?** **BROOKE: **Aside from dancing, I love being a member of the Gold Rush because of the amazing opportunities that come along with it. We are able to go out into the community, meet all of our amazing fans, and be a part of charity events. It is one of the most rewarding experiences I have ever been a part of. **What is your biggest goal this season? ** **ASHLEE:** There is no greater feeling in the world than setting a goal and seeing it come to life! Making this team is a dream come true. My ultimate goal is to work hard and show my full support for the 49ers. My team is full of ambitious, smart, hardworking women, and I want people to see that. **Who is the most inspirational person in your life?**

### **BROOKE** ** BROOKE: **My mom is the most inspirational person in my life. She approaches every situation with a huge heart and an unbelievable amount of compassion. She‚Äôs the type of person that can make anyone smile, and I can only hope to be half the person she is. ** ASHLEE: **My parents are my inspiration. My mother who taught me the value of patience and my father who taught me the importance of hard work. **What is your biggest fear?** **BROOKE: **Clowns! I do not like clowns at all! **What is your most embarrassing moment?** **ASHLEE: **Oh my, I have too many to count because they happen on the daily. One that comes to mind would be back when I was cheering for the Utah Flash, a loose ball hit me right in the face in front of thousands of fans and I blacked out. I was so embarrassed!
**GOLD RUSH FAVORITES**
**ASHLEE** **BROOKE**
MOVIE OCEANS 11 ANYTHING FROM PIXAR
TV SHOW SUITS CRIMINAL MINDS
**APP** UBER INSTAGRAM
**CHARITY** MAKE-A-WISH DANCERS AGAINST CANCER

Title: Get to Know the 49ers 18 Undrafted Free Agents
Headline: The San Francisco 49ers have added 18 players to their 2017 rookie class. Get to know them all.

CustomEntity.Title: 49 Hours: Round 1 of the 2017 NFL Draft

ExtendedFields.Author: joe.fann
ExtendedFields.Description: An inside look at how the San Francisco 49ers landed Solomon Thomas and Reuben Foster in the 2017 NFL Draft.

NeutralCustomEntity.Title: 49 Hours: Round 1 of the 2017 NFL Draft

ExtendedFields.Author: joe.fann
ExtendedFields.Description: An inside look at how the San Francisco 49ers landed Solomon Thomas and Reuben Foster in the 2017 NFL Draft.

Body.Content:
Once the draft concludes, the wait begins for the other shoe to drop. John Lynch said immediately following the conclusion of Day 3 that the San Francisco 49ers were already on the phone with undrafted free agents.

Some names have been circulating, but now we have the entire list of 18 undrafted prospects who have signed with San Francisco. Here‚Äôs the rundown along with a brief bio of each player.**Nick Mullens, QB, Southern Mississippi** 

Mullens was a four-year starter at Southern Mississippi and finished his career with 11,994 passing yards and 87 touchdown passes. His best season came in 2015 when he threw for 4,476 yards and 38 touchdowns to just 12 interceptions. He joins the 49ers after adding 3,272 yards and 24 touchdowns to his collegiate numbers as a senior in 2016.**Cole Hikutini, TE, Louisville**

Hikutini served as the safety valve for Heisman Trophy-winning quarterback Lamar Jackson in 2016. He caught 50 passes for 668 yards and eight touchdowns. Those numbers earned Hikutini second-team All-ACC honors. He began his career at Sacramento State before transferring to City College of San Francisco for one year. Hikutini is [said to have](http://www.nfl.com/draft/2017/profiles/cole-hikutini?id=2558179) ‚Äúspeed to attack over the top of linebackers and run under a deep ball.‚Äù**Lorenzo Jerome, DB, Saint Francis**

The 5-foot-10 safety turned heads at the 2017 Reese‚Äôs Senior Bowl following a standout senior season for the Red Flash. Jerome earned first-team FCS All-American honors following his six interceptions, 59 tackles and 11 pass breakups in 2016. He also added 14 kick returns for 405 yards and a touchdown. Jerome [has](http://www.nfl.com/draft/2017/profiles/lorenzo-jerome?id=2558206) ‚Äúoutstanding instincts and ball skills.‚Äù For what it‚Äôs worth, his NFL draft profile projected him to go in the fourth or fifth round of the draft. ESPN‚Äôs Todd McShay also had Jerome as his top-ranked undrafted player.**Matt Breida, RB, Georgia Southern**

Breida‚Äôs production dipped a bit in 2016. However, the ball-carrier scored 17 touchdowns in both 2014 and 2015. His 1,609 rushing yards in 2015 were a career-high.**Erik Magnuson, OL, Michigan**

Magnuson was named first-team All-Big Ten in 2016, and his [NFL Draft profile](http://www.nfl.com/draft/2017/profiles/erik-magnuson?id=2557926) calls him ‚Äúone of the better right tackles in the nation.‚Äù The 6-foot-6 lineman has starting experience at both guard and center.**Kendrick Bourne, WR, Eastern Washington**

Bourne was one half of the most prolific receiving tandem in FCS history, along with fellow Eagle Cooper Kupp. The 6-foot-1 wideout earned All-Big Sky honors three times. In 2016, Bourne caught 79 passes for 1,201 yards and seven touchdowns.**Darrell Williams Jr., OL, Western Kentucky**

The 6-foot-5 lineman made 41 career starts for the Hilltoppers split between his time at right tackle and right guard.**KD Cannon, WR, Baylor**

Cannon is the latest weapon to come out of Baylor‚Äôs wide receiver factory over the past five years. He posted 1,215 yards and 13 touchdowns for the Bears in 2016. Cannon has outstanding vertical speed as evidence by his 4.41 40 time at the NFL Combine. His pre-draft [profile](http://www.nfl.com/draft/2017/profiles/kd-cannon?id=2557975) projected him as a fourth-fifth round pick.**Victor Bolden, WR Oregon State**

In four years for the Beavers, Bolden caught 170 passes for 1,863 yards and seven touchdowns.**Jimmie Gilbert, LB, Colorado** 

Gilbert found his stride as a senior in 2016 with 14 tackles for loss and 11 sacks. The 6-foot-5 pass-rusher has plenty of length to use to his advantage. Gilbert comes from a basketball family and had a scholarship offer to play hoops at Stephen F. Austin out of high school.**John Flynn, OL, Montana State**

Flynn was a four-year starter for the Bobcats and a first-team All-Big Sky Conference selection.**Noble Nwachukwu, DE, West Virginia**

Nwachukwu played all four years for the Mountaineers and was productive for the final three. He finished his career with 117 total tackles, 26.5 tackles for loss and 13 sacks. His pre-draft [profile](http://www.nfl.com/draft/2017/profiles/noble-nwachukwu?id=2557990) projected him as a fifth-sixth round pick and called him ‚Äúagile and explosive.‚Äù**Donavin Newson, LB, Missouri**

Newson led the Tigers with 73 tackles in 2016. He added 5.5 tackles for loss, three sacks and four pass breakups.**Bret Treadway, OL, Lamar**

If his medicals weren‚Äôt a concern, Treadway would have been a highly-touted prospect. His NFL Draft [profile](http://www.nfl.com/draft/2017/profiles/bret-treadway?id=2557946) calls him ‚Äúone of the most athletic interior lineman in the 2017 draft.‚Äù The four-year starter could prove to be a post-draft steal in San Francisco.**Tyler McCloskey, FB/TE, Houston**

The linebacker-turned-fullback-turned-tight end quite literally did it all at Houston. His well-rounded career stats include 39 receptions for 406 yards and five touchdowns. McCloskey added 16 tackles on defense.** Malik Golden, S, Penn State**

The two-year starter for the Nittany Lions had a breakout year in 2016 with 75 tackles, one interception and three pass breakups.**Evan Goodman, G, Arizona State**

Goodman started 23 games at left tackle over the past two seasons for the Sun Devils. At 6-foot-4, he possesses NFL size.**Zach Franklin, CB, Washburn**

Franklin played in 45 career games (34 starts) at Washburn and totaled 109 tackles and four interceptions. In 2016, he recorded 38 tackles, three picks, 21 pass breakups and a fumble recovery.

Title: Sullivan to coach O-Line

Body.Content:
The San Diego Chargers have added offensive line coach Mike Sullivan to the coaching staff.

Sullivan, who enjoyed a five-year NFL playing career with the [Tampa Bay Buccaneers](http://www.buccaneers.com/) and [Dallas Cowboys](http://www.dallascowboys.com), spent the last two seasons as the assistant offensive line coach in Cleveland. In San Diego, he will work alongside Hal Hunter in coaching the Chargers‚Äô offensive line.

In between stints in Cleveland, Sullivan coached the offensive line at Western Michigan University for two seasons. Prior to entering the NFL‚Äôs coaching ranks, Sullivan both worked and played at the University of Miami (Fla.). Chargers Head Coach Norv Turner was the offensive coordinator in Dallas when Sullivan was drafted by the Cowboys.

**Bolts add eight**

The Chargers announced the signing of eight players to reserve/future contracts. All eight spent time on the Bolts‚Äô practice squad during the 2008 season.

The group includes linebacker Eric Bakhtiari, wide receiver Gary Banks, running back Eldra Buckley, defensive end Andre Coleman, guard Brandyn Dombrowski, cornerback Grant Mason, nose tackle Ogemdi Nwagbou and cornerback DeJuan Tribble.

Title: Two more coaches agree to join staff

Body.Content: The Chargers are down to two vacancies on their coaching staff after the team reached agreements with two more assistant coaches Wednesday.Former All-Pro cornerback Cris Dishman, who spent the 2008 offseason with the Chargers through the NFL‚Äôs Minority Coaching Fellowship, will assist newly-hired secondary coach Steve Wilks. Greg Williams, who was most recently a graduate assistant at the University of Pittsburgh, agreed to terms to become the Chargers‚Äô assistant linebackers coach. Dishman played 13 seasons in the NFL and was named to two Pro Bowls. He began his career with the Houston Oilers, played for Chargers Head Coach Norv Turner with the [Washington Redskins](http://www.redskins.com/) and played one season each with the [Kansas City Chiefs](http://www.kcchiefs.com/) and [Minnesota Vikings](http://www.vikings.com/).

Since 2006, Dishman has been on the staff at Menlo College in the Bay Area where he‚Äôs served as defensive backs coach and most recently as defensive coordinator.Williams comes to the Bolts after one season at the University of Pittsburgh, where he‚Äôs worked under former Turner colleague Dave Wanndstedt. Williams was a four-year letterman at the University of North Carolina and attended training camp with the [Chicago Bears](http://www.chicagobears.com) in 1998. Chargers Defensive Coordinator Ron Rivera was a Bears assistant at the time. Williams has also spent time at Arkansas Tech University, DuPage College and Arizona State. He played professionally in NFL Europe, the XFL and the Arena Football League.With four hires in the last two days, Turner still has two open positions on his coaching staff. He‚Äôs in the process of hiring a tight ends coach and an assistant offensive line coach.

Title: Ramsdell rooting for former pupil

Body.Content:
Tampa, Fla. - Chargers quarterbacks coach John Ramsdell grew up in Steelers country in Lancaster, Pennsylvania, but it‚Äôs unlikely that any Keystone State native will be rooting harder for their opponent, the [Arizona Cardinals](http://www.azcardinals.com/), come Sunday night‚Äôs Super Bowl.

‚ÄúYou can‚Äôt help but pull for a guy like Kurt Warner,‚Äù Ramsdell said. ‚ÄúHe‚Äôs such a great person and a great quarterback.‚Äù

Ramsdell knows a thing or two about great quarterbacks. He‚Äôs coached Warner, Marc Bulger and Philip Rivers to Pro Bowls and has been a big asset to Chargers Head Coach Norv Turner during Ramsdell‚Äôs tenure with the Bolts.

‚ÄúRams does a great job, starting in the offseason working with the fundamentals of playing the position to game-planning and game preparation,‚Äù Turner said. ‚ÄúHe‚Äôs done a great job with Philip and all of our quarterbacks.‚Äù

As the Cardinals prepare to face the Steelers Sunday at Raymond James Stadium, Warner‚Äôs tale has been recounted continually this week in Tampa. No one knows it better or appreciates the story more than Ramsdell.

Prior to joining the Bolts in 2006, Ramsdell spent 11 seasons with the [St. Louis Rams](http://www.stlouisrams.com/). He instructed tight ends and H-backs for three years before being assigned to quarterbacks coach in 1999, where he was by Warner‚Äôs side during the former Arena League star‚Äôs ascension from obscurity to superstardom.

In the spring of 1999, the Rams signed free agent Trent Green to lead Mike Martz‚Äôs fast-paced attack. Warner spent 1998 as the third quarterback and entered 1999 as the backup. But three games into the preseason, Green suffered a torn knee ligament against the Chargers, which thrust Warner into the limelight.

‚ÄúWe were just kind of grooming Kurt to get ready to be our backup; to be the next guy in,‚Äù Ramsdell recalls. ‚ÄúWe didn‚Äôt know that was going to be a month later.‚Äù

Warner embraced his opportunity and produced one of the most amazing seasons in league history. Although he‚Äôd never taken a snap in the NFL prior to that year, Warner tossed 41 touchdowns and only 13 interceptions while leading St. Louis to a 13-3 record. He was named league MVP and earned Super Bowl MVP honors after leading the Rams to a win over the Titans.

Ramsdell watched Warner grow throughout the year, and the now-two-time NFL MVP believes his former quarterbacks coach deserved a great deal of credit for his immediate success.

‚ÄúJohnny was awesome,‚Äù Warner said. ‚ÄúAny questions that I had, anything that I wasn‚Äôt sure of, he was right there. He was a detail-oriented guy, always staying on top of the little things from technique to reads to making sure that we were all 100 percent sure what we were supposed to do on any play versus any coverage.‚Äù

Since 1999, Ramsdell has seen two other young quarterbacks thrive. Bulger won the starting job in St. Louis in 2003 and when 12-3 in his first year at the helm of an NFL offense. In 2006, Ramsdell oversaw Rivers‚Äô first season as a starter, a year in which the Bolts went 14-2.

Warner praises Ramsdell‚Äôs football intelligence and even-keel approach but believes that his ability to handle his players has led to much of his success.

‚ÄúI don‚Äôt think there‚Äôs anything more important for a young guy than to be encouraged,‚Äù Warner said. ‚ÄúYou know you‚Äôre going to make mistakes. You know you‚Äôre going to have some rough times. You need a coach that knows how to coach you while encouraging you, coach you while keeping you confident in what you can do. I can‚Äôt say enough about what Johnny did for me.‚Äù

Ramsdell and Warner do their best to stay in touch, although they haven‚Äôt spent much time together since Warner joined the [New York Giants](http://www.giants.com/) in 2004. Ramsdell is humbled by Warner‚Äôs approach to life and proud of his perseverance.

‚ÄúKurt‚Äôs just a great person,‚Äù Ramsdell said. ‚ÄúHe‚Äôs very selfless, cares about other people and has a great attitude on life. He‚Äôs all about giving. He has a huge family and he has a great responsibility and love for them.

‚ÄúHe went through some tough times after losing the starting job in St. Louis, going to New York and then had his up and downs with the Cardinals. Once it was decided that he was the guy in Arizona, he just took off. It‚Äôs been great to see.‚Äù

Ramsdell and the Chargers faced the Steelers twice this season. While Pittsburgh led the NFL in nearly every defensive category in 2008 and is heavily favored Sunday, Ramsdell warns fans against counting Warner out.

‚ÄúThe way I think about NFL football right now, it‚Äôs a 50-50 game,‚Äù Ramsdell said. ‚ÄúThe season we had in San Diego, every game was a flip of the coin. I just think Kurt is so good and those receivers are so good. They‚Äôve got such a high-powered offense and have all the momentum going right now. I think they‚Äôve got a great chance of winning the game.‚Äù

Title: Sproles enjoying Tampa festivities

Body.Content:
From a regular season that saw him set new career highs in every statistical category to a two-touchdown performance in the Chargers‚Äô playoff win over the Colts, Darren Sproles had quite a year in 2008. This weekend, Sproles is in Tampa participating in a few pre-Super Bowl events. Chargers.com caught up with him to find out how he‚Äôs reflected on a remarkable season and hear about his offseason plans.

**What have you been up to since the season ended?**
‚ÄúI‚Äôve just been taking it easy, trying to get my body right. It takes some time to get feeling back to normal. I was sore, but it wasn‚Äôt a bad sore. I‚Äôve been in San Diego relaxing.‚Äù

**Now that you‚Äôve had some time to reflect, how much fun was the last month of the season for you personally?**
‚ÄúDecember was fun for all of us. We‚Äôre disappointed we fell short and didn‚Äôt play longer. I had fun (in 2007) too, but I got a lot more touches this past season. I feel like I‚Äôve taken steps each season. This season it was a big step and I had a lot of fun. "It takes some time to process it. During this time, I don‚Äôt really think much about football. I just try to relax. It‚Äôll all sink in once I start my training and thinking about next season.‚Äù

**What are you doing while you‚Äôre in Tampa?**
‚ÄúI‚Äôm about to visit radio row here in the media center to do some interviews. I just started a partnership with Yardbarker.com so I‚Äôm promoting that a little bit. I went to the Madden Bowl party last night. I‚Äôve got a couple appearances scheduled at the NFL Experience over at the stadium. I‚Äôll sign some autographs over there.‚Äù

**When you were at the Madden Bowl, did you watch Antonio Gates play in the tournament?**
‚ÄúYeah, but he can‚Äôt play (laughing). No, he did pretty good. He made it to the semifinals and got beat by Justin Tuck. I gave him a hard time about losing but he‚Äôs really good.‚Äù

**What are you plans for the next couple of months?**
‚ÄúI‚Äôm not going to do anything special. I‚Äôll be back and forth from San Diego to Kansas City. I want to spend some time with my family. I‚Äôll probably start my offseason workouts at the beginning of March sometime.‚Äù

**You‚Äôre an unrestricted free agent this spring. What do you hope happens?**
‚ÄúI want to stay in San Diego but we have to wait and see what happens. Your second contract, that‚Äôs the one where you have a chance to take care of yourself and your family. I enjoy my teammates and love playing for the Chargers. We‚Äôll just see how things go down.‚Äù

**Were you aware that the Chargers Team Store at Qualcomm Stadium ran out of number 43 jerseys in January?**
‚ÄúNo, I didn‚Äôt know that, but that‚Äôs cool to hear. When I first got to the Chargers, they didn‚Äôt sell my jersey in the stores. To get it sold out, that feels good. I really appreciate how all of our fans support our team and support me. People stop me a lot and always have nice things to say. It‚Äôs really nice.‚Äù

**What are your thoughts about Sunday‚Äôs game?**
‚ÄúI think Pittsburgh is going to win. Their defense is so tough. They force turnovers and make big plays. When their offense gets it, they can go on long drives and hold the ball like they did against us. That keeps Arizona‚Äôs playmakers off the field, so I like the Steelers Sunday.‚Äù

Title: Coaching staff starting to take shape

Body.Content:
Head Coach Norv Turner took the first step towards filling his 2009 staff Tuesday as he announced that the team has agreed to terms with two assistant coaches.

Don Johnson is set to become the club‚Äôs new defensive line coach and Steve Wilks will guide the Chargers‚Äô secondary. Both coaches are former [Chicago Bears](http://www.chicagobears.com) assistants and have a history with Bolts Defensive Coordinator Ron Rivera.

Johnson and Wilks were both with Rivera in Chicago in 2006 when the Bears led the NFL in takeaways and finished fifth in total defense en route to an NFC Championship and appearance in Super Bowl XLI.

Johnson replaces defensive line coach Wayne Nunnely, whose contract expired. Johnson spent the last two years as the [Oakland Raiders](http://www.raiders.com/)‚Äô defensive tackles coach. He previously served as the defensive line coach in Chicago (2005-06). Johnson helped Bears defensive tackle Tommie Harris earn two Pro Bowl appearances and oversaw the development of defensive end Mark Anderson, who recorded 12 sacks as a rookie in 2006.

Prior to joining the Bears, Johnson spent five seasons coaching the defensive line at UCLA and served as the school‚Äôs recruiting coordinator in 2004. The Newark, New Jersey native played at Jersey City State and for the United States Football League‚Äôs New Jersey Generals.

Wilks joins the Chargers after three seasons with the Bears and, like Rivera, Wilks places a keen emphasis on forcing turnovers. In his first two seasons in Chicago, Bears defensive backs forced 15 fumbles, the most among NFL secondaries during that period, and accounted for 27 of the team‚Äôs 40 interceptions.

A native of Charlotte, North Carolina, Wilks spent 11 seasons in the college ranks before joining the Bears, including stints at the University of Washington (2005) and Notre Dame (2004).

Wilks fills the role most recently held by Bill Bradley, who was released from his contract last week. Wilks played defensive back at Appalachian State and spent one season in the Arena Football League.

With the addition of Johnson and Wilks, the Chargers now have four openings on their coaching staff. Turner is in the process of hiring a tight ends coach as well as additional men to coach the offensive line, secondary and linebackers.

Title: Turner‚Äôs offense has produced great runners and passers

Body.Content:
Chargers Head Coach Norv Turner just completed his 18th season as an offensive play-caller in the NFL, and throughout that tenure he‚Äôs strived for balance and more importantly offensive success.

In 2008, the Bolts threw the ball 478 times compared to 421 runs, causing some outside the organization to believe that the Bolts have evolved to a pass-first team. However, a look at Turner‚Äôs history as a play-caller doesn‚Äôt support that notion.

As both a head coach an offensive coordinator, Turner has called plays for five different NFL rushing champions. That list includes LaDainian Tomlinson in 2007, Miami‚Äôs Ricky Williams in 2002 and Emmitt Smith, who won three-consecutive rushing titles with the Cowboys from 1991-93. Turner has seen two other running backs ‚Äì Frank Gore in 2006 and Stephen Davis in 1999 ‚Äì lead their respective conference in rushing under his watch.

Turner has served as the offensive coordinator in Dallas, San Diego, Miami and San Francisco and has called offensive plays in each of his 11 seasons as an NFL head coach (San Diego, Oakland and Washington). In those 18 seasons, he‚Äôs produced 15 1,000-yard rushers, including LT‚Äôs rookie season of 2001 with the Chargers.

In addition to his history with rushing champions, Turner has seen his leading ball-carrier finish in the top 10 in the NFL in rushing an astonishing 13 times, including LT‚Äôs 10th place finish in 2008.

Turner‚Äôs pursuit of balance has produced another interesting statistic. On seven different occasions, Turner has called plays for a team that featured a 3,000-yard passer, a 1,000-yard rusher and a 1,000-yard receiver. The Chargers accomplished that feat in 2008 (Philip Rivers, Tomlinson and Jackson) as well as during Turner‚Äôs lone season as the club‚Äôs offensive coordinator in 2001 (Doug Flutie, LT and Curtis Conway).

His teams recorded the ‚Äútriple crown‚Äù twice in Dallas (‚Äô92 and ‚Äô93), twice with the Redskins (‚Äô96 and ‚Äô99) and again in 2005 with the Raiders.

In 2008, the Chargers threw just seven more passes than they did in 2007. However, they ran 57 fewer plays in Turner‚Äôs second season as head coach.

Several factors contributed to their decline in opportunities. Bolts‚Äô opponents scored first in 10 of their 16 contests, and teams that fall behind typically have to throw the ball more to catch up. The Chargers also won the time-of-possession battle just five times during the regular season.

The Bolts didn‚Äôt enjoy the success they‚Äôd hoped for on the ground early in the season, which put them in passing situations on second and third down and forced them to throw the ball more.

‚ÄúI don‚Äôt think it was ever as bad as perceived,‚Äù Turner said late in the season. ‚ÄúWe went a stretch of games where we played Buffalo and we only had 50 offensive snaps. You can‚Äôt really get yourself going in that environment. We had a tough time getting teams off the field early. There are a lot of reasons.‚Äù

The Chargers got things going on the ground in the final month of the season. During their four-game winning streak in December, the Bolts averaged 151 rushing yards per game, including a franchise-record 289 yards in their regular-season finale against Denver.

Turner has won AFC West titles in each of his two seasons as the Chargers‚Äô head coach. While he acknowledges that balance is key, results are the ultimate goal of his offense.

‚ÄúI‚Äôve been in this offense all the way back,‚Äù Turner said. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs the same offense we ran with the Rams back in ‚Äò87, so it‚Äôs going on 30 years. When we won, the balance was great. When we didn‚Äôt, the balance was bad. There (were) times (in 2008) I don‚Äôt think we threw the ball enough based on the way people were playing us. I‚Äôd love to be able to line up and have them play in a look every down where you can run or pass. And I‚Äôd like to be good enough that it doesn‚Äôt matter what they‚Äôre playing. You can say, ‚ÄòWe‚Äôre going to run it, and they can‚Äôt stop us.‚Äô"

Title: AJ reaches out to LT

Body.Content:
San Diego Chargers General Manager A.J. Smith, under fire for recent comments about the status of running back LaDainian Tomlinson, decided he owed the future Hall of Famer a phone call to clear the clouds of misinformation and speculation.  So he picked up the phone on Monday evening and found Tomlinson in Tampa, Florida.   

‚ÄúIt was important to me that L.T. know exactly what happened,‚Äù Smith said referring to comments he made in the San Diego Union-Tribune regarding statements on L.T.‚Äôs web site.    

‚ÄúI just answered a question and unfortunately my response was inappropriate,‚Äù said Smith, who has sat in the GM‚Äôs chair since 2003.  ‚ÄúAfter reading my response to the question, I can see why it was interpreted the way it was.

‚ÄúI absolutely meant no disrespect toward L.T‚Ä¶ none.  I have the utmost respect for him on two fronts, as a player and as a person.‚Äù  

Admittedly, Smith was hurt by some the comments made by the local and national media.  Though stung by the reaction, Smith was comforted by those who know him best.  

‚ÄúDean Spanos and many members of our front office and coaching staff know exactly how I feel about L.T., and that is what has gotten me through this difficult time.  

‚ÄúAnd most important, L.T. knows how I feel about him.‚Äù   

Smith characterized the 10-minute conversation as ‚Äúa great talk ‚Ä¶ the kind of talk we have at the beginning of each season.‚Äù  

Like Smith, Tomlinson had nothing but positive vibes from the phone call.  

‚ÄúIt was great to hear from him,‚Äù said the five-time Pro Bowl performer.  ‚ÄúIt really went well.  It‚Äôs always better talking directly to someone one on one.  He was very upbeat and very sincere.  He felt bad about what had happened.‚Äù

Title: Chargers add Grennan, release Battle

Body.Content:
The San Diego Chargers signed defensive end Keith Grennan to the active roster today from their practice squad. To make room for Grennan on the 53-man roster, the team released safety Tra Battle.   

Grennan, 6-4, 298, was signed by the Chargers as an undrafted rookie free agent in 2007 spent the entire season on San Diego‚Äôs practice squad. He has spent the first 11 weeks of the 2008 season on the practice squad as well.

Title: Chargers place Davis on ‚ÄúReserve-Injured‚Äù

Body.Content:
The Chargers have placed wide receiver Buster Davis (groin) on the ‚ÄúReserve-Injured‚Äù list and re-signed tackle Corey Clark to the active roster.

Davis was limited to just four catches for 59 yards this season and missed the last five games while recovering from the injury. Clark spent the first 10 weeks of the season on the 53-man roster and was released this past Saturday to make room for Tra Battle on the active roster. Clark was re-signed to the practice squad after clearing waivers on Monday.

Cornerback Grant Mason will fill Clark‚Äôs vacancy on the practice squad. Mason is a 6-0, 198-pound former Michigan Wolverine who spent the 2007 and parts of the 2008 season with Pittsburgh. He began his Steelers career on the practice squad and was signed to the active roster for the last five games of the ‚Äô07 season and Pittsburgh‚Äôs playoff game against Jacksonville. He again spent time on the Pittsburgh practice squad this season before being waived on Nov. 11.

Title: Blackout lifted on Chargers-Chiefs game

Body.Content:
Enough tickets have been sold to lift the local television blackout and allow Southern California to see the CBS Sports telecast of the match-up between the San Diego Chargers and [Kansas City Chiefs](http://www.kcchiefs.com/) on Sunday, Nov. 9 at Qualcomm Stadium.  Kickoff is 1:15 p.m. PT.  The game will be televised in San Diego on KFMB, Ch. 8 and in Los Angeles on KCBS, Ch. 2.  Gus Johnson and Steve Tasker will call the game from the booth.  

A limited number of Club Level seats and other single seats are available online at www.chargers.com; the Chargers Ticket Office at Qualcomm Stadium (Gate C), or by calling TicketMaster at 619-220-TIXS (8497).     

This week‚Äôs game is the team‚Äôs first home game since Oct. 12 and the first of four home games in the next five weeks.    

Tickets for all remaining home games are available by logging onto [www.chargers.com](/) or going to the Chargers Ticket Office at Gate C at Qualcomm Stadium.

Title: Chargers kickoff food drive

Body.Content:
Fans are encouraged to support the San Diego Food Bank by bringing all types of non-perishable food to Sunday‚Äôs game at Qualcomm Stadium between the Chargers and [Indianapolis Colts](http://www.colts.com/) game. The food collected will help families stricken by the economic crisis and help shore up the Food Bank‚Äôs dangerously low food supply.    

The parking lot gates open at 12 noon and entrance gates open at 3 pm. Red bins will be positioned at all stadium entrances.  The most needed items are canned meats, canned fruits and vegetables, pasta, soup, and cereal.   

The fan who brings in the most food will receive a Philip Rivers autographed football.   

For more information about the San Diego Food Bank‚Äôs Food Drive, call Director of Communications Chris Carter of the San Diego Food Bank at 619-857-2314.

Title: Chargers receive extension to lift blackout

Body.Content:
Due to the Thanksgiving holiday and the shortened business week, the National Football League granted the Chargers a 24-hour extension in an effort to sell enough tickets and lift the local television blackout of this Sunday‚Äôs Chargers-Falcons game at Qualcomm Stadium.  The team now has until 1:05 pm PT on Friday to sell the remaining 2,000 tickets.  

Fans can go to the Chargers‚Äô ticket office at Gate C at Qualcomm Stadium, go to www.Chargers.com or contact TicketMaster at 619-220-TIXS (8497).  The ticket office at Qualcomm Stadium is open on Friday (8-5 pm) and Saturday (10-4 pm).  The office is closed on Thanksgiving Day.  

If the local television blackout is lifted, the game will be shown live on Fox 5 in San Diego and Fox 11 in Los Angeles.  Matt Vasgersian and J.C. Pearson will call the action.  

The radio broadcast can be heard in San Diego on KIOZ Rock 105.3 FM and XTRA Sports 1360 AM in San Diego and KLAC 570 AM in Los Angeles.  Josh Lewin and Hank Bauer call the action from the booth and Jim Laslavic reports from the sideline.  Jorge Villanueva, Adrian Garcia and Efren Dominguez call the game in Spanish on XHFG 107.3 FM in San Diego and KWKW 1330 AM in Los Angeles.

Title: Bo Roberson: The Little Known Chargers Olympian
Headline: The remarkable story of a Chargers Olympian.

Body.Content:
For the next two weeks all eyes will be on a Russian resort town turned sports mecca for the 22nd Winter Olympiad in Sochi. While the winter games have seen NFL players come home empty handed, the Summer Olympics have been fertile ground for success stories. In all, 31 players that have worn an NFL uniform have won medals, including long jump silver medalist and San Diego Charger Bo Roberson.

Born in Philadelphia in 1935, Irvin ‚ÄúBo‚Äù Roberson became one of the greatest multi-sport athletes to come out of the City of Brotherly Love. After enrolling in a prep school, Roberson attended Cornell in the fall of 1954, lettering in football, basketball and track. In his three years on the gridiron, Roberson rushed for 1,175 yards on 348 carries and scored nine touchdowns. He also caught 16 passes for 224 yards and one TD. While his football talent was evident, it was his track and field skills that would be his true calling card in college.

After graduating from Cornell in 1958, Roberson dominated the 1959 Pan-American Games, leaving his competition in the dust.  He jumped more than a foot further than the second place finisher. In 1960 he jumped even further at the National AUU Indoor Championships, beating Jesse Owen‚Äôs 25 year indoor record with a leap of 25-9 ¬Ω. Soon after, it was off to Rome for the Olympic Games.

He was not expected to medal in 1960, a year with a strong pool of talent entering the long jump. Yet as the competition wore on, the Philadelphia native had the last jump ‚Äì and a chance for Olympic gold. He also had a famous fan in the stands rooting him‚Äì Jesse Owen. Owen‚Äôs 1936 record for the long jump still stood and he had arrived in Rome feeling ‚Äúlike a father who has come back to watch his successful children.‚Äù Unfortunately, Roberson came up one centimeter short of winning the gold, earning the silver medal.

A year later it was Roberson‚Äôs exploits in Philadelphia, not Rome, that would earn him his ticket to the AFL. Al LoCasale, a Chargers personnel man, had also gone to high school in Philly and recommended Roberson to then Chargers coach Al Davis.

‚ÄúBo went to Bartram High and I went to Olney in the same league,‚Äù remembered LoCasale. ‚ÄúWhat I remembered about him was his tremendous speed and his tremendous ability, and that he was put together like a football player, not a skinny track kid. When I remember back, I remember his speed, his acceleration, his takeoff.‚Äù

The Chargers and Roberson would both arrive in San Diego in 1961. In that first season with the Bolts, Roberson would do a little of everything ‚Äì returning kicks, catching passes and running the ball. The former Olympian rushed for 275 yards (second most on the team) and got in the end zone three times for the Chargers. Roberson also caught six passes for 81 yards. His former work as a sprinter also paid off as a return man for San Diego, averaging 15.9 yards per return.

The Chargers would go 12-2 their first year in San Diego, making it to the AFL Championship game against the Houston Oilers at Balboa Stadium. In a tough contest, Roberson would lead the team in rushing yards with 37 on eight attempts. Despite the Bolts best effort, they fell to the Oilers 10-3.

Despite a promising 1961 season, Bo Roberson‚Äôs first year in San Diego would also be his last. That offseason Roberson would leave San Diego along with two other Chargers in exchange for the rights to the Oakland Raiders‚Äô 2nd round pick, a fair haired wide out from the University of Arkansas ‚Äì Lance Alworth.

Roberson would play five more years in the NFL before returning to school and coaching. After attending Stanford Law School, Roberson would earn his doctorate from United States International University (now Alliant International University) here in San Diego. Although Roberson passed away in 2001 he still is alone in a unique club - the only person to have an Ivy League degree, a Ph.D., an Olympic medal and a career in NFL. Not bad for a kid from west Philadelphia.

Title: Chargers Press Conference Transcripts: Head Coach Norv Turner and Quarterback Philip Rivers

Body.Content:
**Opening Statement by Head Coach Norv Turner: **

**

** ‚ÄúThere are several things that I was very pleased with about what our team was able to do. The first thing, we made a big emphasis during the week when you go play in Kansas City. You have to handle the environment, the crowd noise, the reputation. You have to handle the early start and we spent a lot of time putting a plan together that would allow us to get in there and get off to a fast start. I think our players responded to that plan. We got off to a fast start in all three phases of the game. The other thing is for our team to be the kind of team we want to be and have the kind of season we‚Äôre looking to have. We‚Äôre going to have to handle adversity on a week to week basis. Obviously we didn‚Äôt play as well in the Atlanta game as we hoped or planned to but you have to respond and come back. We can‚Äôt let last week affect us negatively. Also responding to adversity in games and in both of those areas our guys were outstanding. We got great performances and in some cases their best game ever. We had a great performance from Nick Novak on Friday afternoon to come here and pick up right where he left off from training camp. It was extremely impressive. We had a great performance in the kicking game from Melvin Ingram. He was on all four special teams, he played 20 plays in the kicking game, he had four tackles. It was certainly his best performance in that area which is critical for us because every guy that can contribute in the kicking game makes a difference. Defensively there is no question in my mind, Corey Liuget and Vaughn Martin played their best game probably since they‚Äôve been here. They were outstanding, very aggressive and a great push. I was very impressed with the things they were able to do. I thought Jeromey Clary, that was a tough match up for him. They have good rushers and I thought he played extremely well. The one thing that was my concern going into Kansas City, they have a lot of players that can change the game. They have an outstanding running back that is leading the game in rushing, they have two outstanding receivers, big guys that made big plays and are obviously capable. We‚Äôve obviously had a tough time when we‚Äôve been there, handling their rushers. You have to put a plan together that says be able to manage and control these aspects. For the most part we were able to do that. When we didn‚Äôt I think it showed that these are explosive guys. Jamaal Charles made a great run and he used his abilities to make an outstanding run. Fortunately he was only able to do that once in the game and that was a big part of our success. For the things we addressed and focused on for the most part we were able to get done. We had a few stretches there where we struggled offensively but that‚Äôs the type of defense this team has. They have been able to shut people down in spurts and you‚Äôre able to get plays on them. I thought our guys managed the tough spots and responded in the fourth quarter with two scoring drives, a touchdown drive and a field goal drive. Obviously the key to our game was being able to attack defensively and create six turnovers. If you do that you‚Äôre going to win most of the time.‚Äù **On whether kicker Nick Novak is better than other NFL kickers:** ‚ÄúI just think that it‚Äôs a matter of personal opinion. If you‚Äôve had the level of exposure we‚Äôve had with Nick, if I was somewhere else I would certainly think I would feel good about him kicking. He‚Äôs better than some of the kickers I‚Äôve worked with in the past.‚Äù **On linebacker Donald Butler‚Äôs performance:** ‚ÄúDonald‚Äôs performance was outstanding. I didn‚Äôt mention him because he‚Äôs been playing at that level. I wanted to mention Corey and Vaughn because I thought that was another level for them. Donald has been playing at that level and he just keeps getting better and better. He‚Äôs a really good football player.‚Äù **On telling the defensive players to play fast and not think so much:** ‚ÄúWe‚Äôve talked about reacting to what you see and trusting what you see. That comes with experience and I think from a standpoint of what we‚Äôre trying to get done upfront and with some things we did a little different in the game, is continue to have a mindset that we‚Äôre going to be aggressive with the calls but we‚Äôre going to be aggressive within the calls. You can be an aggressive football player within any defensive call. You can be an aggressive football player with any offensive call. That‚Äôs what we‚Äôre trying to get done.‚Äù **On whether the defensive scheme was altered after the loss to Atlanta:** ‚ÄúI don‚Äôt think we ever change anything completely. We have a system that we trust and believe in. We used some things that I think helped us in that game and got our guys started a little bit. There are things that we have in our play book. Obviously Atlanta posed some different problems than we had in Kansas City. As I said after the Atlanta game, we have a lot of new moving parts in players and coaches. My goal starting Monday of last week was to make sure we learn from what happened in Atlanta and take from that to help us get better.‚Äù **On running back Ryan Mathews playing limited minutes but still putting up yards:** ‚ÄúI think they had 30 carries between them [Mathews and Battle]. I liked the mixture we had. Ryan came in on the screen and got a big play early. I think every week we‚Äôre going to look at what gives us the best chance to win; we‚Äôll put a game plan together and try to implement it. Both guys obviously were effective in their own way.‚Äù **On who starts the game at each position being overrated:** ‚ÄúI don‚Äôt think it is to the players because I think it is important to them but from a standpoint of our team now, we have so many different guys that can contribute. We‚Äôre week one and Antonio Gates can‚Äôt play and Dante Rosario goes and catches three touchdowns and he hasn‚Äôt been utilized a lot since then. There are only so many balls. We have a lot of guys who can contribute and be a part of this. If we keep a mindset of what matters, each week finding a way to win, yeah I think it is overrated who starts. I understand a player‚Äôs mentality of wanting to be a guy and be the starter.‚Äù **On the possibility of defensive coordinator John Pagano taking time off due to his brother being diagnosed with Leukemia:** ‚ÄúChuck Pagano worked for me in Oakland and Chuck was a graduate assistant when I was at USC so I‚Äôve known him since 1984. He‚Äôs a great guy, a great person, and obviously an outstanding coach. He‚Äôs a heck of a father and as Jim Irsay said today, he‚Äôs going to beat it. John found out about this on Wednesday morning and that‚Äôs one of the things that as coaches, there‚Äôs a commitment that you make to a group of guys and John handled it as well as you can handle it during the week. It was a very difficult week for him, it was a combination of things. You get all caught up in losing a game to Atlanta and on Wednesday morning you get a call that your brother has Leukemia. It puts things into perspective and John did an unbelievable job handling what he had to handle.‚Äù **On whether Ryan Mathews learned his lesson by limiting his exposure during the game:** ‚ÄúRyan was put in a tough spot. You miss entire camp for the most part, the first couple games and you come up and everyone is six weeks ahead of you. He handled it extremely well. He had one bad play against Atlanta and if he had 100 carries and no fumbles and had a fumble on that play, he got hit really hard on that play in the Atlanta game but it doesn‚Äôt make it ok. You can‚Äôt fumble the ball. Everyone thinks it is to send a guy a message but the best thing for us in the Kansas City game was to start Jackie Battle and give him and our offense a chance to get into some rhythm. On a feel when it was the right time, we wanted to give Ryan the opportunity to be a part of it. As the game went on he became a big part of it. He understands the importance of taking care of the ball. He‚Äôs not negligent. I don‚Äôt think there is anyone that works any harder. He had a bad play in the Atlanta game but I do believe that we‚Äôre going to get past that.‚Äù **On having the regular referees back and returning to the general rhythm of the game:** ‚ÄúThat was probably the hardest thing, trying to establish the rhythm. No one was at fault because obviously if you get thrown into the middle of something like that it was a real challenge. It was great to have the officials back, they a great at what they do. Like a lot of things, all of the sudden they aren‚Äôt there and you realized it was pretty good before. It‚Äôs not going to be perfect, we all know that. We‚Äôve all been in situations where we‚Äôve benefitted from a call that wasn‚Äôt exactly right and I‚Äôve been in situations where we‚Äôre at the other end of it.‚Äù **On kicker Nate Kaeding‚Äôs status:** ‚ÄúNate is being evaluated as we speak. He was very sore on Friday when he had the injury. He went through the process of having and MRI and seeing a specialist. We‚Äôll know more as the week goes on. I would not anticipate him kicking for a while.‚Äù **Quarterback Philip Rivers**

**On tackle Jared Gaither‚Äôs performance against Kansas City:** ‚ÄúHe played well but I think that he would be the best one to ask because he has some things that he wants to correct and improve on just like we all do. But it was great to have him back out there.‚Äù **On his rhythm with wide receiver Robert Meachem:** ‚ÄúThis game was one of those where he didn‚Äôt really have a lot of opportunities. The one that he did have, I shouldn‚Äôt have thrown. But we are in good sync, he and Eddie [Royal] both along with all the guys we‚Äôve added. But we‚Äôve had games like this every year where it was the running backs. Malcom [Floyd] and [Antonio] Gates got a few but it was that kind of game. We were efficient except for the turnover. And it was good to run it 23 times and to get six turnovers. When that happens and you get a short field you don‚Äôt end up with as many long drives or yards but it obviously boils down to points.‚Äù **On the running backs contributing to the receiving game:** ‚ÄúThat‚Äôs how it‚Äôs always been around here. If you look back to years past, Ryan [Mathews] and [Mike] Tolbert caught over 100 passes combined. So that‚Äôs nothing new for our backs to be a big part of our passing game, not just in protection, but in catching the ball. Ronnie [Brown] had two big third downs. Jackie [Battle] had a big catch in the one big drive for about 15 or 16 yards. Ryan [Mathews] had a few there in the last drive. The backs all catch the ball well.‚Äù **On how the Chief‚Äôs defended tight end Antonio Gates:** ‚ÄúWe knew that‚Äôs what we were going to get and they mix it on third down. So we had opportunities to get him the ball on first and second down. We were able to do that on a couple of those drives. And on third down what they‚Äôre going to try to do is get two guys on him at the line and make it hard for him to get off. There aren‚Äôt completions in the stat book, but to me, he had two catches in the first drive. They were both incomplete because of the pass interference, but the defender obviously felt like they were going to be catches and he went and grabbed him. Those were big plays. They don‚Äôt count, but they do count yardage-wise. It was good to Gates going and in a flow.‚Äù **On the possible psychological impact on running back Ryan Mathews not getting as many reps:** ‚ÄúIt didn‚Äôt seem that way from his body language and his approach. I know one thing, and that is he was fresh and flying around in the fourth quarter. He had some big carries and first downs. He caught a screen in the first drive for about a 15 yard gain which was big. I think that it was a nice mix of those two guys. I don‚Äôt know the exact carry total but I know they were both in double digits. Ryan probably ended up with more yards but it‚Äôs a good combination with Ronnie [Brown] in there on third down doing what he did. It‚Äôs a nice group and they can all be fresh. Jackie [Battle] is a huge contributor on special teams. I didn‚Äôt feel any lack of confidence from Ryan. He‚Äôs improving every day and you can‚Äôt overlook the fact that he was out for six weeks. This was his second game in and he felt a little more comfortable. That‚Äôs just natural. He played a big role in yesterday‚Äôs game.‚Äù **On whether or not who starts the game is relevant:** ‚ÄúI think that it matters with certain positions. Offensive line and things like that don‚Äôt matter because you‚Äôre going to play the whole game. But in our system and the way we intermingle guys, you saw how balanced it was. It keeps them fresh and allows us to let them do what we they do best both in the run and the passing game.‚Äù **On what the win against Kansas City says about the team after coming off a tough loss to Atlanta:** ‚ÄúIt didn‚Äôt tell us anything new about what we already knew in the locker room. We knew that we were resilient and that we were going to come right back. It just reiterates what I‚Äôve always said about this being a week-to-week league. The one thing is that we know we have to play those guys again in a month or so. If it wasn‚Äôt a six-turnover game it would have been a tight game down to the wire. That was a good team and a good defense. I think that we had the right approach of let‚Äôs get after it early. Let‚Äôs not wait around and get a feel for the game and let the crowd get going. It was one of those games where we weren‚Äôt in a bind and we got up on them early.‚Äù **On the New Orleans Saints being more talented than their record shows them to be:** ‚ÄúA record obviously means something but it means nothing when you have to prepare for an opponent. We know what we‚Äôre getting into with the Saints. When you watch the games that they‚Äôre been in they could be 4-0. And they had this Kansas City team 27-6 like we did. Obviously it got away from them and they could have very easily won the game yesterday in Green Bay. A record means everything in terms of where you‚Äôre sitting at the end of the year but we‚Äôve been in the same position where we were the 4-6 team and the 3-5 team where we knew we were pretty good but we hadn‚Äôt shown it. This game is going to be a heck of a challenge. It‚Äôs a game that you love to play in but also one that you know is going to be tough.‚Äù **On the mindset of the New Orleans Saints:** ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs been many years since I‚Äôve been around Drew [Brees] but he‚Äôs treating today like they‚Äôre 4-0. He‚Äôs very steady. And that‚Äôs how you bounce back from a situation like they‚Äôre in. In a Drew Brees team with what they‚Äôve been though, you can‚Äôt ever count them out of anything. We‚Äôll get their best and we‚Äôve got to prepare to make sure that we give them our best.‚Äù **On quarterback Drew Brees throwing a touchdown in 47 consecutive games:** ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs impressive when you think about how many games that is in a row throwing a touchdown. He‚Äôs broken a lot of records in the past few years and he‚Äôs a heck of a player. I was with him in the early part of his ascent to the level he‚Äôs at. So it‚Äôs been fun to see where his and what a great player he is.‚Äù **On what he‚Äôs learned from quarterback Drew Brees:** ‚ÄúWe‚Äôre so different. I think that every quarterback is just a little bit different in our approach to the game and the way we think and talk about the game. But then again you learn things and you take things that are just about being a pro. The way we prepared and did the same thing every week is the one thing that I took from the most. We could have won on a Monday night or been beat and he was going to do the same thing. His demeanor never changed. He could have thrown three interceptions and it was like he had thrown three touchdowns or vice versa. And I think that‚Äôs something that filters down through the locker room. I‚Äôm a little more emotional and it‚Äôs harder for me to keep as steady but that‚Äôs one thing that I did learn from him. I appreciated being able to watch him those first two years. The competitor in me wished that I had been playing from the first snap as a rookie but I do appreciate seeing it from the sidelines.‚Äù **On defensive coordinator John Pagano‚Äôs brother being diagnosed with leukemia:** ‚ÄúI didn‚Äôt know what he was dealing with last week and I saw how steady he was through it while getting the defense ready and continuing the regular preparation through a tough time with his family. But family is most important. I know his brother a little bit, but it‚Äôs times like these where you have a tight group that helps you through it. They‚Äôre tough and they‚Äôre fighters and they‚Äôll get through it.‚Äù **Marty Schottenheimer and Keenan McCardell being nominated for the Pro Football Hall of Fame:** ‚ÄúI spent a few years here with coach Schottenheimer and with Keenan as well so it was a very small portion of their long careers. But my experience with both of them is that were a great coach and player. But it‚Äôs something when you‚Äôve played with a guy and then you see him on that list. And there will be many more that end up either in the hall of fame or being eligible and in the finals. So being with those guys is definitely special.‚Äù **On the defense creating turnovers and scoring points:** ‚ÄúThat‚Äôs why I was so mad at myself for the turnover. I hate every turnover but in a game like that I didn‚Äôt want to give them any reason to get back in the game while the defense was playing the way that they were. Our defense is certainly flying around and playing together with a lot of confidence. They‚Äôre also very unselfish. There are a lot of guys contributing on both sides of the ball and it‚Äôs fun to be part of it.‚Äù **On having the regular officials back:** ‚ÄúMore than anything was the familiarity with the guys we‚Äôve seen for many years now. It‚Äôs definitely more comfortable and there is more communication. You feel like the crew is on the same page. And the pace of game improved. There wasn‚Äôt a whole lot of discussion on every penalty that they threw. It‚Äôs one less thing to think or worry about. Not that we did that, but we know that these are guys who have been a part of it for a long time.‚Äù **On developing consistency:** ‚ÄúYou just have to play better each week and keep growing from a preparation standpoint. You‚Äôre going against different fronts each week. It‚Äôs week to week but you have play at a more consistent level. That doesn‚Äôt mean you‚Äôre going to score like we did yesterday or create turnovers like we did yesterday. But it‚Äôs about playing at a level that gives you a chance every week. And we‚Äôve done that over the years. The last few years we didn‚Äôt do it from a win column standpoint but we‚Äôre in every single game.‚Äù **On making improvements from last week:** ‚ÄúWe can certainly make some things better. Those are the kinds of things you work on correcting week to week. You also have to understand that the game is not going to go perfect. You‚Äôre going to have adversity throughout a game.‚Äù **On having kicker Nick Novak back:** ‚ÄúYou hate it for Nate [Kaeding] and how he got injured but at the same time you‚Äôre thankful that Nick hadn‚Äôt been signed yet because the way he kicked last year all through camp and into the preseason. We‚Äôre lucky that he was here in San Diego and available. He could have been anywhere on a Friday afternoon. And he was great. He seemed very comfortable and stepped in.‚Äù **On his feelings on the offense:** ‚ÄúWe just have to keep growing. We‚Äôre not where we‚Äôre going to be in December. We‚Äôll be better. But we have to win along the way. It was great to get Eddie [Royal] involved yesterday and have him catch a touchdown pass. We have to keep getting better. We‚Äôve had the big numbers, we‚Äôve had the 400-yard days and all those things. It‚Äôs just a matter of winning.‚Äù **Inside linebacker Donald Butler:**

** ** **On his excitement during his interception and touchdown run against Kansas City:** ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs only natural when you see some open field in front of you and one offensive player to beat. I was able to make a play and go in for the score. It really starts with the guys up front. It‚Äôs about guys getting pressure on the quarterback, him making an errant throw and me being in the right place at the right time. I don‚Äôt think that it was necessarily anything that I did. It was a combined defensive effort.‚Äù **On keeping their momentum going heading into the game against the New Orleans Saints:** ‚ÄúWe‚Äôve got to keep it going and it starts today. We have to watch film and correct the mistakes that we did make. And we have to get ready for a good Saints team.‚Äù **On the Saints being better than their 0-4 record:** ‚ÄúThey have a very high-powered offense with a lot of weapons. We‚Äôre going to have our hands full.‚Äù **On the Chargers‚Äô defense:** ‚ÄúRight now we‚Äôre playing at a very high level. The Falcon game was a little setback. We came out yesterday and made some very good plays and I think we can be very good. It‚Äôs going to be something that week in and week out we‚Äôre going to have to work on, but as of right now I think we‚Äôre all playing at a high level.‚Äù **On what needs to be improved upon:** ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs all about consistency and I think that we‚Äôre haven‚Äôt been at a consistent level.‚Äù **On what was different in the Kansas City and the Atlanta game defensively:** ‚ÄúI think that it was creating opportunities. Whenever you can get that amount of turnovers does strides for the team. The offense fed off of us and special teams did as well.‚Äù **On defensive coordinator John Pagano‚Äôs brother being diagnosed with leukemia:** ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs heartbreaking. We‚Äôre all going to be there for John as much as we can and try to help him get through this. I can‚Äôt imagine what he‚Äôs going through right now. Whenever you have a family member who comes down with a sickness it really touches your heart.‚Äù **On being an underdog against the Saints:** ‚ÄúI don‚Äôt even look at that. The next game is the most important game and that‚Äôs the Saints regardless of their record. They‚Äôre a dangerous team.‚Äù **On the Chargers‚Äô defensive line:** ‚ÄúThose guys are doing a great job up front penetrating, getting off the ball and getting on the edge getting after the quarterback. As a linebacker, that‚Äôs all you can ask for.‚Äù **On what felt better, his interception or Washington upsetting Stanford:** ‚ÄúIt has to be the interception. But it definitely felt good seeing my Huskies get the w.‚Äù
