Title: Alyssa Milano to promote new Chargers women's fashion

Body.Content:
**Alyssa Milano to promote new Chargers women‚Äôs fashion collection at Qualcomm Stadium on Sunday**  

On Sunday, November 23, actress Alyssa Milano will be at the Chargers Team Store at Gate G at Qualcomm Stadium to promote her new licensed women‚Äôs fashion collection ‚Äì TOUCH by Alyssa Milano.     

Any fan that purchases a piece of TOUCH product from the collection will get the chance to meet Alyssa and receive a free autographed gift from her. The meet and greet will take place from 3:00 - 4:00pm (before the 5:15pm Chargers game against the [Indianapolis Colts](http://www.colts.com/)). *A game ticket is needed to access the Chargers Team Store. *  

TOUCH by Alyssa Milano is a unique, licensed women‚Äôs fashion brand designed for the female sports fan.  Launched this season with the National Football League, this high-end brand blends fashion and function and is a great addition to existing women‚Äôs sports licensed apparel offerings.  The TOUCH brand empowers the fiercely loyal female sports fans to look and feel their best.    

The missy contemporary targeted collection consists of apparel and jewelry and accessories. The apparel collection is designed utilizing high quality fabrics and body contouring silhouettes.     

**ABOUT ALYSSA MILANO**  

Milano has spent almost her entire life in the public eye.  She has starred in a number of long running successful television series including the hit WB series ‚ÄúCharmed‚Äù for eight years, the longest running show in the history of TV with female leads.  She also starred on the Fox cornerstone series ‚ÄúMelrose Place,‚Äù and began her television career on ABC‚Äôs ‚ÄúWho‚Äôs the Boss,‚Äù which ran on ABC for eight years and continues to appear in syndication.  Her film credits include ‚ÄúHugo Pool‚Äù co-starring Sean Penn and Robert Downey Jr., the Imagine/Universal film, ‚ÄúFear,‚Äù and ‚ÄúDickie Roberts: Former Child Star.‚Äù   She was most recently seen as the title character in the Lifetime Original movie, ‚ÄúWisegal,‚Äù (which she also produced) and in a recurring role on the hit NBC comedy, ‚ÄúMy Name is Earl.‚Äù

Title: 2,000 tickets available for next two home games

Body.Content:
The Chargers‚Äô streak of 35 consecutive regular-season and postseason home games shown on live local television is in jeopardy.  More than 2,000 tickets remain available for Sunday‚Äôs game against the [Atlanta Falcons](http://www.atlantafalcons.com/) at Qualcomm Stadium.  Kickoff is Sunday at 1:05 pm.  All general tickets must be sold 72 hours prior to kickoff for NFL games to be televised live locally.    

In addition, an equal number of tickets are available for the Chargers‚Äô nationally-televised home game versus the [Oakland Raiders](http://www.raiders.com/) on Thursday night, Dec. 4.    

Tickets are available online at www.Chargers.com; the Chargers Ticket Office at Qualcomm Stadium (Gate C), or by calling TicketMaster at 619-220-TIXS (8497).    

If a sellout is announced, the game will be shown live on Fox 5 in San Diego and Fox 11 in Los Angeles.  Matt Vasgersian and J.C. Pearson will call the action.   

The radio broadcast can be heard in San Diego on KIOZ Rock 105.3 FM and XTRA Sports 1360 AM in San Diego and KLAC 570 AM in Los Angeles.  Josh Lewin and Hank Bauer call the action from the booth and Jim Laslavic reports from the sideline.  Jorge Villanueva, Adrian Garcia and Efren Dominguez call the game in Spanish on XHFG 107.3 FM in San Diego and KWKW 1330 AM in Los Angeles.

Title: Spanos, LT talk

Body.Content:
The Chargers‚Äô recent run to the playoffs lifted the spirits of a community like nothing else. Nothing elicits emotion and passion in San Diego like the Chargers.

That emotion and passion is clearly evident now as rumors swirl around the team and decisions it must make in the coming months.

It‚Äôs an emotional business, yet a business best run without emotion.

‚ÄúWinning a Super Bowl for San Diego has always been and will always be our mission,‚Äù said team President Dean Spanos. ‚ÄúWe are San Diego‚Äôs team and we owe that to the people who care about and support this team.

‚ÄúWe can‚Äôt let our emotions taint our decisions. We owe it to our fan base and the City we represent to make sound decisions that will help us win a Super Bowl.‚Äù

The questions to be discussed are many right now at Chargers Park.

What coaches can be added to help the Chargers win a Super Bowl?
What players on the roster give them the best chance to win?

What players are getting better and what players have peaked and started to drop off?

What players can be added, and at what positions, to ensure success?

Should the new faces be rookies acquired through the draft or veterans available on the free agent market?

Given the restraints of the NFL‚Äôs salary cap, how do they keep every player they want to keep?

Again, given the limitations of the salary cap, what does the team do with such key players as Darren Sproles, Malcom Floyd and nine others whose contracts are due to expire next month?

And how do they do that while also leaving enough money to sign this extensive list of top players ‚Äì Philip Rivers, Vincent Jackson, Shawne Merriman, Tim Dobbins and Marcus McNeill among others ‚Äì whose contracts expire after the upcoming season?

The number-one question being discussed by the Chargers‚Äô faithful today is the future of running back LaDainian Tomlinson. Speculation and rumor are running wild.

Tomlinson and Spanos have become close over the years, and the team‚Äôs owner called his friend Thursday to explain the process and everything the team must take into account in the months ahead.

‚ÄúWe talked about the situation and I just tried to explain everything that must be considered,‚Äù said Spanos. ‚ÄúI told him we haven‚Äôt even started our discussions and won‚Äôt for awhile, so don‚Äôt jump to any conclusions. And I told him I would call him personally to make sure he‚Äôs aware of everything that‚Äôs going on.‚Äù

Could the team do what was once unthinkable and part ways with its future Hall of Fame running back, a player whose list of accomplishments is long but whose time on the field may be running short?

‚ÄúI wish we knew the answers to all of these questions now, but we don‚Äôt,‚Äù said General Manager A.J. Smith. ‚ÄúWe want our evaluation process to be as thorough as possible. We always start with open minds and with the same goal every year: put together the team that gives us the best chance to bring a championship to San Diego.‚Äù

According to the NFL calendar, teams cannot release players until Feb. 9, can‚Äôt designate Franchise Players until Feb. 19 and can‚Äôt make trades until Feb. 27.

That is why the team, according to Smith, takes this time to assess its position and options. It also provides enough time for the dust to settle on an emotional ending to a season and assure its judgments are based on solid facts for the future and not on the intense disappointment following a season unfulfilled.

‚ÄúIt‚Äôs important that we take the time necessary and get input from all of our coaches and personnel people and don‚Äôt make rash decisions,‚Äù said Smith.

Title: Bizarre third quarter dashes Bolts hopes

Body.Content:
It was a quarter that saw only seven points scored, but it was a frame that provided the unusual, the bizarre and more or less the dagger to the Chargers‚Äô season.

‚ÄúWe knew it was going to be a back and forth game but it was such a weird third quarter that it really changed the whole flow,‚Äù quarterback Philip Rivers said.

To be exact, the Chargers‚Äô offense spent 14:43 of the third quarter of Sunday‚Äôs Divisional Playoff game watching and waiting.

The Steelers had just a 14-10 lead at halftime and converted just one of their five third downs in the first two quarters. On the opening drive of the second half, they reached the sticks on a 3rd-and-7, a 3rd-and-11 and a 3rd-and-8. The drive covered 7:56 and ended with a Heath Miller touchdown catch.

‚ÄúWe‚Äôve got to make a play and get off the field,‚Äù safety Eric Weddle said. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs as simple as that. We weren‚Äôt able to and that‚Äôs disappointing for a defense that has played so well lately.‚Äù

The long drive left the Chargers trailing by just 11 points, hardly an insurmountable lead. The Bolts got a little optimism with Miller‚Äôs touchdown catch was followed by a 63-yard kickoff return by Darren Sproles that put the Chargers on Pittsburgh‚Äôs 23 yard line.

That hope was quickly dashed. On the first play of the drive, Rivers fired to his left to a wide-open Chris Chambers. Unfortunately, the pass was tipped at the line of scrimmage and ultimately intercepted by Larry Foote.

‚ÄúYou can‚Äôt really call it a fluke,‚Äù Rivers said. ‚ÄúThey made a play, but it‚Äôs almost uncontrollable.‚Äù

Eight plays later, the Steelers were forced to punt, but another strange bounce kept the peculiar series of events going down a disheartening path for the Chargers. Mitch Berger‚Äôs high, short kick bounced off the helmet of an unsuspecting Weddle. William Gay recovered for Pittsburgh, keeping the Bolts‚Äô offense to watch from the sideline for another three minutes.

‚ÄúIt‚Äôs a freak play,‚Äù Weddle said. ‚ÄúIt was just such a short punt. When I was running I looked back at Sproles and he was a ways from there. My first thought was, ‚ÄòHe‚Äôs going to catch it. I‚Äôm going to get to my guy now.‚Äô As soon as I got my hands engaged, it hit me.‚Äù

The Steelers didn‚Äôt score on the drive. They were actually stopped on 4th-and-goal from the San Diego one, but the damage had been done. They had an 11-point lead going into the fourth quarter and had exhausted the Bolts‚Äô defense.

‚ÄúWe know how explosive (our offense) can be,‚Äù defensive end Luis Castillo said. ‚ÄúWe just keep thinking if we give them a chance, there‚Äôs no doubt in anybody‚Äôs mind they can go out and make something special happen. We couldn‚Äôt get off the field.‚Äù

They were able to run the ball well and establish the play-action. When you let a team like that get going on that kind of roll, it‚Äôs hard to stop them. Give them credit. They‚Äôre a great team.

While the defense was frustrated they couldn‚Äôt get off the field, the offense felt helpless not being on it.

‚ÄúIt was such a weird third quarter,‚Äù Rivers said. ‚ÄúIt had a huge impact on the game.‚Äù

Title: Chargers-Chiefs Postgame Notes

Body.Content:
Chargers and Chiefs Postgame Notes from Today's Game  



Antonio Gates led the team and had a season-high eight catches today, including the ultimate game-winning touchdown catch, his team-leading sixth of the season‚Ä¶Gates has a touchdown catch in three of the team‚Äôs last four games.

Malcom Floyd had his third touchdown catch of the season and all three have come in the last four games.

LaDainian Tomlinson rushed for 78 yards today, raising his career total to 11,279‚Ä¶in doing so, he moved past O.J. Simpson (11,236) and Corey Dillon (11.241) and into 15th place on the NFL‚Äôs all-time rushing list. John Riggins ranks 14th with 11,352.

Philip Rivers passed for 316 yards and two touchdowns today, his fourth 300-yard game of the season today and his third in the last four games‚Ä¶since Oct. 5 at Miami, Rivers has passed for 1,171 yards and 10 touchdowns‚Ä¶coming into this season, Rivers had only passed for over 300 yards a total of four times during his career.

Rivers completed 75 percent of his passes today (27 of 36), his third game of the season ([New York Jets](http://www.newyorkjets.com/) and Buffalo) with a completion percentage of .750 or above.

Rivers also finished the day with a 96.5 passer rating, leaving his season rating at 106.3, which leads the NFL.

The Chargers had exactly 400 yards of total offense today, their third 400-yard game in the last four games.

San Diego‚Äôs game-winning touchdown drive went 14 plays, 94 yards and 8:24‚Ä¶it was the team‚Äôs longest touchdown drive of the season in terms of plays and time of possession, and its second-longest of the season in terms of total yards‚Ä¶Rivers completed all eight of his passes on that drive for 75 yards and the touchdown to Gates.

This was the Chargers‚Äô fourth win over the Chiefs in the last five games between the teams in San Diego‚Ä¶the Chargers narrowed the gap in the all-time series to 50-46-1‚Ä¶it was the first one-point game in the series since 2002, a game the Chargers also won by a score of 35-34.

Kansas City scored an offensive touchdown in the first quarter today, ending the Chargers streak of regular-season games without allowing a first quarter touchdown at 11.

Title: Sen. Boxer honors Chargers

Body.Content:
U.S. Senator Barbara Boxer from California was proud of the resilience the Chargers showed this season, and two days after the Bolts‚Äô season came to an end, Boxer honored San Diego‚Äôs team with a statement printed in the Congressional Record.

The statement read as follows:

Mr. President, today I wish to send my congratulations to the San Diego Chargers for the remarkable way that they turned around their 2008 season in the National Football League. During difficult economic times, as they face hardships and uncertainty, millions of sports fans across America turn to their hometown teams for solace and inspiration. Few teams this year faced as many hardships as the Chargers, and few teams in any year have overcome adversity with such inspiring tenacity.

Hampered by injuries to star running back LaDainian Tomlinson and other key players and suffering through a series of heartbreaking losses, the Chargers began the 2008 season with just four wins in their first twelve games. With three weeks to go in the regular season, they trailed the division-leading [Denver Broncos](http://www.denverbroncos.com) by three games. Though their fans remained loyal and the team remained confident, few outside observers gave them any chance of reaching the NFL playoffs. Over the next five weeks, though, the Chargers made an amazing run. Beginning on December 4th, three consecutive San Diego victories and two Denver losses left the Chargers just one game back entering a December 28th showdown with the Broncos. In the decisive game, the Chargers staged an awe-inspiring offensive display to crush the Broncos 52-21 and win the AFC Western Division championship. They became the first team in NFL history to have been 4-8 and make the playoffs and the first team ever to win their division after being three games behind the leaders with three games to play. Six days later, on January 3rd, the Chargers faced a terrific [Indianapolis Colts](http://www.colts.com/) team in the playoffs. In perhaps the greatest NFL game ever played in San Diego, the Chargers beat the Colts in overtime, 23-17. Every playoff tournament ends sadly for every team but one. Last Sunday, on a snowy day in Pittsburgh, the mighty Steelers ended the Chargers season. But nothing can dim the luster of the Chargers‚Äô late-season run. Their dramatic turnaround is an inspiration to sports fans everywhere. Mr. President, I grew up in Brooklyn, in the shadow of Ebbets Field, where baseball fans endured years of frustration with the annual cry of ‚ÄúWait Till Next Year.‚Äù When I was in high school, our dream finally came true, and ‚Äúnext year‚Äù became this year. With a talented young team that has triumphed over adversity, the San Diego Chargers can look forward to next year with pride and confidence. I salute the Charger players, coaches, staff, and ownership ‚Äì along with their loyal fans ‚Äì for a great 2008 season.

Title: Relive the Selection of Keenan Allen
Headline: A look back at the moment Keenan Allen became a Bolt.

Body.Content:
Each Thursday leading up to the 2016 NFL Draft, we'll take a look back to the moment we selected some notable Chargers under the Tom Telesco/Mike McCoy era.

During their first draft, the Bolts came away with the steal of the 2013 NFL Draft when they selected Keenan Allen in the third round. Now you can relive that day with all the articles, videos and photos posted following his selection. After he was taken in the third round with the 76th overall pick, we reposted the [prospect profile](/node/89316) written in the weeks leading up to the draft. Moments later, were were able to have an [exclusive phone conversation with Allen just a few minutes after he became a Bolt](/node/89321), and he gave great insight into what type of player he hoped to become. Immediately following the selection, General Manager Tom Telesco discussed the highly touted wideout.

ExtendedFields.Description: 8b6df287-4620-43e9-bdb4-ee88cc0abbda
8b6df287-4620-43e9-bdb4-ee88cc0abbda

Body.Content: When Allen arrived at Chargers Park on Saturday, he immediately granted an exclusive interview on what also happened to be his 21st birthday.
Make sure to check out the one-of-a-kind photo galleries documenting Allen's arrival at the team's facility for the very first time.
Later, the Cal product met with the media.

ExtendedFields.Description: 130cea56-dcb9-421b-b28d-f7fbb1d7cac8
130cea56-dcb9-421b-b28d-f7fbb1d7cac8

Body.Content: Finally, for a breakdown of Allen's game on the field, President of Football Operations John Spanos detailed how the new wide receiver would help the Bolts.

Title: Transcripts from Wednesday's press conferences

Body.Content:
**Transcripts from San Diego Chargers**
**Wednesday, Dec. 24, 2008**

**Head Coach Norv Turner**

‚ÄúIt‚Äôs been 14 games ago, you‚Äôve seen guys and the way they‚Äôve grown and gotten better. I don‚Äôt think Denver is giving up as many big plays on defense as they did the first time we played them. They‚Äôve got guys who have been together and played together, they‚Äôre playing better team defense and offensively they‚Äôre first or second in the league in a number of categories. They‚Äôre explosive and they‚Äôre skilled guys play with great confidence and they‚Äôre explosive players.‚Äù

**Is your team peaking?**
‚ÄúWell we played extremely well against Tampa on Sunday so I think if you‚Äôre peaking, you have to do that two weeks in a row so hopefully we‚Äôll do it Sunday night and then we‚Äôll start talking about that.‚Äù

**What did you learn about this team after the last few weeks?**
‚ÄúI think it goes back a lot further than that. We‚Äôve had ups and downs all year and we‚Äôve had a lot of different scenarios in terms of winning or losing close games. You asked me what I learned and I learned it last year as we went through the season and I think that experience helps you keep competing and going and making plays. Obviously the key game for us was the Kansas City game, coming back with 4:50 left being down by two scores and finding a way to win that game.‚Äù

**On the call that Hochuli made in Week 2:**
‚ÄúI don‚Äôt even get involved in it because I had been involved with a number of those on different stops in my career and as I said, once it happens it‚Äôs gone and you can‚Äôt ever get it back. We‚Äôre fortunate to be in the position that we‚Äôre in and it‚Äôs going to be a heck of a game. They‚Äôre an extremely explosive team. They‚Äôve got very good athletes in all three phases and we‚Äôre going to have to play our best.‚Äù

**Is that easier said than done, letting go of something like that?**
‚ÄúYes, I mean, if you believed me when I said that I could sell you some other things. You can‚Äôt let it go, but you have to. You have to put it behind you and you can‚Äôt let it effect what you‚Äôre doing in the future.‚Äù

**Is this defense better prepared to handle Brandon Marshall the second time around?**
‚ÄúWell, we played better in the second half against their offense. Obviously the first half was really, really a struggle up there. You have to understand that those guys are awfully good and they are going to make plays. We have to contain them and if they make a big play we have to line up the next play and make sure they don‚Äôt get two in a row. They‚Äôve made big plays in every game they‚Äôve played so you‚Äôre not going to shut any of those guys down we just need to tame the best we can. I think tackling is going to be a big key for us as well as getting a lot of guys the ball and hopefully being able to create some turnovers.‚Äù


**Quarterback Philip Rivers**

**Are there some hard feelings between you and Jay Cutler?**
‚ÄúNo, there really isn‚Äôt. It got a lot of attention about a year ago actually, but there‚Äôs really nothing there.‚Äù

**What‚Äôs different about the Broncos from the team you faced in Week 2?**
‚ÄúObviously they‚Äôve had a lot of unfortunate injuries so you see a lot of different guys in the lineup. They‚Äôve haven‚Äôt had the same 11 on the field for a long period of time. Other than that, they‚Äôre playing a lot of the same stuff. It comes down to one game, so you‚Äôve got to prepare for anything.‚Äù

**Why do you think the rivalry between you and Cutler has drawn so much attention?**
‚ÄúIt‚Äôs exciting. First off, Chargers-Broncos (game) is exciting every year, especially the last couple. We‚Äôve been battling for the division. You‚Äôre always looking for match-ups to throw things in the mix but I know one thing and I know Jay feels the same way: we‚Äôre not playing one another out there. We‚Äôve both got tough defenses to worry about and we‚Äôre trying to help both of our teams advance into the playoffs.‚Äù

**What did you ask for for Christmas?**
‚ÄúNothing. I‚Äôve felt like I‚Äôve just about got everything. I feel fortunate. I don‚Äôt really have a lot of wants and needs. It‚Äôs about the kids at this point.‚Äù

**What was your favorite gift you received as a child?**
‚ÄúI have a lot. You obviously always remember a bicycle I guess you got. For me, probably my favorite was I had a basketball court in the back that got paved and painted the lines on it and everything. That was probably the one that sticks out the most.‚Äù

**Is this team peaking at the right time?**
‚ÄúI hope so. Again, I think we‚Äôve played good sporadically all year long. We lost a lot of close games. I don‚Äôt think we‚Äôve been that far off, I don‚Äôt think we‚Äôre all of the sudden there. We‚Äôre still sitting at 7-8 and have battled and won three in a row. Hopefully we‚Äôre going to continue to play better and we‚Äôll have a chance to play better into January.‚Äù

**Has it been hard to get over the Ed Hochuli call in the Week 2 game?**
‚ÄúSomewhat, but you‚Äôve got to move on to the game next week. I think as players, thinking back to how we handled it, we can really only worry about what we could have controlled differently. There‚Äôs plays obviously as you watch that tape, individually and collectively we could have done differently that would have not caused it to come down to a call. I know much has been made about it. I‚Äôve heard a lot about it this week. I don‚Äôt really think it‚Äôs in anybody‚Äôs minds at this point. We‚Äôre just excited to have the opportunity. We‚Äôve got one game to win the division.‚Äù

**Do you think you feel differently about it because now it does matter?**
‚ÄúHonestly, the fact that it was in Week 2, it was so long ago, we‚Äôve had so many tough losses and close games and opportunities to get it turned around, I really don‚Äôt think anybody hung their hat on that one game and tried to blame a season on that one game. We fought and scratched and battled and got to the point we are now to give ourselves a chance.‚Äù

**What have you learned about this team in the last three weeks?**
‚ÄúI think going back three weeks, remembering some of the things we were talking about here was, ‚ÄòWe‚Äôll find out.‚Äô We talk about what a close-knit group we‚Äôve got, a high character group with good leadership and a good group of guys. It‚Äôs easy when it‚Äôs 14-2 and you win (six) in a row last year to finish the season. That‚Äôs when it‚Äôs easy to be a good teammate and all those things, but we really got tested this year. I think all we did was prove to ourselves and hopefully to a lot people that we are who we thought we were. Now all we‚Äôve done is put ourselves in a position. We haven‚Äôt done anything. The one thing we‚Äôve got to understand is we‚Äôve done nothing. We‚Äôre still 7-8. We just now have been given an opportunity to go accomplish what we set out to early in the year.‚Äù

**What does it say about a division when a 7-8 team and an 8-7 team are playing for a playoff spot?**
‚ÄúI don‚Äôt know. It says the two things at the top have been inconsistent really. Denver has lost some tough games as well as we have. We‚Äôve won some big games. You hear about how not very good the AFC West is but yet we‚Äôve beat a lot of teams in some other conferences that are at the top of their divisions as well. You think back to New England and the Jets and some of those teams that we‚Äôve played and won. I know it‚Äôs two teams that are capable, that‚Äôs for sure. It‚Äôll be exciting, two teams that obviously are good enough to win the division because we‚Äôre in the position. Regardless of record I think it‚Äôs clear that we are the two best teams in the division, right there at the top and it‚Äôs good that it‚Äôs going to get to come down to being decided out there on the field.‚Äù

**Are the Broncos now a bigger rival for the Chargers than the Raiders?**
‚ÄúIt‚Äôs probably that way anyway. That‚Äôs no slight to Oakland, but the past couple of years, even though some of the games have been close, we‚Äôve beat Oakland pretty consistently. Denver, it‚Äôs always a tough game every year. It seems every year us and them are going to be battling for a division. It‚Äôs turned into a good rival and it will continue to be one. There are a lot of young players on that team. They‚Äôve struggled with injuries. They‚Äôre only going to get better in time and we feel like we‚Äôre a team that‚Äôs continuing to grow, that‚Äôs going to be hopefully battling for a division every year. I think there will be nothing but more and more exciting games and matchups with these two teams just like it will be here on Sunday.


**Linebacker Stephen Cooper**

**Can you tell us about the bad blood between the two teams? Has it intensified over the last couple weeks?**
‚ÄúYes, it has intensified but that‚Äôs because they‚Äôre an AFC West opponent. We‚Äôve been battling the last couple years in who is going to win the AFC West and it‚Äôs been a battle between us and Denver and that‚Äôs why it‚Äôs become a rivalry game. ‚Äù

**Do you think there is more of a rivalry with them than the Raiders?**
‚ÄúPeople build it up to be like that because they have a great quarterback and we have a great quarterback. At the end of the day, it‚Äôs 11 guys going out there trying to do a great job and win the AFC West.‚Äù

**What‚Äôs different about this Denver team?**
‚ÄúWell, they‚Äôre not playing at high level right now but it‚Äôs for the title. It‚Äôs to go in the playoffs. Jake Cutler is one of the best in the league. He‚Äôs going into the Pro Bowl. Brandon Marshall is one of the premier wide receivers. We‚Äôre going to go out there as a defense and prevent them from scoring. Our offense can put up points but we have to do a great job in all three aspects.‚Äù

**On if the team is on a roll:**
‚ÄúI think so. I think we‚Äôre playing well. We finally put together a whole game on special teams, offense and defense. We put up 41 points. We prevented them from scoring and we did a good job on special teams. If we can carry that over, I think we will be successful.‚Äù

**What do you have to do as a defense to help ?**
‚ÄúWe have to play physical. We have to go out there and stop the game like we did in Tampa. Our offense gets seven points and our defense gets a three and out. We have to control the field position with our special teams.‚Äù

**On your play:**
‚ÄúIt has a lot to do with our defensive coordinator putting me in good position. Guys like Shaun Phillips and Antoine Applewhite getting to the quarterback. Three of my interceptions came off pressure from them. A lot of guys have been talking about that all year long to get pressure on the quarterback. We‚Äôve been doing that as of late.‚Äù

**What are you asking for Christmas?**
‚ÄúA win over Denver.‚Äù

**As kid, what was a memorable gift?**
‚ÄúMy first bike when I was seven years old. I remember seeing my mom bringing into the house about midnight and she said it was from Santa Claus. I believed it. I know Santa Claus is coming again and I hope he brings me a victory.‚Äù

**What have you learned about this team?**
‚ÄúYou never give up. The guys stuck together the whole time and we play with a lot of confidence as you could see in Kansas City. We almost let one get away especially going to Arrowhead and playing in that environment. It‚Äôs tough. I think we did a good job as a team. Our offense did a good job of getting 14 points in the last four minutes.‚Äù

**On LT‚Äôs talk after the Atlanta loss:**
‚ÄúWhen ever LT opens his mouth, it always gets our attention. He doesn‚Äôt really open up his mouth too much. He lets his play speak for himself. When LT speaks, we have to listen because he‚Äôs a leader of our team. He came in at the end of that game and he said ‚ÄòGuys we‚Äôre going to turn it around. We‚Äôre not going to give up.‚Äô That‚Äôs what we‚Äôre doing.‚Äù

**On how Ron Rivera has affected the defense:**
‚ÄúHe‚Äôs doing a great job making it simple. He‚Äôs letting us go out there and play defense. We‚Äôre not worrying about checking out defenses. We‚Äôre just going out there and making plays.‚Äù


**Running Back LaDainian Tomlinson**

**Why aren‚Äôt you wearing any TCU clothing?**
‚ÄúWe act like we‚Äôve been there before (laughing).‚Äù

**How exciting was it to watch the Poinsettia Bowl? **
‚ÄúIt was pretty exciting to watch, especially with how big of a game everybody was talking about it being. It was a big game because of the hype of the game, Boise being undefeated, everybody talking about they possibly could have been in a BCS game. TCU could have been in a BCS game. It was a big game and we knew we had a lot to prove and wanted to give Boise State their first loss. It was a great win and I was happy to be there.‚Äù

**Were you the honorary coach for TCU?**
‚ÄúI guess it‚Äôs a tradition now, when they come out here they always put my locker up in the coaches‚Äô locker room. I would rather be in the players‚Äô locker room, but the coaches‚Äô locker room is good enough. Since I was an honorary coach, I did say something to the team before the game, so I would like to say my talk helped them out.‚Äù

**What‚Äôs different about Denver now from the team you faced in Week 2?**
‚ÄúThey‚Äôve had a couple of injury problems obviously on defense. Some of their key guys have been out in the middle part of the season, but I think they‚Äôre getting back to being that team that we saw early in the year. It looks like the guys are getting back healthy. They‚Äôre going to be a tough team no matter what everybody thinks. Losing two straight, that doesn‚Äôt matter. They know they need to win one game so they‚Äôre going to come here ready to play.‚Äù

**Do you think the Chargers are peaking at the right time?**
‚ÄúI think so. I really think we are peaking. We had talked about playing our best football at the end of December into January. It seems like we‚Äôre doing that.‚Äù

**When you went to Denver in Week 2 you were battling the toe injury. How much different do you feel this time around?**
‚ÄúLet‚Äôs see‚Ä¶this is Week 17, that was Week 2; about 15 weeks better. I‚Äôm not worn down at all to be honest with you. I don‚Äôt know where my carries are. I don‚Äôt know if I have 300 carries yet, but last week I felt good. This week I feel good. I think by me feeling good right now at this time of the season, it‚Äôs perfect, especially if we win this game and get into the playoffs.‚Äù

**How much different do you feel than at this time last year?**
‚ÄúLast year at this time I was still healthy. It was the playoff game where I hurt my knee. If things continue to go like they‚Äôve been, pretty much stay healthy, I like our chances.‚Äù

**As well as you know the Broncos, what do you look for when you watch film?**
‚ÄúI look at any new blitzes that they may be putting in, anything that they may try to do to kind of mix it up a little bit. That‚Äôs the thing to me that over the years their defense has been real good at, bringing corners, catching you at different times in the game to cause game-changing plays on defense, coming up with stops when they need to. I like to look at the blitzes to make sure that I‚Äôm in tune with everything they might try to do.‚Äù

**Do you think of yourself in more of a blocking mode when Denver is on the schedule?**
‚ÄúNo, I wouldn‚Äôt say a blocking mode. I‚Äôd just say aware. You have to make sure you‚Äôre aware of what‚Äôs going on because with some teams you don‚Äôt really have to be aware of them blitzing and the things that they‚Äôre doing. With this team, because they have so many people in the box a lot of times, you‚Äôve got to really pay attention to where the safeties are, where the corners are lined up, where the linebackers are because if they do happen to blitz somebody, you don‚Äôt know where it‚Äôs coming from because they all are up along the line of scrimmage.‚Äù

**Have you come to the point where you now think of Denver as your main rival rather than the Raiders?**
‚ÄúIn terms of winning and losing games and not really dominating the series like we have with Oakland, yeah I think it would be fair to say that this is much more of a rivalry. That comes with you beating them sometimes, they beat you and you go back and forth.‚Äù

**Is there as much bad blood and extra curricular stuff between these two teams as some of the others?**
‚ÄúThere is kind of a little extra activity that goes on out there. I‚Äôm pretty sure there will be a lot of that going on this weekend with so much on the line and two teams that really don‚Äôt care for each other.‚Äù

**In the long run, is it fair to say that the increased emphasis on the pass has been better for you?**
‚ÄúI wouldn‚Äôt say that.‚Äù

**How do you deal with it?**
‚ÄúIt‚Äôs part of my job to make sure that I do everything possible to help this team win and if that‚Äôs doing more in the passing game then so be it.‚Äù

**After the loss to Atlanta, you addressed the team in the locker room. What motivated you to do that?**
‚ÄúI don‚Äôt know. It was something on my heart to say something to the team because at that time it looked like we were pretty much done. When that happens, I‚Äôve been on a team before where they have tanked. They‚Äôll say, ‚ÄòThe season is over and we don‚Äôt really have anything to play for.‚Äô At that point it was all about not quitting and staying with it, finishing strong and being prideful about finishing our work, finishing the season strong. That‚Äôs basically what it was about.‚Äù

**That‚Äôs not something you do that often, is it?**
‚ÄúTo me, I‚Äôm not going to get up in front of the team and talk a lot. I don‚Äôt want to do that, I don‚Äôt want to be that way. Also I think it gets kind of fake when guys hear you saying something all the time. They kind of get tired of you talking all the time. I feel like when I really need to say something, then I‚Äôll really say something.‚Äù

**What did you learn about this group in the last three weeks?**
‚ÄúIt was stuff I already knew about them. This team is a never-say-die-attitude type team. It‚Äôs a really unique team from that standpoint of always believing that they‚Äôre still in it no matter how far we‚Äôre down or how many games out of first place we may be. This team to me has a knack for staying focused and really continuing to play football.‚Äù

**What are your thoughts on the Buffalo Bills?**
‚ÄúGod bless them.‚Äù

**Did you exchange text messages with any of their guys?**
‚ÄúNo. I would have if Aaron Schobel had played. I don‚Äôt know if he played or not, but that‚Äôs the guy I know well. In my mind I wanted to but I just kind of forgot about it and got to thinking about that TCU game.‚Äù

**What do you want for Christmas?**
‚ÄúA win. That‚Äôs what I‚Äôm asking for. I‚Äôve got everything I need and want except for a win on Sunday. We (TCU) beat the (Boise State) Broncos last night. It would be good to beat the Broncos on Sunday.‚Äù

**What‚Äôs your most memorable Christmas gift you‚Äôve ever received?**
‚ÄúMy most memorable gift was a banana seat bicycle with the long seat. That was the first bike I had and that bike gave me a lot of trouble. It put knots on my head from running into trees and stop signs and stuff. It was my first bike and I remember it.‚Äù

**Do you think Ed Hochuli is glad that this game means something?**
‚ÄúI think he‚Äôd rather be part of it, refereeing in it. But no, I think Ed, I really believe that he‚Äôs probably happy that this is a game that‚Äôs going to mean something, that whatever happened at the beginning of the year, it doesn‚Äôt mean anything now. I really believe that‚Äôs the way he feels.‚Äù

**No you guys feel that way as well, you have a chance to erase that moment?**
‚ÄúAbsolutely. We can‚Äôt sit here and blame Ed for that call because right now it doesn‚Äôt mean anything. We have the opportunity to make that go away and really for people to forget about it. That‚Äôs our focus.‚Äù

**Can you talk about the buzz in San Diego right now surrounding the Chargers?**
‚ÄúIt‚Äôs extremely exciting right now around town. At the toy drive I had yesterday, I can‚Äôt tell you how many people were talking about this game on Sunday and looking forward to it. People are really excited and I‚Äôm happy we‚Äôve got that fever back here in San Diego. I think that‚Äôs the way it should be around here. It‚Äôs a great sports town and hopefully we can keep that going.‚Äù

**Do you feel you take more cheap shots against the Broncos than against other teams?**
‚ÄúI take a fair amount of cheap shots against them and probably a couple of other guys, too. That goes right along with the chippy-ness and the extracurricular activity stuff that goes on. If that‚Äôs the way they‚Äôre going to be then we‚Äôre going to get our guys to do the same thing. That‚Äôs just the way it‚Äôs going to work.‚Äù

**Is that different from other teams you‚Äôve played?**
‚ÄúYes. Absolutely.‚Äù

**Stephen Cooper just said there‚Äôs no animosity. You disagree?**
‚ÄúYeah, he‚Äôs being nice.‚Äù

Title: Two special teams plays costly

Body.Content:
Chargers safety Eric Weddle called it a ‚Äúfreak play,‚Äù a term that could have been used to describe a handful of occurrences Sunday, particularly in the kicking game.

The Bolts, who are widely regarded as one of the best special teams units in the NFL, fell victim to two anomalies Sunday that played major roles in their season-ending loss in Pittsburgh.

‚ÄúOur special teams have been one of our strengths and been something that have been fabulous since I‚Äôve been here,‚Äù Head Coach Norv Turner said.

The first big play came in the opening quarter when Santonio Holmes became the first player to return a Mike Scifres punt for a touchdown. Holmes‚Äô 67-yard return saw him make an initial man miss, giving him a clear path down the sideline thanks to Pittsburgh‚Äôs return team.

‚ÄúThey did a great job on one of our gunners and when they got kicked back on the punt return there was no one there,‚Äù Turner said. ‚ÄúWe know he‚Äôs dangerous once he gets started. That play was the difference in the first half and it was a big play in the game.‚Äù

The second was the one Weddle spoke of. After the Chargers got a defensive stop in the third quarter, Pittsburgh‚Äôs Mitch Berger hit a high, short punt, so short that it hit an unsuspecting Weddle in the back of the head. The Steelers recovered the loose ball and although they didn‚Äôt score, it was another blow to a third quarter that saw the Chargers run one offensive play.

‚ÄúIt was just such a short punt,‚Äù Weddle said. ‚ÄúWhen I was running I looked back at Sproles and he was a ways from there. My first thought was, ‚ÄòHe‚Äôs going to catch it. I‚Äôm going to get to my guy now.‚Äô As soon as I got my hands engaged, it hit me.‚Äù

The day did provide highlights in the kicking game as well. Antwan Applewhite and Jacob Hester snuffed out a fake punt attempt in the second quarter, which led to a 42-yard field goal by Nate Kaeding.

The kick came despite Kaeding battling a sore groin, which kept him from kicking off early in the game.

**Going in, coming out**

Sunday‚Äôs game also swung on two possessions that blanketed halftime. After the Bolts went up 10-7 in the second quarter, they couldn‚Äôt stop the Steelers in the final minutes as Willie Parker put Pittsburgh on top.

The Steelers opened the third quarter with a drive that covered nearly eight minutes and saw them convert three 3rd-and-long opportunities.

‚ÄúIt was one of the most important drives of the game,‚Äù linebacker Shaun Phillips said. ‚ÄúI always try to preach that, ‚ÄòCome on, we‚Äôve got to buck up. We‚Äôve got to get this momentum coming out of half time.‚Äô Those two drives gave them a little bit of confidence.‚Äù

**Spectator status**

For the first time in his career, an injury caused LaDainian Tomlinson to be inactive Sunday. After the game, LT admitted it was tough to watch.

‚ÄúI don‚Äôt know if you can really get an idea for what it‚Äôs like,‚Äù Tomlinson said. ‚ÄúInjuries happen. Everybody goes through them. That‚Äôs what I was dealt with and I was hoping that the guys could pull through without me.‚Äù

Had the Chargers won, Tomlinson would have ‚Äútried to warm up next week‚Äù and participate in the AFC Championship Game. He‚Äôs holding out hope that he won‚Äôt need surgery to repair his strained groin but hasn‚Äôt ruled out the possibility.

Prior to Sunday, LT was inactive only one other time in his eight-year career. That came in the final week of the 2004 season when the Bolts had clinched the AFC West and rested several starters.

**Unifying month**

The Chargers were quick to express disappointment Sunday but also took a bit of pride in their resilience. After becoming the first 4-8 team to make the playoffs, the Bolts learned a lot about themselves.

‚ÄúOne thing I‚Äôve learned is that we‚Äôre a bunch of guys that will fight with their backs against the wall,‚Äù Phillips said. ‚ÄúI‚Äôll sleep in a foxhole with any of these guys.‚Äù

Moments after it came to an end, the Bolts had a hard time putting the season in perspective.

‚ÄúIt‚Äôs tough because we didn‚Äôt accomplish our goal,‚Äù wide receiver Chris Chambers said. ‚ÄúWe did some good things and I think we grew in a lot of ways but there are 31 teams that go home disappointed and we‚Äôre one of them.‚Äù

**Clutch again**
Two week, no practice, two big performances. That was the line for tight end Antonio Gates this postseason. A high ankle sprain left him questionable for both playoff games, but the five-time Pro Bowler fought through the pain and delivered. He led the Chargers in catches last week against Indianapolis and tied for the team lead with five Sunday.

‚ÄúI‚Äôm a competitor and I was going to do whatever it took to be out there,‚Äù Gates said.

Gates opened the game with a 21-yard catch on the first play of the day and finished with five grabs for 59 yards.

**Escaping pressure**

The Chargers sacked Steelers quarterback Ben Roethlisberger just one time Sunday as he completed 17-of-26 throws.

‚ÄúThey‚Äôre a very good pass blocking group,‚Äù Turner said. ‚Äú(Roethlisberger) does a good job of sliding and moving. They‚Äôve got places to get the ball out. I didn‚Äôt expect this thing to be where we were able to get him off his mark every single time.‚Äù

Roethlisberger was also aided by a running game that produced 165 yards and what the Chargers called an afternoon of team execution.

‚ÄúThey did a good job of max protecting,‚Äù Cooper said. ‚ÄúThey were keeping seven guys in and running three-man routes. They did a good job in their blocking schemes.‚Äù

**Deceiving numbers**

Philip Rivers lauded the play of running back Darren Sproles, who had just 15 yards on 11 carries but never got much of a chance to get going Sunday.

‚ÄúThe thing they did to him was keep him sitting over there,‚Äù Rivers said. ‚ÄúHe was sitting on the bench and didn‚Äôt get to do much in the second half.‚Äù

Sproles caught five passes for 91 yards, including a late 62-yard touchdown, and had a 63-yard kickoff return.

Title: After strong finish, Bolts‚Äô defense looks forward

Body.Content:
It‚Äôs not how you start, it‚Äôs how you finish.

After a rocky start during the first half of the season, the Chargers found a new leader and renewed aggressiveness on defense that allowed the team to finish strong and claim a third-consecutive AFC West title.

Ron Rivera was promoted to defensive coordinator prior to Week 9, and the Chargers allowed 6.4 fewer points per game under his watch than they did in the first half of 2008. During the club‚Äôs four-game December winning streak, the Bolts intercepted eight passes. They had just seven picks in their first 12 games.

The Bolts took a blow when linebacker Shawne Merriman was lost for the season after Week 1. Still the club fought through, and they‚Äôll welcome the three-time Pro Bowler back in 2009.

Up front, the Chargers were led by yet another stellar season from Jamal Williams in 2008, who started all 16 games and posted 10 tackles for loss. Luis Castillo started 15 games at left defensive end after signing a contract extension last summer. Right end Igor Olshansky saw his playing time drop towards the end of the season and is an unrestricted free agent.

Jacques Cesaire had a typical year for the gritty veteran, filling in at different spots up front and serving as a more than capable backup. Ryon Bingham saw time at both end and nose tackle, and both he and Cesaire are candidates to replace Olshansky in the starting lineup should Olshansky leave during free agency. Ian Scott signed with the Bolts three games into the 2008 campaign and appeared in four contests. He‚Äôll likely be in the mix as a reserve again next season.

Despite missing the first four games of the season, Stephen Cooper had another strong year. He led the team in tackles and interceptions with four, more than any other NFL linebackers. Matt Wilhelm and Tim Dobbins split time beside Cooper. Dobbins saw the most extensive action of his three-year career and turned in a key interception in a win in Oakland and provided perhaps the biggest defensive play of the year, a fourth-quarter sack of Peyton Manning that gave the Chargers a chance to tie and eventually beat the Colts in the playoffs.

Brandon Siler continued to be a monster on special teams and was a key part of three goal line stands on defense. Fellow second-year linebacker Anthony Waters also made his mark in the kicking game.

Shaun Phillips led the team with 7.5 sacks while essentially playing out of position. With Merriman out for the year, Phillips shifted from his more natural weak side spot to the strong side and had 15 tackles for loss. Merriman‚Äôs return in 2009 will allow Phillips to slide back to the ‚ÄúWill‚Äù position.

Jyles Tucker recorded 5.5 sacks while starting 12 games but is expected to move back into a reserve role upon Merriman‚Äôs return. One of the more pleasant surprises for the Chargers was the play of outside linebacker Antwan Applewhite, who played well in spot duty on defense and was a force on special teams. Marques Harris, who had 2.5 sacks last season, is an unrestricted free agent.

In the secondary, Eric Weddle‚Äôs strong second half allowed him to show the promise the Chargers thought he had when they moved up in the 2007 Draft to get him. He finished second on the club in tackles and appeared to get better as the year went on. Clinton Hart battled injuries throughout the year, which created opportunities for Steve Gregory towards the end of the season. Second-year pro Paul Oliver also saw his playing time increase as the year went on and could see his role continue to grow.

Cornerback Quentin Jammer had perhaps his finest season of his career as he led the club with 19 passes defensed. Antonio Cromartie suffered a hip injury in Week 1 that nagged him throughout the year and kept him from enjoying the same success he had in 2007. He looks to return at full strength in 2009.

Antoine Cason, the team‚Äôs top draft pick, had a solid rookie campaign as the nickel corner and tied for second on the team with 15 special teams tackles. Cletis Gordon is a restricted free agent after seeing his most significant action of his career.

Title: Disappointment overshadows positives

Body.Content:
Moments after Sunday‚Äôs loss in Pittsburgh, linebacker Stephen Cooper called the season a major disappointment simply because it ended knowing another team will hoist the Lombardi Trophy in two weeks.

After a little time to reflect, Cooper found plenty he and his teammates could hang their hats on.

‚ÄúThere‚Äôs a positive and negative to it,‚Äù Cooper said. ‚ÄúThe negative is that our goal is to win a Super Bowl and we didn‚Äôt do that. The positive is we rallied in the end around each other and came together as a team.‚Äù

Monday was a reflective day for the Bolts as they went through their end-of-season physicals and had their final team meetings. Players thought back on the long road they took, one that included an 0-2 start, a trip to London, four last-second losses, a 4-8 record at the end of November and ultimately a five-game winning streak that put them within reach of hosting the AFC Championship Game.

‚ÄúThis was the strangest of all the seasons since I‚Äôve been here,‚Äù said quarterback Philip Rivers, who players voted the team‚Äôs co-MVP Monday along with Jamal Williams.

‚ÄúA lot of good things mixed in with a lot of things that weren‚Äôt so good. You‚Äôre never ultimately happy unless you win it all, but as the dust settles, there will be a lot of things we‚Äôll look back, a lot of great memories from games, a lot of bad memories from close finishes but really a season with a bunch of memorable plays and games and certainly a lot to be proud of.‚Äù

Several Chargers echoed Cooper‚Äôs sense of unity and pride of the way the Bolts hung together to create a memorable December.

‚ÄúThis was a team that fought every game, even when it didn‚Äôt seem like we were going to even make it to the playoffs, win our division,‚Äù running back LaDainian Tomlinson said. ‚ÄúThis team never stopped believing that we were an elite team in this league. I think that‚Äôs something that I‚Äôm going to take away because of the kind of guys we have on this team.‚Äù

They also shared in Cooper‚Äôs frustration over the fact that the season ended two weeks earlier than they would have liked.

‚ÄúObviously we didn‚Äôt have the season we wanted to have or expected to have record-wise and ultimate outcome,‚Äù Rivers said. ‚ÄúFrom that perspective, we fell short.‚Äù

Monday included a few lamentations. The Chargers had a chance to truly do something special but Sunday didn‚Äôt play up to the level they believe they‚Äôre capable of. The Bolts committed two turnovers in Pittsburgh, struggled to get off the field defensively and had a pair of misfortunate plays on special teams.

‚ÄúLate in the year we weren‚Äôt doing those things,‚Äù Cooper said. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs sad to see it happen in the playoff game. We‚Äôre going to go back to the drawing board and work hard this offseason to get back to Charger football.‚Äù

They also looked all the way back to the beginning of the season to a difficult first couple months that forced them to scratch and claw their way back into the divisional race.

‚ÄúThe last two years, September didn‚Äôt go the way we‚Äôd hoped,‚Äù safety Eric Weddle said. ‚ÄúDoing it this way is tiring. We‚Äôve got to be a complete team from day one next year.‚Äù

Rivers agreed with Weddle‚Äôs assessment.

‚ÄúWe got ourselves in a situation where we had to string eight in a row together,‚Äù Rivers said. ‚ÄúWe had to play eight elimination games to win it all. That‚Äôs tough to do. We stump our toe one time in Pittsburgh and have a crazy third quarter and it‚Äôs over. It‚Äôs hard fighting a battle up hill.‚Äù

Once team meetings concluded Monday afternoon, players bid their farewells to each other. They‚Äôll have approximately six weeks off before the club‚Äôs offseason conditioning program begins. Rivers and company will spend at least the next few days adjusting to a completely different pace of life.

‚ÄúThe first couple days are tough because you‚Äôve been in such a routine and such a focus for‚Ä¶20 weeks now,‚Äù Rivers said. ‚ÄúAll of the sudden it‚Äôs over. It‚Äôll settle in and you kind of get away from it a little bit and then you gear up and go at it again.‚Äù

**Rivera to Lions?**
****
Chargers Head Coach Norv Turner confirmed Monday that Defensive Coordinator Ron Rivera may interview with the [Detroit Lions](http://www.detroitlions.com/) for their vacant head coaching position. Rivera joined the Bolts as inside linebackers coach prior to the 2007 season and held that position until being promoted to defensive coordinator on Oct. 28.

During the final half of the season, the Chargers gave up nearly seven fewer points and seventy fewer yards per game.

‚ÄúThat was our spark in the middle of the season,‚Äù Cooper said. ‚ÄúGuys rallied behind him and played great defense.‚Äù

Rivera has been a hot candidate for head coaching jobs in the past and even interviewed for the job that Turner received in 2007 with the Chargers. Cooper selfishly hopes Rivera returns to San Diego, but would be happy for his coach should he land a top gig.

‚ÄúGuys would be sad but it‚Äôs part of the business,‚Äù Cooper said. ‚ÄúGuys come and go, whether it‚Äôs players or coaches. If it does happen, more power to him. He deserves a head coaching job. He‚Äôs a great coach and a great person.‚Äù

**Wait and see**
****
Tomlinson hopes that a month of rest will allow his strained groin to heal, but he hasn‚Äôt ruled out the possibility of offseason surgery.

‚ÄúWe‚Äôve got a deadline that if I‚Äôm not feeling better by then, then we probably might have to do something,‚Äù Tomlinson said. ‚ÄúHopefully we won‚Äôt have to because I think in a month‚Äôs time I feel like I‚Äôll be feeling better.‚Äù

Sunday was the first time in LT‚Äôs NFL career in which injury caused him to be inactive for a game. He said that he‚Äôs talked to other players who have dealt with his injury and successfully seen the strain heal without an operation.

**Plans for ‚Äò09**
****
Turner said Monday that he and General Manager A.J. Smith would wait until a later date to discuss how the team will move forward this offseason. The Chargers currently have 43 players under contract for the 2009 season.

Unrestricted free agents include guard Kynan Forney, guard Mike Goff, linebacker Marques Harris, center Jeremy Newberry, defensive end Igor Olshansky and running back Darren Sproles. Wide receiver Malcom Floyd and cornerback Cletis Gordon are restricted free agents, and tackle Jeromey Clary is an exclusive rights free agent.

The Chargers will select 16
HTML NO SUPPORTED : th in the first round of April‚Äôs NFL Draft.

Title: Chargers make coaching changes

Body.Content:
The Chargers announced Tuesday that four assistant coaches from the 2008 squad will not return to the team next season.

Secondary coach Bill Bradley and tight end coach Clancy Barone, both of whom just completed their second seasons with the Bolts, were released from their contracts.

In addition, the contracts for offensive line coach Jack Henry and assistant secondary/quality control coach Kevin Ross are due to expire in February and both men will not return in 2009.

Henry, a veteran of 15 NFL seasons, joined the Chargers in 2006 and was also with the club in 1996. Ross played cornerback for the Bolts in 1996 and worked with Chargers defensive backs in 2007 and ‚Äô08.

‚ÄúWe appreciate the contributions and hard work of these four men and wish them only the best in their future endeavors,‚Äù Head Coach Norv Turner said.

Title: Contratan a apoyador

Body.Content:
El jugador defensivo llegar√° a los electrizantes tras haber defendido la causa de los Vaqueros de Dallas las anteriores cuatro temporadas, sus primeras en la NFL, se espera que ayudar√° a la franquicia sandieguina en la defensa y en unidad de equipos especiales.  

‚ÄúEstamos emocionados de tener la oportunidad de agregar un fenomenal jugador de futbol americano a nuestro equipo‚Äù, asegur√≥ AJ Smith, gerente general del equipo, ‚ÄúKevin es excelente en situaciones de pateo adem√°s que tiene experiencia de desarrollarse en un sistema defensivo muy similar al que tenemos ac√°, nos sentimos realmente bendecidos de tenerlo a bordo‚Äù.

Title: Bolts find little room, opportunity to run

Body.Content:
After having two great weeks running the ball on the ground against the Broncos and Colts, the Chargers rushing attack met its match Sunday when they came in to Pittsburgh.

During the regular season, the Steelers held opponents to only 80.2 yards per game on the ground, the second-lowest total in the NFL. Thanks in part to Pittsburgh‚Äôs stellar play and due in part to the way the game panned out, the Chargers gained just 15 yards on 11 carries.

‚ÄúThey did a great job,‚Äù running back Micheal Bennett said. ‚ÄúFor the most part of the game they were up. Although it was tied for a moment, they got up on us and we were forced to go to our passing game. We still had our chances, but there were some mishaps. You have got to give them credit. They played a great game.‚Äù

With the Chargers trailing and points needing to be thrown up on the scoreboard, the Bolts were forced to go to their passing game. They ended up with no rushing attempts in the second half and only 12 total rush attempts in the entire game.

‚ÄúWe didn‚Äôt do a good enough job,‚Äù tackle Jeromey Clary said. ‚ÄúIn the third quarter we only touched the ball once. The one time we touched it we had a turnover. It‚Äôs hard to win a game when you do that.‚Äù

The Steelers also won the time of possession battle holding the ball on offense for a total of 36:30, which totaled to thirteen minutes more than the Chargers who held the ball of only 23:30.

‚ÄúTime of possession also really hurt us,‚Äù Clary said. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs not that we could not rush the ball, we just had no choice. We just didn‚Äôt do our job and we didn‚Äôt take care of our business.‚Äù

Darren Sproles rushed for all 15 yards on offense but shined once again in the return game and scored on a 62-yard touchdown towards the end of the game.

‚ÄúWe kept running outside zones and stuff like that,‚Äù Sproles said. ‚ÄúThat felt pretty good but we had to get away from it because we got down so fast.‚Äù

Even though Sproles made a couple big plays in the passing game and had a 62-yard kickoff return Sunday, the Steelers were pleased that they were able to limit him on the ground.

‚ÄúWe definitely did not want to get him going,‚Äù Steelers Linebacker LaMarr Woodley said. ‚ÄúEarly in the game, we did what we were supposed to as a team by staying in our rush lanes and not allowing him to see the hole and hit it.‚Äù

The Chargers were held to 5-of-12 on third downs Sunday, which were regularly third-and-long situations. Playing from behind and having nine or ten yards to go on third downs, the Chargers were forced to throw the ball.

Although the Bolts defense came up with a stop or two in crucial situations, the Chargers offense just could not dig them out of a deficit.

‚ÄúThey made the most out of their situation,‚Äù Head Coach Norv Turner said. ‚ÄúThey opened the third quarter with a long drive for a touchdown. We return the kick, the ball is batted in the air and then they have the ball until the end of the quarter. You don‚Äôt get a chance to get the rushing attempts.‚Äù

Chargers quarterback Philip Rivers was sacked four times, thanks in part to the fact that situations made the Bolts somewhat one dimensional.

‚ÄúYou try to keep it consistent,‚Äù Rivers said. ‚ÄúYou try to continue to work at it, but when you get behind 18 points in the fourth quarter, you have to open it up and throw the ball.‚Äù

Title: Southern California to see Chargers-Colts playoff game

Body.Content:
Enough tickets have been sold to lift the local television blackout of Saturday night‚Äôs nationally-televised AFC Wild Card Playoff Game between the Chargers and the [Indianapolis Colts](http://www.colts.com/). There is small number of Club seats, single seats and suites still available.  

The game kicks off at 5:08 pm PT and will be televised live in San Diego on NBC 7/39 and in Los Angeles and Orange County on KNBC Channel 4.  Al Michaels and John Madden will call the action and Andrea Kremer will report from the sidelines.    

The radio broadcast can be heard in San Diego on KIOZ Rock 105.3 FM and XTRA Sports 1360 AM in San Diego and KLAC 570 AM in Los Angeles. Josh Lewin and Hank Bauer call the action from the booth and Jim Laslavic reports from the sideline. Jorge Villanueva, Adrian Garcia and Efren Dominguez call the game in Spanish on XHFG 107.3 FM in San Diego and KWKW 1330 AM in Los Angeles.  

Special note for all Season Ticket Holders: Season Ticket Holders who have paid for their postseason tickets must either print their tickets online at www.Chargers.com and My Chargers Account, or pick them up at Gate C Will Call at Qualcomm Stadium anytime Wednesday through Friday from 8 am ‚Äì 6 pm (including New Years Day). Accounts with pre-paid parking must pick up their parking pass at Gate C Will Call. Parking passes cannot be printed online.  Will Call for Season Ticket Holder postseason tickets will NOT be available on game day.  For additional postseason information, please log onto www.Chargers.com.
