Title: Transcripts: Turner, Rivers, Tomlinson, Gates & McNeill

Body.Content: **Head Coach Norv Turner********How much more important will the running game be due to the weather?**‚ÄúThe key when you go play back East on a tough field like we‚Äôre going to be on is like you said, running the football is critical, stopping the run is critical. After that, field position and special teams are such a big part of it. Our guys are getting primed, our punt team particularly. Mike (Scifres) is on a role and punting so well and that should help us in the football game. Then, when you have opportunities to make some big plays you just have to take advantage of it.‚Äù** ****Did you guys exercise your East Coast demons when you beat Tampa?**‚ÄúIt‚Äôs a late game. We‚Äôre playing an awfully good team. When I went back and looked at the first Pittsburgh game, we were on the East Coast and there were a lot of good things that we did in that game. It was an 11-10 game and it was a very, very physical game, it was a hard-fought game. They‚Äôre just an outstanding football team. I‚Äôm not sure (it would matter) if we played them on the East Coast or the West Coast. We know how difficult it‚Äôs going to be.‚Äù **Has being in the playoffs the last few years seasoned these guys?**‚ÄúPlaying in them and understanding, to me, it‚Äôs not about the game as much as the preparation. You have to prepare to do all of the same things you do in a regular season game. Sometimes I think younger players forget about that the bigger the game gets, and they start thinking about all the other things that are involved. We‚Äôve tried to keep a pretty even keel in terms of our preparation. Winning games in the post-season and having won games helps, but I think probably the thing that helps most is the guys that have been here long enough to go through those two tough defeats. I don‚Äôt know that you ever lose that feeling and I have reminded them a couple times of what feels like to be involved in a game like that and I think that is a great motivator.‚Äù ** ****How was LT today?**‚ÄúLT is sore. He‚Äôs in doing his treatment and those things. I don‚Äôt know that he‚Äôs a lot different than he was earlier in the week.‚Äù**If someone told you five weeks ago that Darren Sproles was going to be on the cover of Sports Illustrated, what would you have thought?**‚ÄúFive weeks ago. That was a long time ago. Nothing that happens for Darren or that he does would ever surprise me.‚Äù**Is Darren preparing differently this week because he will probably get more carries?**‚ÄúNo. Darren has always gotten a good percentage of the practice at running back because he plays a lot at running back. He‚Äôs played a lot through out the year at running back. LT couldn‚Äôt practice today so we‚Äôre giving his share to Michael Bennett, so I don‚Äôt think that part of it is a whole lot different.‚Äù **How much different is it for an offensive line to have to protect against a 4-3 defense rather than a 3-4?**‚ÄúIt‚Äôs a big change. We‚Äôre fortunate that we practice against it on a regular basis but we‚Äôve had a series of games now against a 4-3, so it‚Äôs a change. These guys are the best at it, Pittsburgh is the best at the 3-4, and they give you a lot of different looks. They‚Äôve got two really, really fine pass rushers on the outside, obviously the defensive MVP of the National Football League and they‚Äôre very creative with what they do. It‚Äôs not like last week where you line up and the guy is rushing every single time and you have to block him. They do a lot of different things and it‚Äôs demanding in terms of our preparation.‚Äù**What kinds of things set Ben Roethlisberger apart from other quarterbacks?**‚ÄúHe‚Äôs just a great, great competitor. We were fortunate enough to coach him and coach the AFC in the Pro Bowl, and he is uncanny at throwing the ball into tight spaces. He can put the ball anywhere he wants it on a receiver‚Äôs body, so if you have one side of him covered he can throw it to the other side. He‚Äôs got great vision, but the thing that obviously sets him apart or that he is especially gifted at is that he can move in that pocket and slide in the pocket and he can throw the ball to anybody anywhere on the field. Once he starts moving, you can‚Äôt worry about him running. From a coverage standpoint you have to cover the closest guy to you because he is liable to throw it to him.‚Äù**What is your reaction to Vincent Jackson making the news for something other than football?**‚ÄúWe‚Äôve handled that with the release. Obviously I‚Äôm disappointed. It‚Äôs something that is a league matter now in terms of evaluating his situation and what the ramifications are.‚Äù**Do you talk to your team about things like this before games of this magnitude?**‚ÄúWe spend a lot of time from the beginning of the season all the way through. The thing that I think that the league has done is that the league has programs and has done a great job of educating young player and veterans. They come in two or three times a year and talk to our players. We have in-house people that set up programs for our players, and being a father and having kids you‚Äôd like to think that you would never have to deal with something where a guy makes a mistake. As I say, we‚Äôll handle it the way we need to handle it.‚Äù**Will his playing time be effected?**‚ÄúNo.‚Äù**Did you have a meeting with Vincent individually?**‚ÄúI spent some time with Vincent, yes.‚Äù ** ****Quarterback Philip Rivers ****With Ben Roethlisberger coming from the same draft class as you, does that add anything to this weekend?**‚ÄúNo. We‚Äôre in the playoffs. It‚Äôs about us trying to advance. Really nothing more than that. Tough opponent, tough team at home with an outstanding defense. We‚Äôll have our work cut out for us. We‚Äôll need to play our best game of the year to win. I think we‚Äôre preparing right now so we can do that.‚Äù**Are you guys doing anything special to prepare for the cold?**‚ÄúThere‚Äôs really not much you can do to simulate it. I think obviously we can get a lot of good work done with the weather like this. We‚Äôve always handled the cold just fine. Obviously if there‚Äôs any precipitation, that‚Äôs when the weather can become a factor. Cold, once you get out there you deal with it and you go play. I don‚Äôt see that it will be a problem.‚Äù**Would it affect the game plan?**‚ÄúNo, based on so far I don‚Äôt see that it will have an affect on it at all.‚Äù**Does the fact that you played the Steelers so close a few weeks ago give you confidence?**‚ÄúI don‚Äôt know if it gives you more confidence. Obviously I think what it does say is two teams that went at it in Week 11, now there‚Äôs even more at stake. I think it‚Äôll be a heck of a game as it was then. We don‚Äôt think we played our best game then. They probably feel the same. It‚Äôll be another close game I can imagine.‚Äù**How do you balance protecting the ball versus being aggressive?**‚ÄúYou just go play. I think both turnovers really from a mentality standpoint were not the issue, just a throw that got away from me and then really a good play in the end zone where maybe I held onto it a little long. You‚Äôve still got to be aggressive. You understand as the game goes when to be more aggressive and when not to depending on what type of game it is. There are two good defenses right now. Our defense finished the season as hot as any ‚ÄòD‚Äô and Pittsburgh ranks right up there at one in every category. That‚Äôs what you expect in the playoffs. We saw last week what the field position game meant to us with Mike punting and Darren with some returns. Certainly we know that‚Äôs a factor, protecting the football and getting some points on the board. Again it will come down to the fourth quarter like most of them do.‚Äù**Do you feel like you‚Äôve exorcised the East Coast demons after the win in Tampa?**‚ÄúI don‚Äôt see that as being an issue. For whatever reason we did struggle. The fact that we are playing later on, it being at 4:45, it‚Äôll be similar to what a 1:00 kick is here for us, which is normal. I don‚Äôt see that being an issue.‚Äù**What do you personally do to deal with cold temperatures?**‚ÄúReally nothing. Just mentally you prepare to be cold. That‚Äôs about it. I‚Äôd probably have on a long sleeve shirt. Other than that you just go out and bare it and play. When you‚Äôre out there playing you don‚Äôt give much thought to it. We‚Äôve all played in cold games before. You think back over the years we‚Äôve played in cold games that are probably colder than this one. We all grew up in different parts of the country. Some of us grew up in cold weather and are used to it, some of us didn‚Äôt as some of the Steelers players. It‚Äôs not like everybody on that team grew up in Pittsburgh. It is what it is for both teams. You go out and play.‚Äù**If five weeks ago someone had told you Darren Sproles would be on the cover of *Sports Illustrated *the first week in January, what would have been your reaction?**‚ÄúI certainly believe Darren Sproles could do something spectacular to deserve being on there. I probably wouldn‚Äôt have expected it to be in a Chargers uniform based on where we were five weeks ago. It‚Äôs been an impressive run this far and an exciting one. Obviously I know where the expectations were for us coming in, for our fans coming in. They were that we‚Äôd be at this point. Now we‚Äôre here and we want to capitalize and make the best of it, not just be excited that we finished the season strong.‚Äù**Have you protected the ball better since the last trip to Pittsburgh?**‚ÄúIn Pittsburgh it wasn‚Äôt really out of the pocket when they got me. I always try to be conscience when you‚Äôre moving around of somebody coming behind you or getting it. Really the first Colts game when (Robert) Mathis got me from behind was one that‚Ä¶it‚Äôs that you never take it for granted or relax. It‚Äôs turnovers like that that kill you, that put it more and more ingrained in your mind. There‚Äôs no quarterback that wants to fumble or throw a pick so it‚Äôs not that I‚Äôm trying harder not to do that, but certainly the fact that we have stayed away from a lot of turnovers lately has certainly helped us go on the run that we have.‚Äù**How important is it going to be this weekend to establish the run?**‚ÄúI think we need to be able to run the football. I think if you look at the last‚Ä¶since we‚Äôve gone on the five-game winning streak we‚Äôve ran the football. I think it is key because it helps us in our play-action game and again we want to be as balanced as we can, especially when you‚Äôre playing against a defense like the Steelers. You look and they‚Äôre almost number one in every category. If you are able to put a drive together, you get down in the red zone and they‚Äôre one there too. They don‚Äôt let people get in the end zone. It‚Äôs going to be a challenge each and every possession. We‚Äôre going to work like crazy all week and on Sunday to get in the end zone.‚Äù**Do the Steelers have an advantage because of the amount of film they have on Sproles now?**‚ÄúI think it can work both ways. Obviously they‚Äôve seen him more now as an every-down back, getting some more conventional runs from the I-back position. At the same time, when LT‚Äôs healthy, (Sproles) comes in in more of a third-down role and all you hear is ‚ÄòDraw and screen!‚Äô from the opposing team. I think it can work both ways. He touched it 35 times last week including the special teams and I think he showed you‚Äôve got to be ready for anything. This is the same offense with him in there scheme wise. He can do a lot of things with the football so I don‚Äôt think there really is an advantage either way as far as what they‚Äôve seen on tape.‚Äù**With this being your sixth playoff game, how is it different for you than it was two years ago?**‚ÄúI think there is something to be said about having some experience in the playoffs. Just the type of atmosphere it brings, managing the week, managing these types of deals is something certainly to get used to. It‚Äôs always easier when you look back, but when I look back to the 14-2 season when we had the home playoff game and got beat, you wonder if it was a little too big for us. I don‚Äôt know. It‚Äôs always easier after you lose a game to say that. We did some things that were uncharacteristic of us in that game and there were a lot of guys on the field that had never been in that big of a game. I think the fact that we‚Äôve been in these types of games now, this is my sixth but there are a lot of guys that have played in a lot of big ones. You think of last year in Indy, last year in New England, going to Pittsburgh will be right up there, a similar type deal. I think from a hype standpoint, playoff game standpoint we‚Äôll be just fine.‚Äù**Do you ever study Roethlisberger to see what he does well?**‚ÄúI don‚Äôt specifically go find other quarterbacks to watch them. As you‚Äôre watching the Colts defense or you watch whoever you‚Äôre playing, when quarterbacks pop up you do watch them and see throws they‚Äôve made against the defense you‚Äôre about to play. Just from seeing him on TV and coming out the same year, he does a lot of things well. Most importantly he finds a way to help his team win games. That‚Äôs the ultimate deal for quarterbacks, you see him up there in double-digit wins every year and right there in the thick of things as they are this year.‚Äù **Running back LaDainian Tomlinson ****How important is it to establish the running game in the Pittsburgh weather?**‚ÄúI think it‚Äôs important to establish the running game in any weather really, just cause a team can‚Äôt particularly worry about one thing, whether it‚Äôs run or pass. They‚Äôve got to prepare for both of them.‚Äù**What‚Äôs your status for Sunday?**‚ÄúDoubtful.‚Äù**For lack of a better term, how much does it suck to be in the playoffs and not be able to play?**‚ÄúPretty much what you said, that‚Äôs how much it sucks.‚Äù**You think you‚Äôll be able to push it Sunday, test it?**‚ÄúI don‚Äôt know. All this time I‚Äôve been taking it day by day. I think, depending on the training staff and where they think I am, if they think I should, obviously that‚Äôs when I‚Äôll try to push it. We‚Äôve talked about it. That‚Äôs why they have me listed as doubtful is because the thing that I did last week, it wasn‚Äôt really‚Ä¶ I couldn‚Äôt do much. Obviously, it‚Äôs not feeling much better this week, it kind of puts you in a position where you have to be listed as doubtful.‚Äù**Have the doctors told you that it will require surgery?**‚ÄúI‚Äôve had doctors say I may need surgery and I‚Äôve had some that have said don‚Äôt do surgery. Of course I would want to get through this without having surgery and that‚Äôs why I‚Äôm going to take my time and wait and see if I‚Äôm actually going to need it, before I do anything stupid.‚Äù**Have they given you an estimate on the time required to heal?**‚ÄúNo, not really to be honest with you. Different people say different things. Obviously when you talk to doctors, anywhere from 4-6 weeks is typical, you know, I don‚Äôt know. I just always wait and see. Miracles do happen and I think we‚Äôll just have to wait and see.‚Äù**Last year you had to come out against New England. You‚Äôre injured again this postseason. Do you feel a little bit cursed?**‚ÄúYou know, it‚Äôs been a tough year, 2008, I mean, it has. The whole year, you look back at the playoff game against New England and got hurt there and this whole year I‚Äôve pretty much been banged up. So it‚Äôs been a tough year. But at the same time, to me, I always carry it as a fluke just because I‚Äôve played so many years and haven‚Äôt been banged up, haven‚Äôt really missed any time. But here I am the last year, it‚Äôs been hurt more than I ever have. Now I can say that I‚Äôm getting old and maybe that has something to do with it or I can say it‚Äôs been a fluke, which I still think I‚Äôm in great shape. I think I‚Äôm just going to have to wait and see what happens next year and the year after that and see if indeed it‚Äôs because of my age and I‚Äôm getting older.‚Äù**Is there one play that you hurt it?**‚ÄúNo, I don‚Äôt. Looking at the tape, it may have been that touchdown run, the last touchdown run where it kind of slipped a little bit going into the endzone. But throughout that process, after the touchdown I really didn‚Äôt feel it at all. Maybe it was because of the excitement, the adrenaline. But that next play I definitely felt it when I tried to burst.‚Äù**When you took that first carry in that last game, in the long gain, it looked like it was almost dragging?**‚ÄúYeah it was. It was. And that‚Äôs why I said earlier that that game was just all pure determination of trying to just push it and trying to do as much as I I could and go. But it was clear from the first carry that I couldn‚Äôt pick my leg up and explode and it did feel like it was dragging.‚Äù**Do you compare your situation to Shawne Merriman‚Äôs attempt to play in the first game?**‚ÄúWell, not really. I mean, it‚Äôs kind of similar of trying to play, but that‚Äôs what guys, that‚Äôs what football players do though. You‚Äôre going to always try to play. Most of the time when you get hurt, that next week after you‚Äôre going to always try to test it, and try to see if you can play with it. Then from that point on, you‚Äôll pretty much know where you are. That was the same way with my toe. That next game against Denver, I was trying to see where I was. I knew at that point that I could possibly play with it, but it was going to take more time. I was going to need the help of the other guys. But with this, this is something that‚Äôs a lot more serious.‚Äù**What do you do during the game if you can‚Äôt play?**‚ÄúI help coach. I try to motivate the guys and help Sproles and Michael Bennett out with some of the things that they may be seeing out there and just try to encourage them.‚Äù**What emotions are involved with suffering an injury this late?** ‚ÄúI don‚Äôt think anybody can know the frustration, to be honest with you. It‚Äôs tough dealing with it. I really sometimes just want to go home and just stay at home and lock myself up and not even go into public, just cause all my life all I‚Äôve ever wanted to do is play football. That‚Äôs all I‚Äôve ever wanted to do and you know, win a championship. And to feel so helpless, to be at this point where we have a chance to do it and again, I can‚Äôt do anything about it, I can‚Äôt play, it‚Äôs like I‚Äôm being punished for something. It‚Äôs tough to deal with.‚Äù**Does it make it worse knowing that you‚Äôre not going to have that many more chances?**‚ÄúWell, I mean, that does have something to do with it because you know that these chances don‚Äôt come around that often. But what do you do? You just hope that you get another shot at it.‚Äù**Should the Chargers win this week and you don‚Äôt play, do you still take as much pride in the win?**‚ÄúAbsolutely, because, you know, it‚Äôs a different point where I‚Äôve been here all year and been a part of this and helped them get to this position. For them to win a game, two games without me, you have to take pride in that because you still feel as much as part of this team as anybody else. If it was where I went all season and didn‚Äôt really play, that‚Äôd be different. Then I can say, ‚ÄòWell, I wasn‚Äôt really part of the team. They did it without me.‚Äô But this is different. You know, I‚Äôm in the meeting rooms everyday, with the guys everyday.‚Äù**If someone told you five weeks ago that Darren Sproles would be on the cover of Sports Illustrated, would you have thought they were crazy?**‚ÄúNo, no, not at all because he‚Äôs always been making plays for us, but it‚Äôs been in special teams. You never know when somebody‚Äôs opportunity is going to come. They‚Äôre going to take advantage of it and they‚Äôre going to get exposure and people are going to recognize the things that they‚Äôre able to do. So, you never say never. You never say that a guy can‚Äôt do something.‚Äù**In practice, what‚Äôs it like trying to catch one of Mike Scifers‚Äôs punts?**‚Äú(Chuckles) It‚Äôs pretty difficult because he can do so many things when he‚Äôs punting the ball. I remember when (Darren) Bennett was here and I always knew how tough it was, catching Bennett‚Äôs punts. But Bennett taught Mike, so that should tell you how difficult it is when he does the different spins on the ball and the different punts that he‚Äôs able to do.‚Äù**Does Mike surpass his teacher?**‚ÄúThat‚Äôs tough, I don‚Äôt know. You‚Äôll have to ask him. I don‚Äôt want to get into that.‚Äù **What‚Äôs your reaction when a player like Vincent Jackson makes the news for something other than football?**‚ÄúObviously we‚Äôre all behind him. Vincent says he‚Äôs innocent. We‚Äôre his teammates and we‚Äôre going to stand behind him. It‚Äôs a tough situation to be in and I hope that he can get past it.‚Äù**When a player makes that kind of news at a critical time like this, what does it do to a team? Does it do anything?**‚ÄúWell, not really. It doesn‚Äôt really do anything. If anything, it really kind of makes you focus in and really understand that you‚Äôve got to be on your toes at all times, that you can‚Äôt put yourself in those positions. You just start to realize things like that, so it brings you a little bit closer. Guys rally behind him, you know, rally around him and talk to him and make sure that he‚Äôs going to get past this.‚Äù**Have you guys met as a group to talk about this?**‚ÄúWe have. Earlier in the season, the NFL has a program where we talk about the different things that may happen off the field, the different situations you may be put in as an NFL player, and we have group time and we have sessions where we all talk about that type of stuff.‚Äù**How about this week?**‚ÄúNo, we haven‚Äôt really had the time to really talk about it as a group. But guys are talking about it individually, together and making sure that we‚Äôre always on our toes and doing the right thing.‚Äù **Tight end Antonio Gates**** Have you been in a boot this week?**‚ÄúI had to wear the boot the first couple of days because of the soreness, but for the most part I‚Äôm able to walk. I struggle with cutting and jumping with the high ankle sprain, but walking is not a big problem.‚Äù**As a Detroit native, how do you handle cold weather?**‚ÄúYou learn to deal with it. You go out and you play and you try to block that out. Obviously with the experience of playing in the cold, we played there earlier this year and the AFC Championship Game last year we played in New England, we have experience playing in the cold. You go out and try to win a football game.‚Äù**Is it worse on the sideline when you stiffen up?**‚ÄúBecause they have the heaters over there and you tend to get the heat. Then you try to go out and you‚Äôre basically numb by the time you get to the line of scrimmage. It gets cold. It‚Äôs really mind over matter at that point. When you know first go out there, you know it‚Äôs going to be cold and you get your mind prepared to play with the expectations that it‚Äôs going to be cold and there‚Äôs nothing you‚Äôre going to be able to do that.‚Äù**Will**** you wear sleeves?**‚ÄúNo sleeves. It‚Äôs mind over matter. It doesn‚Äôt mean I‚Äôm not cold with no sleeves. I don‚Äôt want anybody to know that.‚Äù**Getting eight catches with a high ankle sprain, how proud are you of that?**‚ÄúI think I was most proud of our will to win on Sunday. Guys were asked to make plays and were able to step up. Defensively we just did a tremendous job against Peyton Manning. Special teams were huge. We just wanted to maintain field position. I was asked to go out there and do a job. I didn‚Äôt try to do more or less than I was asked to do.‚Äù**On the first-quarter catch where you got behind the defense, what were you thinking there?**‚ÄúI felt him coming. Sometimes you tend to harp on your injury when you‚Äôre playing in the game. Even though you feel okay, you try to protect it as much as possible. That was just the perfect case where I was trying to protect my right ankle. I knew they were coming up behind me.‚Äù**What‚Äôs your status for this week?**‚ÄúIt‚Äôs always the same for me. I‚Äôm trying to do as much as I can to feel as close as I can to feel 100 percent on Sunday. (Head Athletic Trainer) James Collins and his staff do a tremendous job of helping me rehab and getting me prepared to play the game.‚Äù**Will**** you feel better this week than you did last week?**‚ÄúI was a little sore coming off the game. Obviously that was my expectations and I kind of had to plan that if I was going to play I was going to feel a certain way. That‚Äôs exactly what happened. I felt really, really sore on Sunday. I felt really, really sore on Monday and Tuesday and I‚Äôm able to walk around pretty decent (today), kind of normal to where it was last week.‚Äù**Do you feel a little ahead this year because you know how to handle it after what you went through last January?**‚ÄúAbsolutely. Just dealing with my past injuries gives me an advantage on how to deal with this injury. I just remember trying to come back and run and do those different things on my past injuries and actually setting myself back so when Sunday was to come, I was sore. Now I just take a different approach where I try to rehab as much as possible and try to get myself close to 100 percent on Sunday.‚Äù**When you look at LT, do you see the pain and frustration he‚Äôs dealing with?**‚ÄúYeah, we talked after it first occurred and it‚Äôs kind of like d√©j√† vu for us. Putting yourself in position to advance in the postseason and then suffering injuries which (keep) you from playing at the level you‚Äôre capable of playing. It‚Äôs especially detrimental to him because he if anybody wants to win a Super Bowl. He‚Äôs put so much into this organization. He‚Äôs put so much into the National Football League itself. It‚Äôs just unfortunate that these types of injuries occur.‚Äù**How will Vincent Jackson‚Äôs situation affect the team this week?**‚ÄúIt won‚Äôt really affect us. Obviously it‚Äôs over with. It‚Äôs in the past. It‚Äôs something we have to be aware of. Needless to say, Vince is a very intelligent person. We just move on from that. We are a high character team. We pride ourselves on character. Unfortunately mistakes do happen regardless of who you are.‚Äù ******Tackle Marcus McNeill****Do you have confidence in playing this team knowing that they only won by one point?**‚ÄúIt has motivated us to go out there and compete because we really felt like we had a chance against them in the first game. We had a couple mishaps but we played them real tough. We plan on going up there and competing at a high level this week too.‚Äù**How do you feel going up against James Harrison?**‚ÄúHe speaks for himself‚Ä¶AP Defensive Player of the Year. He‚Äôs a great defensive player regardless. He can cover. He can rush the passer. I might have my hands full the whole time, but I think the game is going to come down to which offense can handle the other team‚Äôs defense better.‚Äù**What was your experience against Harrison earlier in the season?**‚ÄúEverything you see. He‚Äôs good at rushing the passer. He‚Äôs good on blitzes. He‚Äôs strong. He can drop in the coverage too. I even had to tackle him one time last game. I really don‚Äôt want to do that again.‚Äù**Do offensive linemen like cold weather?**‚ÄúI‚Äôm actually from Georgia so I really don‚Äôt like cold weather that much. It‚Äôs not really true for me. I‚Äôm going to try to keep my sleeves off this week. You kind of get a little more jacked up when you‚Äôre playing without sleeves and man-(up) through that weather.‚Äù**Why does it jack you up?**‚ÄúYou feel like you‚Äôve got a mental edge. Whether they think it‚Äôs a mental edge or we think it‚Äôs a mental edge, nobody knows, but I think it‚Äôs just a dumbfounded fact. We just think it makes us stronger.‚Äù**It‚Äôs always cold for the playoffs?**‚ÄúIt seems like it always is cold like that, but I got a couple extra layers on me anyway so I‚Äôm going to be all right.‚Äù**Last year was cold in New England. Did you do anything to compensate for that?**‚ÄúI defrosted three days after the game. That‚Äôs about all you can do. You gotta man-up through that cold weather and when I get finished I‚Äôm going to jump into that hot tub some where.‚Äù**Is the worst part when the defense is on the field and you‚Äôre waiting to get back on the field?**‚ÄúThat‚Äôs definitely the worst part. For some reason every time we go somewhere that‚Äôs cold our heaters never work. I don‚Äôt know it they do that on purpose to freeze us or not. I mean that‚Äôs the worst part being off the field on the sideline.‚Äù**Why are the Steelers so hard to run against?**‚ÄúYou can see their front. They have a lot of good people. They have Harrison. (Lamar) Woodley on the outside. They‚Äôve got experience on the linebacker‚Äôs corps. They‚Äôve got (Troy) Polamalu who covers and stops the run. They‚Äôre all around a good defense. They‚Äôre good against the run and the pass. I think they‚Äôre number one in both. We‚Äôre going to have our hands full on offense this week.‚Äù **How important is it to establish the run game?**‚ÄúIt‚Äôs definitely important. If we establish a running game I think that will establish our offense a lot. We want to actually take control of the clock. When we have a running game going we can control the clock, keep them off the field and keep them from making big plays. That‚Äôs what our offense wants to do help out our defense and keep them off the field. I keep my defense off the field and I stay warm. They stay cold and we all seem to like each other real well.‚Äù**On Darren Sproles being on the cover of Sports Illustrated:**‚ÄúI actually set it up for him. I knew that was going to happen for him. I wasn‚Äôt worried about that. I had my people call a few of his people. I know how that works.‚Äô**How many zone blitzes did you get last time?**‚ÄúI‚Äôm thinking 16 maybe? I tell you what, the Steelers are a tough team regardless. They really play off their abilities for everybody to play around the field. You‚Äôll see their nose dropping into coverage. You see Harrison dropping into coverage. That allows them to bring a guy like Polamalu off the edge.‚Äù**Ever since the Atlanta game the O-line has played better. Was there anything said or done?**‚ÄúIt‚Äôs just the fact that all these guys, everybody on the offensive line, continued to push. We knew we had the ability the whole year. We just wanted to continue to come together. Our cohesiveness on the offensive line really helps out our run game.‚Äù**Did it take for all of you to be back in the line up to come together?** ‚ÄúYes, definitely. We play as a group definitely as the offensive line. It‚Äôs all five of us taking care of the line of scrimmage. I was out early. Nick was out early. LJ (Shelton) did a great job filling in. (Jeremy) Newberry did a great job filling in. But you know we also miss a lot of tempo and things like that. We came back and it took us a little time to get our rhythm back, but now I feel like we got it going and it‚Äôs really helping out our offense.‚Äù

Title: 7,000 tickets available for Thursday's game
Headline: More than 7,000 tickets need to be sold by 5 pm Monday to lift the local television blackout of Thursday‚Äôs Chargers-Seahawks game at Qualcomm Stadium.  The game kicks off at 5:00 pm.  A variety of Club Seats ‚Äì some of the best seats in the stadium ‚Äì also are available.

Content.html: <iframe width="560" height="315" src="https://www.youtube.com/embed/ndHm01jlQ3w?feature=oembed" frameborder="0" allowfullscreen></iframe>
Content.title: San Diego, BOLT UP!

Body.PartPreview: <iframe width="560" height="315" src="https://www.youtube.com/embed/ndHm01jlQ3w?feature=oembed" frameborder="0" allowfullscreen></iframe>

Body.Content:
Tickets may be purchased by logging onto www.CHARGERS.com, calling 1-800-745-3000 or visiting the Chargers Ticket Office located at Gate C at Qualcomm Stadium.  The Chargers‚Äô ticket office is open Monday from 8-5 pm.  

The game is being televised nationally by ESPN.  If the blackout is lifted, the game will be seen in San Diego on both ESPN and KFMB-TV, Channel 8.  Mike Tirico, Ron Jaworski and Jon Gruden will call the game from the booth while Suzy Kolber reports from the sidelines.  

With the purchase of tickets to see the Chargers-Seahawks game, fans also can purchase sought-after tickets to see the Chargers-Packers game on Nov. 6.  Prices start as low as $108 for the unique two-game package.  This is a way for fans to see Philip Rivers and the Chargers duel quarterback Aaron Rodgers and the defending NFL champs before the Packers game sells out.

Title: Game Rewind: 2011 Week 1
Headline: The San Diego Chargers tied for the top record in the AFC West last year with an 8-8 mark.  Relive each memorable win as we break down some of the greatest moments from the 2011 season. First up is the opening day victory vs. Minnesota.

Body.Content:
The Chargers opened the season with a 24-17 win over the Vikings, overcoming a fourth-quarter deficit and scoring 17 unanswered points in the win. **Philip Rivers** passed for two touchdowns, including the game-winner to **Mike Tolbert** at 5:01 of the fourth quarter. San Diego‚Äôs defense dominated the Vikings, holding them to just 187 yards of total offense and just 26 in the second half. After the Vikings‚Äô second touchdown of the game at 9:44 of the second quarter, they didn‚Äôt manage to cross the 50-yard line into Chargers territory for the rest of the game. The Chargers finished the game with 31 first downs to the Vikings‚Äô 10, and possessed the ball for 37:17 to Minnesota‚Äôs 22:43.

[Game Rewind: San Diego Chargers vs. Minnesota Vikings](http://www.pntrs.com/t/RUBKRUNGSUBIR0hIRkBISEtERw?website=49069)![](http://prod.static.chargers.clubs.nfl.com/http://www.pntrs.com/i/RUBKRUNGSUBIR0hIRkBISEtERw?website=49069)

**Norv Turner** earned his 100th career regular-season win against the Vikings and received a game ball from the team in the locker room afterward.

**Mike Scifres** earned a game ball after taking over for an injured **Nate Kaeding** and scored his first-career NFL points, including a game-tying 40-yard field goal with 10:05 remaining in the fourth quarter...it tied the game at 17-17...Scifres‚Äô last made field goal in a live game (college or pro) was a 56-yard game-winner as time expired to give Western Illinois a 44-41 win over Northern Iowa in 2000 for a conference title...Scifres was also good on all three point-after attempts...Scifres also handled kickoffs and had two touchbacks...Kaeding suffered season-ending torn ligaments in his left knee on the game‚Äôs opening kickoff.

**Antoine Cason** had a game-high two passes defensed...both came on third down plays to force Minnesota punts...the last gave the ball to the Chargers for the go-ahead touchdown drive.

**Philip Rivers‚Äô** 335 yards were his most ever in a season opener...it was his 21st career 300-yard game and the 13th time in his career that he led the Chargers back for a win when trailing in the fourth quarter.

**Mike Tolbert** scored a career-high three touchdowns, including a career-high two receiving touchdowns...Tolbert scored the game-winner for the Chargers on his second touchdown reception, a 19-yarder with 5:01 remaining in the fourth quarter...he became the third player in team history to have two touchdown catches and a rushing touchdown in the same game...his nine catches were a career high.

**Antonio Gates** caught eight passes to move into third place on the team‚Äôs all-time receptions list with 537...he passed LaDainian Tomlinson (530) for third place.

**Shaun Phillips** made a great play on Minnesota‚Äôs first offensive play of the game, tipping a Donovan McNabb pass in the air and intercepting it at the Vikings‚Äô six...it was his fifth-career interception and led to a Chargers touchdown three plays later to tie the game at 7-7.

**Ryan Mathews** had a career-high 73 yards receiving, including a career-long 37-yard catch.

**Antwan Barnes** made two big plays in the second half...on the last play of the third quarter, his pressure on third-down helped force an incomplete pass and a punt...on the ensuing drive, Scifres kicked a 40-yard field goal to tie the game at 17-17...then late in the fourth quarter, Barnes‚Äô 10-yard sack on third-down capped off a three-and-out and the Chargers offense ran out the clock on the ensuing possession to close out the win.

**Takeo Spikes** received a game ball for his first game with the Chargers after leading the team with 13 tackles.

**Corey Liuget** had a team-high two tackles for loss in his first-career NFL game.

<center>[![](http://prod.static.chargers.clubs.nfl.com/http://www.pjatr.com/b/R0BKRklISkBIR0hIRkBISEtERw?website=49069)](http://www.pjatr.com/t/R0BKRklISkBIR0hIRkBISEtERw?website=49069)</center>

Title: 2014 Schedule Teeming with Tough Opponents
Headline: Bolts will face five playoff teams, including both Super Bowl participants.

Body.Content:
<center>![](http://prod.static.chargers.clubs.nfl.com//assets/icons/photo-icon.png)** Slideshow: [2014 San Diego Chargers Opponents](/node/18911)**</center>


The Chargers roll into 2014 fresh off a playoff appearance last season, but must play seven games against playoff teams ‚Äì four alone in the AFC West - in what is one of the toughest schedules in the NFL. Based off the 2013 results, the combined winning percentage for the Chargers‚Äô opponents is .563, tied for the fourth most difficult schedule in the NFL.

All AFC West teams are matched against the AFC East and NFC West. As the third-place team in the AFC West, the Chargers draw games against the third-place team from the AFC South and AFC North (Jacksonville and Baltimore).

Here‚Äôs the breakdown of the home and away opponents for next season:

**Home:** Denver Broncos, Kansas City Chiefs, Oakland Raiders, New England Patriots, New York Jets, Jacksonville Jaguars, St. Louis Rams, Seattle Seahawks  
**Away:** Denver Broncos, Kansas City Chiefs, Oakland Raiders, Buffalo Bills, Miami Dolphins, Baltimore Ravens, Arizona Cardinals, San Francisco 49ers

Game dates and kickoff times will not be determined by the NFL until April. If you would like to be notified when the schedule is released, sign up here:

Title: Chargers cap season with 33-28 win
Headline: The best game of Ryan Mathews‚Äô rookie season and four Nate Kaeding field goals were enough to outscore Denver and help San Diego attain its ninth win.

Body.Content: The Chargers (9-7) ended an up-and-down season with a win for the first time since 2003

The Chargers (9-7) ended an up-and-down season with a win for the first time since 2003, clenching a winning record and sweeping the Broncos for the second time in four years.

Three Ryan Mathews touchdowns and four Nate Kaeding field goals helped San Diego overcome a 7-0 deficit in the first quarter and cling to a 33-28 win Sunday at INVESCO Field.

‚ÄúI think it‚Äôs a great way to go into the next year,‚Äù Malcom Floyd said. ‚ÄúIf we would‚Äôve lost it would‚Äôve left a bad taste in our mouth through the whole offseason.‚Äù

Brandon Lloyd slipped into the right corner of the north end zone uncovered and Tim Tebow‚Äôs easiest throw of the afternoon resulted in a 14-yard touchdown that gave Denver (4-12) a 7-0 lead in the first quarter.

The Chargers responded with 16 unanswered points in the second, including field goals of 42, 45 and 47 yards by Kaeding, and San Diego controlled the game until the final minutes of the fourth quarter.

With many of the remaining fans chanting his name, Tebow capped a 12-play, 92-yard scoring drive with a 6-yard run with 26 seconds left and the Broncos recovered the onside kick. But two Tebow heaves to the end zone fell to the ground in the final seconds to preserve the outcome for San Diego.

The Chargers relied on Mathews often. His 27-yard burst up the middle in the second quarter, a career long, tied the game 7-7.

Mathews set a new career high with a 31-yard scamper around the left side on fourth-and-1 with 7:55 left in the fourth quarter that gave San Diego a 33-14 lead.

The rookie managed season-highs in carries (26), rushing yards (120) and touchdowns (3), also barging into the end zone on a patient 12-yard rush with 2:34 left in the third. He fumbled twice but the Chargers recovered both.

‚ÄúI was impressed with what Ryan did today,‚Äù Head Coach Norv Turner said. ‚ÄúHe ran physical inside. He ran outside. He‚Äôs got some work to do to understand that handling the ball is different in this league.‚Äù

Mathews, limited since Week 2 by a high ankle sprain, did not play in four games and missed portions of others, finishing the season with 678 rushing yards and seven touchdowns. He scored five times in the final four games of the season.

Mathews‚Äô performance was enough to keep Tebow and the Broncos at bay, but the final score was in doubt until a final lob crashed into the grass.

Cassius Vaughn scored on a 97-yard kickoff return with 7:22 left in the fourth quarter to make the late dramatics possible.

The game didn‚Äôt have playoff implications, a rarity for Chargers-Broncos late in the season. One of the teams has made the postseason every year since 2003. But San Diego‚Äôs players and coaches balked at the term ‚Äúmeaningless‚Äù before the game and were able to find benefits to reaching nine wins on the second day of 2011.

San Diego started 2-5 but went 7-2 during its final nine games, overcoming a disappointment in Cincinnati last week to finish on the plus side. The win served as an emotional boost for a team upset with missing the playoffs for the first year since ‚Äô05.

‚Äú(Before kickoff) was the low point certainly of these last seven days,‚Äù Philip Rivers said. ‚ÄúLosing to Cincinnati and being eliminated was tough but it didn‚Äôt really set in.

‚ÄúBy Thursday it was rough. Friday was rougher and right before kickoff today I was so aggravated and fired up to go play a game I couldn‚Äôt stand it.‚Äù

Title: 49ers GM Encourages All to Spread Love in Honor of Holly Heap
Headline: John Lynch is enlisting "The Faithful" for their support of former NFL tight end Todd Heap and his family.

Body.Content:
Following a tragic incident this past March to the daughter of former Baltimore Ravens tight end, Todd Heap, San Francisco 49ers general manager John Lynch is enlisting "The Faithful" for their support.   

Holly Heap, the tight end's late daughter, would have celebrated her fourth birthday on Wednesday May 3. The Heap family is remembering her contagious spirit, and Lynch has encouraged all 49ers fans to get involved.

Content.html:
Friends and all #Faithful, please consider supporting our friends the Heap Family as they turn tragedy into LOVE.https://t.co/YqlVuNtLg5

— John Lynch (@JohnLynch49ers) May 2, 2017

Body.PartPreview:
Friends and all #Faithful, please consider supporting our friends the Heap Family as they turn tragedy into LOVE.https://t.co/YqlVuNtLg5

— John Lynch (@JohnLynch49ers) May 2, 2017

Body.Content:
The Hugs from Holly campaign, promoting random acts of kindness, will launch on Holly's birthday.

Holly was known to ‚Äúgive the best hugs,‚Äù and her family is encouraging supporters to wear pink and spread joy through posting photos on social media with the hashtag #HugsFromHollyDay.

May 3, as we honor and celebrate Holly, here‚Äôs how the Heap family encourages you to get involved on the ‚ÄúHOLLYday‚Äù:

**1.** Wear PINK in Holly‚Äôs honor.

**2.** Make a plan to share hugs and spread love & joy through random acts of heartfelt kindness for those in your community. Smile more. Compliment somebody.  Write a kind note.  Share treats (or chicken nuggets). Do a free lemonade stand. Leave a bigger tip than usual. Pay for the person behind you in the drive-thru. Donate a book in Holly‚Äôs honor. Turn up the music and dance‚Ä¶ the list is endless.  Be creative!

**3.** Capture your family spreading joy and post your pictures using the hashtag #HugsFromHollyDay.
 **-- ** 

For more information on Hugs from Holly, visit [HugsFromHolly.com](http://hugsfromholly.com/)

Title: Mathews back on field
Headline: The rookie‚Äôs presence on the field means San Diego has a chance to face Oakland with its full complement of running backs.

Body.Content:
SAN DIEGO ‚Äì Rookie running back Ryan Mathews (ankle) returned to practice Wednesday.

Mathews has rushed for 4.4 yards per carry this season but has been slowed by a high ankle sprain since Week 2 against Jacksonville. He missed the last two games and hasn‚Äôt practiced since before the Week 10 bye.

‚ÄúIt‚Äôs big getting him back out there,‚Äù Head Coach Norv Turner said.

The running game has looked good the last two games with Mike Tolbert topping 100 yards in both. Tolbert (hand) did not practice Wednesday but expressed confidence he‚Äôll play against Oakland.

Mathews has rushed for 382 yards on 87 carries and has 15 receptions for 92 yards.

‚ÄúHis role hasn‚Äôt changed,‚Äù Turner said of Mathews, who‚Äôs started six of his eight games this season. ‚ÄúHe just hasn‚Äôt been here. Obviously we need every guy that we can get going and we‚Äôre going to need Ryan as we go through this next stretch.‚Äù

**DECEMBER HERE:** The Chargers turned their full attention to the [Oakland Raiders](http://www.raiders.com/) on Wednesday, which happened to be the first day of December.

Turner is undefeated in San Diego during December and Philip Rivers is unbeaten in the final month of the year as an NFL starter.

The Chargers craft the player‚Äôs schedule with end-of-the-season health in mind, Turner said, but attributes the late-season runs to a markedly better turnover ratio.

‚ÄúI know what the problems were this year,‚Äù Turner said. ‚ÄúWhen you have 18 turnovers in the first (seven weeks of the season, I don‚Äôt care how many yards you‚Äôre running for, throwing for, how many yards you‚Äôre holding the other team to, you‚Äôre going to struggle and that‚Äôs what happened with us.‚Äù

This month‚Äôs schedule includes back-to-back home games against division opponents that the Chargers lost to earlier this season.

‚ÄúAny time you play teams twice you feel like you know them better and they probably feel like they know us well also,‚Äù Rivers said. ‚ÄúIt really comes down to out-executing.‚Äù

**PLAYING BIG:** Shaun Phillips may have registered his 10
HTML NO SUPPORTED : <sup>th</sup>

sack Sunday against the Colts, but Antonio Garay had a lot to do with it.

Garay, working against 6-foot-4, 311-pound guard Jeff Linkenbach, drove his man backward and then up into the air, the lettering on the back of Linkenbach‚Äôs jersey threatening to press into Peyton Manning‚Äôs facemask.

‚ÄúOur guys know he‚Äôs one of the strongest in terms of playing strength on our team,‚Äù Turner said. ‚ÄúI don‚Äôt think anyone on our sideline was surprised by it but obviously he surprised the guard. He got underneath him and knocked him back.‚Äù

**SAN DIEGO SHOUTOUT:** During the Sunday Night Football player introductions, outside linebacker Antwan Applewhite said he played college football at ‚ÄúBrady Hoke University,‚Äù creating a buzz at San Diego State.

The Aztecs went 8-4 this season and will attend their first bowl game since 1998.

‚ÄúJust giving a little shoutout to Coach Hoke,‚Äù Applewhite said. ‚ÄúHe‚Äôs turned that program around over there with an eight-win season and winning (Mountain West Conference) Coach of the Year so I thought I had to do something to show my support to the program and that was it.‚Äù

Hoke laughed Tuesday when asked about the prime time mention.

‚Äú(Applewhite) is a heck of a kid. I‚Äôve met him a couple  of occasions; him and Atiyyah (Henderson, former running back) are very close,‚Äù Hoke said. ‚ÄúBelieve me, my phone started going nuts. My brother (Bears defensive backs coach Jon Hoke) called from Chicago and said, ‚ÄòWhat in the hell are you doing?‚Äô‚Äù

**ROSTER MOVES:** The Chargers signed linebacker J Leman and receiver Bryan Walters to the practice squad Wednesday.

Leman spent four weeks on the team‚Äôs practice squad last season and Walters was with San Diego in training camp. The Chargers placed receiver Richard Goodman on ‚ÄúPractice Squad; Injured‚Äù with a toe injury and the [Indianapolis Colts](http://www.colts.com/) signed linebacker Nate Triplett to their active roster.

**BLOOD DRIVE UPDATE:** Chargers Blood Drive XXXII drew more than 3,000 fans to the Town & Convention Center on Tuesday. The official total: 1,259 pints of blood donated, plus 1,851 pints donated the week prior to the drive during Chargers Mania.

Chargers Mania will continue through Dec. 4. Blood donors giving at any San Diego Blood Bank donor center or bloodmobile will get a free long-sleeve T-shirt while supplies last.

Visit SanDiegoBloodBank.org or call (800) 469-7322 for more information.

Title: Broncos-Chargers moved to primetime

Body.Content:
The Week 17 [Denver Broncos](http://www.denverbroncos.com)-San Diego Chargers game on Sunday, December 28 will be played at 5:15 PM PT (8:15 PM ET) on NBC, the NFL announced today.   

The NFL utilizes ‚Äúflexible scheduling‚Äù on Sundays in Weeks 11-17.  Flexible scheduling ensures quality matchups in all NFL Sunday time slots in those weeks and give teams a chance to play their way onto primetime and into the late-afternoon 4:15 PM ET time slot on CBS and FOX.

Title: Chargers re-sign offensive lineman Kynan Forney

Body.Content:
The San Diego Chargers have re-signed unrestricted free agent offensive lineman Kynan Forney to a two-year deal.  

Forney originally signed a one-year deal with the Chargers on Sept. 1,2008, but did not see any game action during the ‚Äô08 season. He is anine-year veteran who played seven seasons with Atlanta where hestarted 88 of 95 games played.  Most of his action has been at guard,where he was named a first alternate to the Pro Bowl in 2005.  TheFalcons led the NFL in rushing three straight seasons from 2004-06, andduring that time Forney was considered the club‚Äôs best offensivelineman.    

The University of Hawaii product has some familiarity with the Chargerscoaching staff.  Chargers running backs coach Ollie Wilson held thesame position in Atlanta for six of Forney‚Äôs seven seasons with theclub.

Title: Bolts‚Äô defense ready for second chance at Broncos

Body.Content:
HTML NO SUPPORTED :
The month of December has been a redemptive one for the Chargers. Their three-game win streak has provided them an opportunity to vindicate a 4-8 start.
Their eight turnovers in the last three weeks have rejuvenated their defense.
The fact that they‚Äôve landed blows as they‚Äôve fought with their backs against the wall has given them a renewed confidence.
A win Sunday against Denver would make their four last-second defeats basically irrelevant.
Sunday also provides the Chargers‚Äô defense with a chance to make up for a disappointing Week 2 showing in Denver, a day in which the Broncos gained 486 yards of total offense, 350 of which came through the air.
‚ÄúThis is a game where we can erase a lot of things that happened this year,‚Äù safety Clinton Hart said. ‚ÄúAnd that was one of the worst things.‚Äù
In Denver‚Äôs Week 2 defeat of the Chargers, Broncos quarterback Jay Cutler completed 35-of-50 passes for 350 yards and four touchdowns. Pro Bowl wide receiver Brandon Marshall, who has 98 catches for 1,210 yards this season, was on the receiving end of 18 of those.
Opposite of Marshall, the Broncos feature rookie Eddie Royal, who has 80 receptions on the season and caught five passes in Week 2, including a fourth-quarter touchdown that set up his game-winning catch on a two point conversion. Along with tight end Tony Scheffler, who caught six passes for 67 yards in Week 2 against the Bolts, the Chargers know they have their hands full.
‚ÄúThey‚Äôve got weapons,‚Äù safety Eric Weddle said. ‚ÄúThey‚Äôre not one of the best offenses in the league for nothing. They‚Äôve got two great receivers. They‚Äôve got a tight end that can run like a receiver and a quarterback who can make a lot of throws. We‚Äôve got to bring our ‚ÄòA‚Äô game.‚Äù
The Chargers secondary acknowledge the challenge Denver‚Äôs second-ranked offense presents, but the Bolts believe they are a much better defense than the one the Broncos saw in three and a half months ago.
‚ÄúWe‚Äôre different schematically,‚Äù Weddle said. ‚ÄúWe‚Äôre more sound in what we‚Äôre doing, each individual along with the team concepts, what we want to do and what we‚Äôre trying to get done. Early on we were hesitant in what we were trying to do. I think right now we like what we‚Äôre doing. We‚Äôre making progress.‚Äù
As the Chargers gather answers for stopping Denver‚Äôs potent passing game this week, they may find some in the film of the second half of September‚Äôs matchup. After giving up 226 passing yards in the first two quarters, the Bolts settled in and allowed just 114 in the second half.
‚ÄúWe played a lot better in the second half and stopped a lot of that until the last drive. One of the things you have to do against them is not let them get big plays. That was the difference in the first half and the second half. We feel like we‚Äôre doing some things better. We are pressuring the quarterback better. We‚Äôre creating turnovers and protecting the ball. That‚Äôs been a big part of what we‚Äôve done over the last three weeks.‚Äù
$%PART%$part_0$%PART%$
**Injury update**
****
Chargers defensive tackle Jamal Williams (foot) returned to the practice field Thursday after missing Wednesday‚Äôs drills, as did defensive end Igor Olshansky, who was ill Wednesday.
Wide receiver Malcom Floyd (collapsed lung) was limited Thursday and linebacker Brandon Siler (foot) missed a second-consecutive day.
Offensive tackle Ryan Clady and tight end Daniel Graham returned to practice for the Broncos as all 53 men on Denver‚Äôs squad practiced on Christmas.
**Floyd feeling better**
****
Ten days after suffering a collapsed lung, Floyd says that he feels fine. He ran during individual drills Thursday but is still unlikely to play Sunday according to Turner.
‚ÄúHe ran well and that would be the issue,‚Äù Turner said. ‚ÄúEvery step along the way has been positive for him. Each thing they did with him, he‚Äôs been fine. I think he‚Äôs come back faster than anticipated. He‚Äôs a very physical player. He catches balls in traffic and unless he‚Äôs completely 100 percent, we wouldn‚Äôt put him in a position where he‚Äôs going to go get banged around.‚Äù
Floyd suffered the injury in the first half of the Chargers‚Äô win over Kansas City two weeks ago. He battled shortness of breath throughout the game but continued to play. He even caught a fourth-quarter touchdown pass that set up an onside kick and subsequent game-winning drive.
‚ÄúDuring the game it felt irregular, just my breathing,‚Äù Floyd said. ‚ÄúIt was hard to catch my breath. I thought it was just because it was so cold but it was more than that.‚Äù
After the game, doctors recommended that Floyd undergo x-rays, which revealed the collapse in his right lung. He spent the night in Kansas City and had a tube place in the lung to re-inflate it.
‚ÄúIf I had gotten on the flight, it could have become really serious,‚Äù Floyd said. ‚ÄúI was disappointed I didn‚Äôt get to fly back with everybody but now I‚Äôm thankful the doctors did everything they did.‚Äù
Floyd is anxious to get back on the field but is trying to be patient and do what‚Äôs best.
‚ÄúI feel normal,‚Äù Floyd said. ‚ÄúI‚Äôm going off the doctor‚Äôs word. They‚Äôve got a close eye on me but I feel great.‚Äù

Title: Kellen Clemens, Chargers Agree to Two-Year Deal
Headline: The San Diego Chargers and quarterback Kellen Clemens agreed to a two-year deal.

Body.Content:
With only two quarterbacks on the roster in Philip Rivers and Brad Sorensen, the San Diego Chargers added a well-tested veteran to the mix today in Kellen Clemens.

Most recently with the St. Louis Rams, Clemens appeared in 10 games with nine starts in 2013 after Sam Bradford was lost for the year.  He completed 142 of 242 attempts (58.7%) for 1,673 yards and eight touchdowns for a 78.8 passer rating.  Clemens led the Rams to four wins over his nine starts, including a pair of impressive victories over the Indianapolis Colts and New Orleans Saints.  Both the Colts and Saints advanced to the Divisional Round of the playoffs.

Clemens spent the first five seasons of his career with the New York Jets, who selected him in the second round (49
HTML NO SUPPORTED : <sup>th</sup>

overall) out of Oregon in the 2006 NFL Draft.  Over his career he‚Äôs appeared in 40 games with 21 starts.  Clemens has completed 338 of 620 passes (54.5%) for 3,944 yards and 15 touchdowns. His first season with the Chargers will mark his ninth year in the league.

The addition of Clemens marks [the seventh transaction that San Diego has made](/node/94496) in free agency.  They kicked it off by re-signing Donald Butler, Darrell Stuckey and Chad Rinehart before also adding Donald Brown, David Johnson and Kavell Conner.

Title: Chiefs Wary of Bolts Playing Spoiler
Headline: Kansas City Chiefs Head Coach Andy Reid previewed Sunday's match and why San Diego is "a team that never gives up."

ExtendedFields.Description: 161228_Reid.mp4
161228_Reid.mp4

Body.Content:
It‚Äôs been 16 weeks since the San Diego Chargers and Kansas City Chiefs first met to open the 2016 season.   

Although they have trended in opposite directions, the pair will meet for the Week 17 finale at Qualcomm Stadium on Sunday.  For the Chiefs, a lot rides on Sunday‚Äôs game including a potential AFC West title and number two seed that would give the team a first-round bye in the playoffs.

On Monday, Chiefs Head Coach Andy Reid said San Diego is ‚Äúa team that never gives up‚Äù and knows his squad is in for a challenge.

‚ÄúTo do what they‚Äôve done with all the injuries (they) have is amazing.  The kids obviously believe in what they‚Äôre doing because they play hard on both sides of the ball and on special teams.  That I hope people appreciate.  It‚Äôs not an easy thing to do or get done.‚Äù

‚ÄúI agree with Coach, totally,‚Äù affirmed Marcus Peters.  ‚ÄúWhen you have a quarterback like that who can put up numbers and who is a gunslinger and when you have a (future) Hall of Fame tight end, they‚Äôve been doing it for a long time and you have to respect them.  You just go in with the same attitude.‚Äù  

The Chiefs know what Philip Rivers is capable of doing against them. Peters says number 17 is not only great in his own right, but great because ‚Äúhe makes those around him better‚Äù.  

‚ÄúYou better not snooze at all with that guy,‚Äù Reid added.  ‚ÄúHe is a competitor and he makes everybody around him better.  That‚Äôs what great quarterbacks do; you see it.  He‚Äôs a heck of a player.‚Äù  

Additionally, the Chiefs defense knows it‚Äôs essential to contain Antonio Gates on Sunday.  Gates is one touchdown away from tying Tony Gonzalez for most touchdowns all-time by a tight end.  As Reid attests, Gates is still a dynamic playmaker in his 14
HTML NO SUPPORTED : <sup>th</sup>

season.  

‚ÄúThat guy must be drinking from the fountain of youth because the second-half of his season here has been unbelievable.  I just love watching him other than when we have to play him.‚Äù

On the flipside, the Bolts defense looks a bit different than in Week 1.  Most notably, up front and in the secondary as Joey Bosa and Casey Hayward have turned in strong performances in an otherwise rough season.  

‚Äú(Hayward) has had a great year.  I think he leads the league in interceptions and that‚Äôs pretty good!  There are some pretty good players in this league so he‚Äôs done a heck of a job. I think (Bosa is) one of those guys who gives (his all) every down.  He plays hard every snap and that‚Äôs what we‚Äôre preparing for.  He obviously has pass rush ability and skill because the sacks are the things that get the attention, but he‚Äôs a pretty complete football player.‚Äù

Title: Chiefs Wary of Bolts Playing Spoiler
Headline: Kansas City Chiefs Head Coach Andy Reid previewed Sunday's match and why San Diego is "a team that never gives up."

Body.Content:
HTML NO SUPPORTED : <nflcsavplayer storypart="True" newsid="444711"></nflcsavplayer>

It‚Äôs been 16 weeks since the San Diego Chargers and Kansas City Chiefs first met to open the 2016 season.   

Although they have trended in opposite directions, the pair will meet for the Week 17 finale at Qualcomm Stadium on Sunday.  For the Chiefs, a lot rides on Sunday‚Äôs game including a potential AFC West title and number two seed that would give the team a first-round bye in the playoffs.

On Monday, Chiefs Head Coach Andy Reid said San Diego is ‚Äúa team that never gives up‚Äù and knows his squad is in for a challenge.

‚ÄúTo do what they‚Äôve done with all the injuries (they) have is amazing.  The kids obviously believe in what they‚Äôre doing because they play hard on both sides of the ball and on special teams.  That I hope people appreciate.  It‚Äôs not an easy thing to do or get done.‚Äù

‚ÄúI agree with Coach, totally,‚Äù affirmed Marcus Peters.  ‚ÄúWhen you have a quarterback like that who can put up numbers and who is a gunslinger and when you have a (future) Hall of Fame tight end, they‚Äôve been doing it for a long time and you have to respect them.  You just go in with the same attitude.‚Äù  

The Chiefs know what Philip Rivers is capable of doing against them. Peters says number 17 is not only great in his own right, but great because ‚Äúhe makes those around him better‚Äù.  

‚ÄúYou better not snooze at all with that guy,‚Äù Reid added.  ‚ÄúHe is a competitor and he makes everybody around him better.  That‚Äôs what great quarterbacks do; you see it.  He‚Äôs a heck of a player.‚Äù  

Additionally, the Chiefs defense knows it‚Äôs essential to contain Antonio Gates on Sunday.  Gates is one touchdown away from tying Tony Gonzalez for most touchdowns all-time by a tight end.  As Reid attests, Gates is still a dynamic playmaker in his 14<sup>

th</sup> season.  

‚ÄúThat guy must be drinking from the fountain of youth because the second-half of his season here has been unbelievable.  I just love watching him other than when we have to play him.‚Äù

On the flipside, the Bolts defense looks a bit different than in Week 1.  Most notably, up front and in the secondary as Joey Bosa and Casey Hayward have turned in strong performances in an otherwise rough season.  

‚Äú(Hayward) has had a great year.  I think he leads the league in interceptions and that‚Äôs pretty good!  There are some pretty good players in this league so he‚Äôs done a heck of a job. I think (Bosa is) one of those guys who gives (his all) every down.  He plays hard every snap and that‚Äôs what we‚Äôre preparing for.  He obviously has pass rush ability and skill because the sacks are the things that get the attention, but he‚Äôs a pretty complete football player.‚Äù

Title: Tomlinson Press Conference Transcript

Body.Content:
HTML NO SUPPORTED :
Chargers Running Back LaDainian Tomlinson
‚ÄúIt‚Äôs great to be back in this room. Obviously I want to thank theorganization and Dean Spanos for me being back. It‚Äôs great to beback. My heart has always been with San Diego and I‚Äôm happy to beback. I love these guys on this team and never really thought I wasgoing to leave. I‚Äôm happy to be doing this right now. I‚Äôll open it upto any questions that you all may have.‚Äù
**How tough has this whole process been?**
‚ÄúIt was kind of tough, I think more so for my family because I hadto answer their questions a lot of the time. Any time something wentacross the screen I had to answer their questions, but I stillmaintained the belief that I would remain a Charger. They drafted mehere. I‚Äôve been here for eight years and loved every minute of it. Ijust couldn‚Äôt see myself putting on another uniform. That Chargeruniform, that 21 with the bolt on the side of my helmet, that‚Äôs prettyspecial. You really can‚Äôt replace that. I‚Äôm just happy to be puttingthat helmet on again.‚Äù
**Can you talk about your relationship with Dean Spanos and how that has evolved?**
‚ÄúIt‚Äôs just kind of happened over the years of knowing Dean and hiswife and family, going out to dinner and playing golf, just hanging outa little bit and getting to know each other beyond the business part ofit, as friends. Obviously I have a lot of respect for him. Relationshipbuilds over time. That relationship is something that has built andit‚Äôs been a strong one. I appreciate that friendship.‚Äù
**Do you feel appreciated by the Chargers after this process?**
‚ÄúAbsolutely. It‚Äôs a two-way street. We‚Äôve always said that this isthe part you don‚Äôt like, the business part of it. Obviously A.J.(Smith) has been criticized as well as myself about some of the thingsthat we both have gone through, but that‚Äôs a part of the business. Ihold no hard feelings to anyone. I respect A.J. for the job he hasdone, the job he‚Äôs continuing to do for this team and I‚Äôm going to tryto do the best job I can for this team on the field. That‚Äôs the waywe‚Äôre going to handle it. When we win a championship, everybody isgoing to be happy.‚Äù
**Realistically, how close are the Chargers to winning a championship?**
‚ÄúI think we‚Äôre very close. Obviously over the past two years we‚Äôvebeen hampered a little bit by injuries. That‚Äôs been the unlucky part ofit. I‚Äôve got to figure that it‚Äôs our time. I‚Äôve got to figure that thisis not going to continue to happen to us where we get so close and getinjured and really hurt ourselves in that way where we can‚Äôt be at fullstrength. When we‚Äôre at full strength, we‚Äôre a tough team to dealwith. I think everyone has seen that in the past. I‚Äôm looking forwardto being at full strength with this team.‚Äù
**Did you at any point feel like you were close to leaving ****San Diego****?**
‚ÄúI don‚Äôt know if there really was. From my standpoint, I remainedoptimistic about it. At the same time, I knew that it was a businessand guys sometimes go other places. For that reason, I kept it in theback of my mind that I might have to. At the same time, I had to thinkthat something would happen. As we kept continuing to talk about it, Ibecame more optimistic that I would be here. I kind of figuredsomething would get done and it did.‚Äù
**How involved was Dean Spanos in these talks?**
‚ÄúI‚Äôm not sure at all. I know when we first started going throughthese talks, Dean called me and said he wanted to talk about a coupleof things. I left it at that. At the end, he called and said, ‚ÄòWe‚Äôregood.‚Äô I was happy to hear those words from him, that ‚Äòwe‚Äôre good‚Äô, andI knew I was going to remain a Charger.‚Äù
**Were you pleased with how little information leaked during the negotiation period and was that done at your suggestion?**
‚ÄúYeah, for me, I‚Äôm a pretty private person. I think thisorganization is the same way. You want to keep everything inhouse. Obviously we had a great relationship through eight years. Weboth kind of felt like the best way to do it was within us, two partiesworking this out. Then if anything was to happen the media would knowlater. We just felt like it was the respectable thing to do, to dealwith business between us two.‚Äù
**Is there anything in this deal that assures us we won‚Äôt be going through a similar scenario a year from now?**
‚ÄúLet‚Äôs just worry about this year. This is something thatobviously you deal with sometimes, but I don‚Äôt think it will be. That‚Äôsnot something that I‚Äôm worried about. I don‚Äôt believe this is somethingwe‚Äôll be going through next year.‚Äù
**Do you have any guaranteed money out in the future?**
‚ÄúI can‚Äôt answer that just because I actually haven‚Äôt signed the contract yet. We have agreed but I can‚Äôt answer that right now.‚Äù
**Besides football, what are some of the other reasons why you really wanted to stay in ****San Diego****?**
‚ÄúI think the most obvious is I‚Äôve got a house here and my familyreally enjoys being here. We‚Äôve been a part of the community for solong. Our foundation does so much stuff here to help so many people. Ijust really didn‚Äôt want to turn our back on the people in the communityand all the things we‚Äôve built here so far.‚Äù
**Did you ever feel like the Chargers were turning their back on you during the process?**
‚ÄúNo, again, I understand the business side of it. I didn‚Äôt feellike they were turning their back on me, but I felt like they needed tomake business decisions as any organization does. I never felt likethey were turning their backs on me. Of course there are times when youwonder if you‚Äôre going to be here. I never felt like they were turningtheir back on me. They had given me eight years, great years. Theydrafted me and gave me the opportunity. Not at all did I feel like theywere turning their back on me.‚Äù
**If you‚Äôre healthy, how close can you be to the LT we‚Äôve seen the last eight years?**
‚ÄúI think I will continue to be a very explosive player. You guyssaw me last year where I was banged up all year, played with a hurt toeand obviously with the groin injury. I‚Äôll be back to full strength andto being the LT that you guys are used to seeing.‚Äù
**Did A.J. Smith explain to you the thought process inrestructuring your deal and were you satisfied with his plan for thefuture?**
‚ÄúAbsolutely. It‚Äôs to win, to get players here to help us wingames. I‚Äôve never been a selfish guy. The more guys we can have here tohelp us win‚Ä¶I‚Äôm all about winning championships. We‚Äôve come so close sofar but haven‚Äôt done it yet. I‚Äôve always said when I first got to SanDiego that I wanted to be a part of something special and help bringchampionships to this organization and to this city. That‚Äôs how Iremain.‚Äù
**Can you remain as explosive as you were in 2006?**
‚ÄúAbsolutely, with the opportunities. That was a special year, nodoubt. Will I rush for 1,800 yards again? Who knows. I think it‚Äôspossible, definitely. That‚Äôs yet to be seen. I think with the sameopportunities, it can happen.‚Äù
**How would you describe your emotions today?**
‚ÄúIt‚Äôs relief, knowing where I‚Äôm going to be playing footballat. That was my whole focus. That‚Äôs very important. It lifts a bigweight off my shoulders and everybody else around you, to know whereyou‚Äôre going to lace them up at.‚Äù
**When you signed your contract in 2004, did you know that this day would likely come?**
‚ÄúI know history tells us that usually you do restructure sometimeslater into your contract. Sometimes you don‚Äôt get to. You end upgetting released or traded or what have you. I was just happy that Ihad the opportunity to restructure my contract rather than be releasedor traded.‚Äù
**What was your wife‚Äôs reaction to the news?**
‚ÄúShe was happy. I could just tell. She probably read every commentthat each of you had written. I used to tell here to stop readingit. She said, ‚ÄòNo, it‚Äôs not bothering me,‚Äô but I knew it was. It wasjust a relief from here after it was done. I knew that she was excitedthat we were going to remain in San Diego. She loves it here and shereally didn‚Äôt want to move anywhere.‚Äù
**Do you have any regrets about the statement you made on your website in January and the reaction that came out of that?**
‚ÄúNo. At that time I was starting to get a lot of notes from fanssaying, ‚ÄòDon‚Äôt leave,‚Äô and ‚ÄòHow could you turn your back on us?‚Äô I justwanted to let them know that I was going to do everything I could toremain a Charger. My heart is here and I‚Äôm going to do everythingpossible to be here. That was my whole point in making that statement.‚Äù
**Do you think you have to prove you can stay healthy through a full season and postseason?**
‚ÄúAbsolutely. I feel like I do have to prove I can stay healthy.I‚Äôve always felt like I needed to prove something. When I first cameinto the league, I wanted to prove that I could play in this league andthat I could be dominant. I know I can do that. Going on 30 (yearsold), I want to prove that I can stay healthy a full season and stillbe that dominant player. Honestly, I haven‚Äôt had any serious injurieswith surgeries. I don‚Äôt see why I can‚Äôt continue to be a dominantplayer.‚Äù
**Is there something you can do during the offseason to help prevent injuries?**
‚ÄúI think you become smarter. You learn how to work in a differentway. You still maintain working hard, but you do it in a differentway. Not as much pounding in the offseason, kind of save myself alittle more for the season and gearing up for training camp and goingthrough the season. Before, I used to start off just going 100 milesper hour, and sometimes it wore me down. I was in such good shape whenI got to training camp that I really had nothing to work for. ObviouslyI think some of that will change, but most of it is going to stay thesame.‚Äù
**Can you talk about your recent comments about EmmittSmith‚Äôs career rushing record and why for the first time you discussedmaking a run at him?**
‚ÄúI think that‚Äôs something that I‚Äôve just kind of got a new fire ofsaying, ‚ÄòWhy not?‚Äô If we‚Äôre winning and winning championships, I dowant to play as long as I can and walk away with all the records. Thatwould be a heck of a challenge and I‚Äôm up for challenges. I‚Äôm certainlygoing to try to do it.‚Äù
**Now that the contract negotiations are done, when do youstart negotiations with Norv Turner about returning the halfback option?**
‚ÄúWe just got through talking about that to be honest withyou. Norv has told me that, I don‚Äôt want to give it away to all theteams out there, but you‚Äôd better watch out. It‚Äôs going to be in.‚Äù
**What is your message to the fans that admire you?**
‚ÄúI just appreciate their support, for coming to the stadium withtheir 21 jerseys on and just the Charger jersey period and supportingthis team. I appreciate that. I look forward to many more years ofexciting football and winning. I just believe that we‚Äôre going to walkoff with that Lombardi Trophy and we‚Äôre going to have the craziestparty in this city that we‚Äôve ever had.‚Äù
**You‚Äôve previously said the Smith record wasn‚Äôt that important to you. What‚Äôs changed?**
‚ÄúI think for so long I blocked it out. It was so far out there,but reevaluating where I‚Äôm at in my career now, I think it‚Äôsreachable. I guess I just kind of got the sense of, ‚ÄòWhy not?‚Äô Whyshould I at the end of my career look back and say, ‚ÄòI was this closeto Emmitt‚Äôs record. Why didn‚Äôt I continue to play and try to get it?‚Äô Idon‚Äôt want to have that regret. I don‚Äôt want to have any regrets when Ileave this game. I guess that‚Äôs kind of what‚Äôs changed.‚Äù
**Did you feel like you were shortchanged last year whenpeople wrote things about your decline when you were actually battlinginjuries?**
‚ÄúNo, you play the hand you‚Äôre dealt. For me, it‚Äôs good because Iget to prove what I‚Äôm worth again. I get to prove to people, and that‚Äôsthe way it‚Äôs always been for me. I‚Äôve always enjoyed doing that. I getto do it once again.‚Äù
**How do you feel physically right now?**
‚ÄúI feel great physically. I‚Äôve started back working out. This weekwas the first week where I‚Äôve actually starting cutting and all kindsof things. It feels really good. It‚Äôs really good to be feeling strongagain.‚Äù
**Have you negotiated any incentives into your contract for passing Emmitt Smith?**
‚ÄúNo I haven‚Äôt. I think sometimes the outside endorsements, you cannegotiate with that as well, with the Nikes and the Gatorade and whathave you. I think the Chargers are paying me enough money. I‚Äôm good.‚Äù
**Was money much of a factor in this process?**
‚ÄúTo me, I thought being fair was what I was looking for. Not toreally try to break the bank or do anything crazy, but just to befair. That was all that I was looking for. The Chargers have alwaysbeen that, so I really didn‚Äôt think they wouldn‚Äôt be fair. When it camedown to it they were.‚Äù
**Do you think the comments your mother made on the radio last week were a factor in this?**
‚ÄúI really don‚Äôt know. The funny thing, I didn‚Äôt know my mom hadsaid that. Sometimes you can‚Äôt tell Mom to be quiet. My mom has her ownopinion, and rightfully so. I‚Äôm her son. If I would have told hersomething, she probably would have given me a backhand or something. Ijust acted like I didn‚Äôt see it.‚Äù
**What did she say when the deal was done last night?**
‚ÄúShe was just excited. She has so much Chargers stuff in herhouse, I don‚Äôt know how that would have gone over, getting rid of allthat stuff.‚Äù

Title: 2008 Mini Camp
Headline: Get a rare, up-close look at an actual NFL practice when the 2008 San Diego Chargers‚Äô rookies and veterans gather for Mini Camp on Saturday and Sunday, May 3-4.

Body.Content:
**When:** Saturday and Sunday, May 3-4, 2008  
**Where:** Chargers Park 
Get a rare, up-close look at an actual NFL practice when the 2008 San Diego Chargers‚Äô rookies and veterans gather for Mini Camp on Saturday and Sunday, May 3-4. It‚Äôs your chance to see the entire squad, including the 2008 draft selections as they make their first appearance in the Chargers‚Äô lightning bolts. **NO VIDEOTAPING ALLOWED AND NO TELEPHOTO LENSES OF ANY KIND.***  
*

**  
Practice Times**

![](http://prod.static.chargers.clubs.nfl.com//assets/images/imported/assets/118/24423_282wh.jpg)  
Mini Camp at Charges Park in San Diego, California  
Mike Nowak, Chargers.com

Saturday  
**10:30 ‚Äì 12:20 pm** ([Add to Calendar](/calendar/?trumbaEmbed=view=event&eventid=76609786))  
**4:00 ‚Äì 6:00 pm** ([Add to Calendar](/calendar/?trumbaEmbed=view=event&eventid=76609786))

Sunday  
**11:00 ‚Äì 1:00 pm** ([Add to Calendar](/calendar/?trumbaEmbed=view=event&eventid=76609786))

**Chargers Park **([Map](http://maps.google.com/?q=4020 Murphy Canyon Rd, San Diego, CA 92123-4407))  
4020 Murphy Canyon Rd.  
San Diego, CA 92109

The 2008 Mini Camp will be held at Charger Park in San Diego. Chargers Park is located at 4020 Murphy Canyon Road, just west of I-15 between Aero Drive and Clairemont Mesa Blvd.

In addition to bleacher seating, fans are welcome to bring their own beach chairs.

**** Practice times subject to change without notice. Please check back for more details, such as practice times, as they come available. ******Due to the lack of available public parking, the team‚Äôs practices on Friday, May 2 are closed.***
