Title: Ingram, Raye and Turner discuss first round

Body.Content: HTML NO SUPPORTED : OLB Melvin Ingram:** **Give us your reaction to being selected by the Chargers: ** ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs a blessing. I‚Äôm thanking God a million times just to be a part of a first-class organization.‚Äù **What do you think you can bring to this defense? ** ‚ÄúI‚Äôm going to bring the team a hard worker who is going to lay it all on the line every play for my teammates.‚Äù **Do anticipate making an immediate impact on the Chargers defense? ** ‚ÄúOf course. That‚Äôs my number-one goal, to come in, work hard and try to make an impact as soon as possible.‚Äù **Do you think you slipped at all or did you land where you wanted to be? ** ‚ÄúIt really didn‚Äôt matter to me. Before I came to the draft, I prayed to God and I said, ‚ÄòI‚Äôm going to put my faith in God and whatever position you put me in I will feel it is the best for me.‚Äô‚Äù **Do you have a history with any other Chargers players? ** ‚ÄúI know there are a lot of first-class, high-caliber athletes out there that I can learn from like Takeo Spikes and Shaun Phillips. They also have a wonderful quarterback in Philip Rivers.‚Äù **Can you talk about the general experience of being drafted? ** ‚ÄúIt couldn‚Äôt have gone any better. It‚Äôs a blessing and I‚Äôm thanking God.‚Äù **Is it your birthday? ** ‚ÄúYes, sir.‚Äù **What did A.J. Smith say to you? ** ‚ÄúThey told me congratulations and to get ready to be a Charger.‚Äù **Is this officially the best birthday present you‚Äôve ever been given? ** ‚ÄúYes, sir.‚Äù **Do you expect to start right off the bat? ** ‚ÄúI plan to get there, learn the playbook, learn the system and get on the field right away.‚Äù **Someone said you were the best-dressed draftee there. Who helped you with that? ** ‚ÄúI just try to look presentable.‚Äù **How about the handshake? ** ‚ÄúThat was something we made up. I told him that I wanted to do something different so we came up with the handshake.‚Äù **What was the difference between your senior and junior year? ** ‚ÄúIn my junior year, I played in certain packages and certain situations. In my senior year, I was a full-time starter and I had a lot more opportunities to make a lot more plays.‚Äù **What do you think you proved as a senior? ** ‚ÄúI think I proved that I was one of the hardest-working players on my team.‚Äù**
HTML NO SUPPORTED : ** **
Director of Player Personnel Jimmy Raye on Ingram:
HTML NO SUPPORTED : ** **Opening Statement:** ‚ÄúWe executed the 18
th

HTML NO SUPPORTED : </sup> pick and selected (Melvin) Ingram, University of South Carolina outside linebacker. As a group, scouting staff, organization, we couldn‚Äôt be happier with the pick. We thought, going into the draft, Melvin was one of the most complete linebackers out of the group of players we scouted, and we feel happy with the selection.‚Äù

**Did you expect him to be on the board at 18?**

‚ÄúNo, and that was the great thing. In all the mocks (drafts) we saw; the stuff we did in our workups, we thought Melvin would be gone a lot early. We were ecstatic as he came down the board. And we were just hoping he would fall to our spot.‚Äù

**On toying with the idea of trading up:**

‚ÄúWe always consider everything. We thought about going up, of course. But we decided to stay where we were. As he came down the board we felt like maybe he will be there. We had a cluster of players that we felt good about, and when he was there we were excited.‚Äù

**What did you see when you looked at him (Melvin Ingram) his senior year?**

‚ÄúThe versatility. The pass-rushing ability. As you guys all know, we‚Äôve talked about getting edge rushers and getting pressure on the quarterback for the last couple of months since the season ended. He is the type of player we felt like brought burst and energy and rush ability off the edge as well as inside, as an interior pass rusher. That type of versatility will bode well for our defense.‚Äù

**Are you surprised it took so long for pass rushers to start going?**

‚ÄúA little bit. I was. You look at the New York Giants and teams like that, what they‚Äôve done the past five or six years is pressure the quarterback and win games. We thought the run on outside linebackers and pass rushers would start a little bit earlier. That‚Äôs why we were so excited when he fell to our pick.‚Äù

**On the comparison between Melvin Ingram and the Giants‚Äô Jason Pierre-Paul:**

‚ÄúThey‚Äôre different players. Jason (Pierre-Paul) is a longer guy. Melvin is more of compact, thick, more like in the mold of the Pittsburgh outside linebackers. Big legs, shorter in stature, powerful guy. In that sense I think they are a little bit different.‚Äù

**On if the team entertained any offers for trades:**

‚ÄúWe got a few calls, which is normal. Once Melvin started coming down the board and some of the guys that we had targeted were there we decided to stay with our selection.‚Äù

**On how he thinks Melvin will fit in:**

‚ÄúGood. Coach (Turner) can probably talk more about that than I can. But we think he fits well in our group. We like the guys that we have. We have a veteran group of guys. We think Melvin as a young rookie coming in, he‚Äôs just going to add to that whole group of players.‚Äù

**<span style="text-decoration: underline;">

Head Coach Norv Turner on Ingram:** **Opening statement:** **‚Äú**In terms of the outside linebackers, Melvin (Ingram) is the most complete linebacker, we felt, this early in the draft. We coached the Pro Bowl three years ago, and it‚Äôs amazing all those Pro Bowl outside rushers are about 6-foot-2. They claim they are, but, they look like they are about 5-foot-11. They‚Äôre 270 (pounds). They have great leverage. They get under people. Jimmy (Raye) mentioned the (comparison to) Pittsburgh linebackers. Melvin is the body type of that. You can talk about a lot of different scenarios, you can talk about a lot of different things, but to me, we‚Äôve improved a great deal as a football team through free agency. We improved as a football team today adding a player of Melvin‚Äôs caliber.‚Äù **On how Melvin will be used:** ‚ÄúYou have to look back to when our defense has been at its best, and we‚Äôve had multiple players playing at the outside linebacker position. One of the things that was really hard on our guys last year was that we had some guys play 750 plays during an entire season. The guys before them really didn‚Äôt have to do (that). Melvin can be an impact player. He doesn‚Äôt have to be on the field every down. He can fit in with the mix of the guys we have. He can learn from them. I think he is going to be outstanding on third down. He has rushed inside. Early, you don‚Äôt ask a guy to do a lot of coverage stuff like that. That‚Äôs kind of been the learning curve the linebackers have had here in the past as first and second-year players. You pick out the things they do best and you let them do them, and that will be our plan with Melvin.‚Äù **Was there a feeling of disbelief when he kept falling to you?** ‚ÄúNot in my mind. There were a group of guys there that we really liked. If Melvin had been taken I think there were some guys that would have been able to come in and help. As I said, we felt Melvin was the most complete guy so that‚Äôs why there was the anxiousness and excitement when he was there when we picked.‚Äù **On comparing him with the Pittsburgh Steelers‚Äô linebackers:** ‚ÄúWell, I don‚Äôt know. They‚Äôre (Harrison and Woodley) both outstanding. Those are the things we‚Äôll find out when we get him here. Both those guys are similar in that they‚Äôre very, very physical players, and that‚Äôs something you always want to do. You want to get the most physical players you can get. They‚Äôre very competitive players. They‚Äôre playmakers. That‚Äôs what Melvin is.‚Äù **Out of the cluster of pass rushers was Ingram your first choice?** ‚ÄúHe was the one guy, if we break down the other guys that we looked at, as I said, (that was the) most complete. Athletic‚Ä¶pass rush‚Ä¶he‚Äôs gone down inside and played inside over a guard and created a matchup that‚Äôs outstanding. He‚Äôs probably the guy that we felt, as I said, (is) the most compete.‚Äù **On the excitement of knowing the player you want is there:** ‚ÄúAbsolutely. You‚Äôve got some guys in your cluster and they‚Äôre there. You know which one you want, but you‚Äôd be excited about any of them.‚Äù **Who was the next person in line?** ‚Äú(Laughing) I don‚Äôt remember.‚Äù **Did you make the phone call?** ‚ÄúA.J. (Smith) made the call, but we all get on the phone with him. That‚Äôs one of the real exciting things about the draft. When you get on the phone with a young guy and he‚Äôs been selected. Melvin is in New York. Later we‚Äôll get some guys that are at home and they have their family there screaming in the background. This is a great day for these guys. They‚Äôve worked awfully hard to get to this point, and it‚Äôs the next step in their careers.‚Äù **On addressing a need by selecting a player on defense versus offense:** ‚ÄúEveryone has an opinion, but I think people are going to be excited about this pick. The ‚Äòso-called‚Äô experts, the people who evaluate players, we‚Äôve gotten a number of calls from people around the league who have (a) great feeling for this player, so I would expect our people to be extremely excited about Melvin.‚Äù **How close to executing your offseason plan are you?** ‚ÄúAs A.J. (Smith) would tell you, it‚Äôs an on-going thing. Like I said, through free agency, I think we have significantly gotten better. We‚Äôre going to continue tomorrow to keep working to get better. For me, it starts in May when we get on the field with our players and start doing the offseason work because we can improve a great deal. No question from an athleticism and talent level we‚Äôve gotten a lot better.‚Äù **On if there is a concern with doubling up on a position with the first-round pick in back-to-back years:** ‚ÄúNot in my mind. You‚Äôre trying to get good football players. As I said, when this defense has been at its best, and I‚Äôve coached against it, and obviously coached it, we‚Äôve had multiple players at the outside position. We‚Äôve been able to roll them in there; we‚Äôve been able to keep them fresh. They‚Äôve been different styles but they‚Äôve all been very, very competitive, very athletic, and for the most part, very physical, like Melvin.‚Äù **On possibly drafting an offensive lineman versus Ingram:** ‚ÄúThis was the right pick for us. I think people who really look at us know that the group of guys that played on the offense line the last five games and played with us healthy, played at pretty high level and they‚Äôre still guys that will continue to get better. We‚Äôre going to continue to look at players that will help us in that area.‚Äù **Does Ingram also fill the need for backup running back?** ‚ÄúI don‚Äôt think he‚Äôll be a running back but that talks to the athlete that he is. I don‚Äôt know if you saw the fake punt that he scored on. He makes a move like a running back so he is going to be a guy ‚Äì you want your young guys to be able to come in and help you in the kicking game, and there‚Äôs no question he‚Äôs a guy that will be able to play in all phases of the kicking game.‚Äù

Title: Live Updates: San Francisco 49ers vs. Dallas Cowboys
Headline: Follow along here for updates throughout the 49ers Week 4 home game against the Cowboys as they look to even their record at 2-2.

Album.Title: Photos: 49ers vs. Cowboys in Week 4
Album.Description: View images from the Week 4 game between San Francisco and Dallas.

NeutralAlbum.Title: Photos: 49ers vs. Cowboys in Week 4
NeutralAlbum.Description: View images from the Week 4 game between San Francisco and Dallas.

Body.Content:
The San Francisco 49ers (1-2) latest installment of the legendary rivalry against the Dallas Cowboys (2-1) continues on Sunday in Week 4 of the NFL season.

A win will even the 49ers record at 2-2 and keep them unbeated at home.

Follow along right here throughout the contest for a running diary of today's game.  

**Pregame**

HTML NO SUPPORTED : [Vance McDonald![](http://prod.static.49ers.clubs.nfl.com/assets/nflimg/icon-article-link.gif)](/team/roster/vance-mcdonald/ef0d881e-059d-49ff-b232-d4cd9904066b/ "Vance McDonald") (hip) and [Jimmie Ward![](http://prod.static.49ers.clubs.nfl.com/assets/nflimg/icon-article-link.gif)](/team/roster/jimmie-ward/a6e3d0d3-36c0-4e2c-b7d3-3b87e383ce65/ "Jimmie Ward") (quad) are San Francisco's two most notable inactives. [Garrett Celek![](http://prod.static.49ers.clubs.nfl.com/assets/nflimg/icon-article-link.gif)](/team/roster/garrett-celek/d46bd860-f147-4140-8d0f-a89d3422999c/ "Garrett Celek") will start in place of McDonald. Either [Rashard Robinson![](http://prod.static.49ers.clubs.nfl.com/assets/nflimg/icon-article-link.gif)](/team/roster/rashard-robinson/90e79b03-7205-48dd-a530-0680950a32f1/ "Rashard Robinson") or [Keith Reaser![](http://prod.static.49ers.clubs.nfl.com/assets/nflimg/icon-article-link.gif)](/team/roster/keith-reaser/52234b03-28eb-4acc-8730-28dcf669a70c/ "Keith Reaser") will get the nod for Ward. Both cornerbacks should see plenty of playing time. Backup tight end could also see increaed snaps in McDonald's absence. The Cowboys will be without a number of starters on Sunday. Left guard La'el Collins (toe), left tackle Tyron Smith (back), top cornerback Orlando Scandrick (hamstring) and top wideout Dez Bryant (knee) are all out against the 49ers. Here's the 49ers full list of inactives: McDonald, Ward,

HTML NO SUPPORTED : Christian Ponder![](http://prod.static.49ers.clubs.nfl.com/assets/nflimg/icon-article-link.gif)](/team/roster/christian-ponder/0c6f14d6-947d-463d-9b12-8dc9df41269f/ "Christian Ponder"), [Keshawn Martin![](http://prod.static.49ers.clubs.nfl.com/assets/nflimg/icon-article-link.gif)](/team/roster/keshawn-martin/97cc5469-6133-4c10-812d-3fae1c1dfc11/ "Keshawn Martin"), [Tony Jerod-Eddie![](http://prod.static.49ers.clubs.nfl.com/assets/nflimg/icon-article-link.gif)](/team/roster/tony-jerod-eddie/e7047bd3-45e0-4517-970c-b3c2b192d60a/ "Tony Jerod-Eddie"), [Taylor Hart![](http://prod.static.49ers.clubs.nfl.com/assets/nflimg/icon-article-link.gif)](/team/roster/taylor-hart/1c0a5bfd-407c-4cae-927e-e05226fb5af5/ "Taylor Hart") and [John Theus![](http://prod.static.49ers.clubs.nfl.com/assets/nflimg/icon-article-link.gif)](/team/roster/john-theus/e534887f-e12e-449f-aba0-0a118fcfcb30/ "John Theus"). And the Cowboys: Collins, Bryant, Scandrick, Smith, Darius Jackson, Mark Nzeocha and Tony Romo. **First Quarter** Dallas got the ball to open the game. Robinson came out with the 49ers first-team defense, and the rookie corner made two early tackles. Ezekiel Elliott carried the ball twice for 11 yards, Dak Prescott added a 9-yard run and a third-down completion to Cole Beasley moved the Cowboys into 49ers territory. A false start penalty and clutch third-down tackle by Antoince Bethea stalled the Dallas drive at San Francisco's 29-yard line. Dan Bailey missed the ensuing 47-yard field-goal attempt to keep the game scoreless.

HTML NO SUPPORTED : Blaine Gabbert![](http://prod.static.49ers.clubs.nfl.com/assets/nflimg/icon-article-link.gif)](/team/roster/blaine-gabbert/6eaa9675-e39e-4c54-9e62-6ecfd8773730/ "Blaine Gabbert") used his legs to convert San Francisco's first third-down attempt on a 7-yard keeper towards the left sideline. The quarterback then connected with [Quinton Patton![](http://prod.static.49ers.clubs.nfl.com/assets/nflimg/icon-article-link.gif)](/team/roster/quinton-patton/58e6921b-95f1-4e71-9dc6-083e830d9b2a/ "Quinton Patton") for 13 yards on 3rd-and-12. **Three plays later, Gabbert hit a wide open

HTML NO SUPPORTED : Jeremy Kerley![](http://prod.static.49ers.clubs.nfl.com/assets/nflimg/icon-article-link.gif)](/team/roster/jeremy-kerley/37b94d88-5895-41d1-b526-055912ac170c/ "Jeremy Kerley") for a 33-yard touchdown to put the 49ers on top, 7-0. (6:41)** San Francisco went 3-for-3 on third down on the scoring drive. Kerley found space in the middle of the field and then made a man miss on his way into the end zone. One first down is all Dallas would get on their following drive. On 3rd-and-4,

HTML NO SUPPORTED : NaVorro Bowman![](http://prod.static.49ers.clubs.nfl.com/assets/nflimg/icon-article-link.gif)](/team/roster/navorro-bowman/6c460530-c18f-400f-902b-894960fe4476/ "NaVorro Bowman") came in untouched on a blitz and sacked Prescott to force a Dallas punt. Gabbert continued to roll on the 49ers second possession. Completions of 13 yards to Garrett Celek, 25 yards to Celek and 17 yards to Kerley moved San Francisco to the Cowboys 12-yard line as the first quarter came to a close. The 49ers finished the opening quarter 5-for-5 on third down. **Second Quarter** Gabbert kept the ball for seven yards on the first play of the second quarter. Hyde followed with a 3-yard carry to set up 3rd-and-1. **Hyde did the rest from there, finding the end zone from 3-yards out to put the 49ers up 14-0 (13:55).**

HTML NO SUPPORTED : Trent Brown![](http://prod.static.49ers.clubs.nfl.com/assets/nflimg/icon-article-link.gif)](/team/roster/trent-brown/72af56ff-c040-44cd-a53e-1e0c69d26a37/ "Trent Brown") delived a perfect block to seal the right edge on the score. Hyde has been flexing plenty this season and now leads the league with five touchdown runs. San Francisco forced another stop against Dallas' offense. On 3rd-and-3, Robinson broke up a pass intended for Brice Butler which led to another Cowboys punt. A 1-yard run from Hyde made the 49ers 7-for-7 on third down to start the game. The possession, however, would stall, and

HTML NO SUPPORTED : Bradley Pinion![](http://prod.static.49ers.clubs.nfl.com/assets/nflimg/icon-article-link.gif)](/team/roster/bradley-pinion/a6d0a7af-c9a4-40af-8adc-1cde62d98e5d/ "Bradley Pinion") punted it back to Dallas. The 49ers defense appeared to have another stop, but a curious personal foul helped lead to the Cowboys first points of the game.

HTML NO SUPPORTED : Chris Davis![](http://prod.static.49ers.clubs.nfl.com/assets/nflimg/icon-article-link.gif)](/team/roster/chris-davis/312e7e17-f221-4411-9ab9-130f8c432bb7/ "Chris Davis") and [Ronald Blair![](http://prod.static.49ers.clubs.nfl.com/assets/nflimg/icon-article-link.gif)](/team/roster/ronald-blair/757bb4bf-05ca-48cf-b500-f0bc8917734a/ "Ronald Blair") were trying to bring down a scrambling Prescott when [Jaquiski Tartt![](http://prod.static.49ers.clubs.nfl.com/assets/nflimg/icon-article-link.gif)](/team/roster/jaquiski-tartt/3a3d5d62-deab-48cf-a9df-c10c74f8eaf7/ "Jaquiski Tartt") came in to help push the quarterback to the ground. Although Prescott wasn't down and the whistle hadn't blown, Tartt was flagged for a dead-ball personal foul. Davis and Blair were credited with a .5 sack each, the first of their respective careers. **Three plays later, Prescott hit Terrance Williams for a 20-yard touchdown to put Dallas on the scoreboard, 14-7. (2:58)** The points were the first allowed by the 49ers at home this season. San Francisco had previously outscored opponents 42-0. Dallas would march down the field before halftime and tie the ball game. Prescott nickled-and-dimed the 49ers down the field with three completions to Jason Witten. A 10-yard completion to Williams got the Cowboys inside the 10-yard line. **On 1st-and-goal from the 49ers 4-yard line, Prescott found Butler in the end zone to tie the game at 14-14. (0:12)** San Francisco took one knee and the teams went in for halftime. The 49ers will get the ball to start the third quarter. **Third Quarter** Hyde opened the quarter with a 32-yard run. Gabbert followed with a beautiful throw to Celek down the right sideline for a gain of 29 yards. The tight end made a ridiculous one-handed catch but was slow to get up after being tackled. **The drive stalled and

HTML NO SUPPORTED : Phil Dawson![](http://prod.static.49ers.clubs.nfl.com/assets/nflimg/icon-article-link.gif)](/team/roster/phil-dawson/4a670b5a-5f1b-4d99-9e60-4efee3ee7d56/ "Phil Dawson") drilled a 36-yard field goal to give the 49ers the lead, 17-14. (12:18)** Dawson's field goal gives him 390 for his career. The team's then traded stops. Midway through the third quarter, Bowman was forced to leave the game with an apparent leg injury. The linebacker walked off under his own power, but had a considerable limp. It's a scary situation for the 49ers who cannot afford to lose their best defender. Elliott busted loose for 23 yards to get the Cowboys to midfield. Prescott to Butler for 14 yards converted a 3rd-and-5 situation. Elliott broke free again, this time for 17 yards to get near the goal line. **The Cowboys rookie ball-carrier finished what he started, scoring from 1-yard out to give Dallas a 21-17 lead. (1:08)** Elliott eclipsed the century mark and now has 103 rushing yards and his third touchdown of the season. **Fourth Quarter** The 49ers made it near midfield but Gabbert's third-down pass to Kerley was broken up to force another punt. An unsportsmanlike conduct penalty against the Cowboys helped San Francisco get a much needed stop. Robinson broke up Prescott's third-down pass intended for Butler to bring out Dallas' punt team. Kerley followed with a 26-yard punt return to get the 49ers near midfield. Gabbert tried for a deep ball to

HTML NO SUPPORTED : Torrey Smith![](http://prod.static.49ers.clubs.nfl.com/assets/nflimg/icon-article-link.gif)](/team/roster/torrey-smith/23a56c17-da51-4cdc-bb58-e00dff9b2c84/ "Torrey Smith") but was intercepted by Morris Claiborne. Smith had Claiborne beat but the ball was underthrown. Elliott ripped off 26-yards as the Cowboys got rolling immediately. Robinson's third pass breakup of the game, this one coming on a third-down throw into the end zone, kept the 49ers in the game. **Bailey's field goal was good from 22-yards out to extend Dallas' lead to 24-17. (4:11)** Robinson's clutch play ensured San Francisco got the ball back within one score. Gabbert opened the ensuing drive with completions of 9-yard to Celek, 7-yards to Kerley and 20-yards to Kerley. The 49ers ultimately failed to convert on 4th-and-6 whe Gabbert's pass to Smith came up short of the first-down marker. Things went from bad to worse for San Francisco. First-round pick

HTML NO SUPPORTED : DeForest Buckner![](http://prod.static.49ers.clubs.nfl.com/assets/nflimg/icon-article-link.gif)](/team/roster/deforest-buckner/49470da5-fbc7-4d32-aa53-4d42d82a3bc5/ "DeForest Buckner")

went down with a leg injury on the Cowboys final drive.

Dallas closed out the 24-17 win to improve to 3-1 on the season. San Francisco dropped to 1-3 on the year and play again on Thursday at home against the Arizona Cardinals.

Title: Jeremy Kerley Teams Up With Big Brothers Big Sisters and Target to Spread Holiday Cheer
Headline: On Dec. 22, 2016 the 49ers wide receiver partnered up with Big Brothers Big Sisters of the Bay area and Target to host his "Shop with JK" charity event.

Body.Content: [Jeremy Kerley![](http://prod.static.49ers.clubs.nfl.com/assets/nflimg/icon-article-link.gif)](/team/roster/jeremy-kerley/37b94d88-5895-41d1-b526-055912ac170c/ "Jeremy Kerley") wanted to spread holiday cheer, and on Dec. 22, 2016 he achieved that goal at his "Shop with JK" event. The San Francisco 49ers wide receiver hosted 35 kids from Big Brothers Big Sisters of the Bay Area for a holiday shopping spree at Target. Kerley gave each kid a $100 gift certificate to pick out presents for the holidays. Fellow receivers [Torrey Smith![](http://prod.static.49ers.clubs.nfl.com/assets/nflimg/icon-article-link.gif)](/team/roster/torrey-smith/23a56c17-da51-4cdc-bb58-e00dff9b2c84/ "Torrey Smith") and [Rod Streater![](http://prod.static.49ers.clubs.nfl.com/assets/nflimg/icon-article-link.gif)](/team/roster/rod-streater/0877291a-cb35-4010-aaaf-3229768a801d/ "Rod Streater") joined Kerley at his first charity event since joining the 49ers in August.

CustomEntity.Title: Jeremy Kerley Makes Spectacular Toe-tap Catch

ExtendedFields.Author: rusty.parker
ExtendedFields.Description: San Francisco 49ers wide receiver Jeremy Kerley kept the 49ers final drive alive by making a great toe-tap catch along the sideline.

NeutralCustomEntity.Title: Jeremy Kerley Makes Spectacular Toe-tap Catch

ExtendedFields.Author: rusty.parker
ExtendedFields.Description: San Francisco 49ers wide receiver Jeremy Kerley kept the 49ers final drive alive by making a great toe-tap catch along the sideline.

Body.Content:
‚ÄúIt‚Äôs such a blessing to be able to do what I love for a living,‚Äù said Kerley. ‚ÄúEven more so in such a great city with an incredible fan base. I want to bless others. The holidays are always very special for my family, but also gives us an opportunity to help those in need and hopefully inspire some others to do what they can to help be a positive influence in their communities.‚Äù

Dawn Kruger, the CEO of Big Brothers Big Sisters spoke highly of Kerley's efforts to give back.  

"Jeremy and his 49ers teammates are powerful role models, and they are creating a lifetime memory for kids who dont have may opportunities like this," said Kruger. "Our children come from low-income households, most being raised by a single parent or foster parent working multiple jobs, and this time of year can be especially challenging for them. We're thrilled to give our kids this moment of holiday joy with their Big Brother or Big Sister alongside Jeremy Kerley and his 49ers teammates."  

Here are some highlights from the event via social media

Title: Daily Roundup: The Lowdown on Day Five
Headline: Here's your daily training camp roundup directly from Chargers Park.

Body.Content:
The Chargers have a day off on Tuesday, but there was plenty of work to be done today as the team once again hit the fields for a practice and walk through.

Since today was closed to the public, be sure to [check out this photo gallery of the team in action](/media-vault/photo-gallery/Day-5-of-Training-Camp/0dadf393-d102-4106-a0f3-52f54d3e6541), then watch our practice snapshot and highlight plays of the day.

We kicked off our written coverage with a blog entry submitted by none other than Malcom Floyd.  [Read here what he has to stay about his career thus far](/node/90331) and why he feels a special connection with the fans.  Be sure to also [view this photo gallery of M-80 in action](/media-vault/photo-gallery/Malcom-Floyd-at-Training-Camp/909651e6-acb2-49b1-856c-a25d8164631e).

Another special connection we highlighted was the friendship between Eric Weddle and Philip Rivers. [ The two are leaders on their respective side of the ball, but also share a unique bond off the field](/node/90346).  Don‚Äôt miss our photo galleries of Weddle ([click here](/media-vault/photo-gallery/Eric-Weddle-at-Training-Camp/9a86f122-c88a-4493-92fd-022c140f902f)) and Rivers ([click here](/media-vault/photo-gallery/Philip-Rivers-at-Training-Camp/fffd6aba-c6fa-4948-8bcd-055e82cff95d)) either.

Kendall Reyes made a strong impression down the stretch last season, most notably when he recorded 3.5 sacks in a Week 16 win over the Jets. [ Click here to read how he plans to build off last year‚Äôs strong finish](/node/90341).

For more on Monday‚Äôs practice watch head coach Mike McCoy‚Äôs press conference below.

The Chargers annual FanFest is this Saturday.  [Click here to learn more about it](/node/90351).

Finally, the team announced the winner of yesterday‚Äôs Ultimate Instagrammer contest.  Watch today‚Äôs BoltsCast at the top of this article to find out who won!

Title: Corey Liuget Set on Sacking Heart Disease for Son
Headline: Liuget is teaming up with the San Diego Chapter of the American Heart Association for the 2016 San Diego Heart & Stroke Walk.

Content.title: San Diego Chargers DE Corey Liuget on His Son's Heart Condition & His New Foundation - 9/6/16
Content.html: <iframe width="480" height="270" src="https://www.youtube.com/embed/K0JkiAiOS-A?feature=oembed" frameborder="0" allowfullscreen></iframe>

Body.PartPreview: <iframe width="480" height="270" src="https://www.youtube.com/embed/K0JkiAiOS-A?feature=oembed" frameborder="0" allowfullscreen></iframe>

Body.Content:
Roughly two years into his NFL career, Corey Liuget‚Äôs life changed in an instant.

Two weeks after welcoming the birth of his son, Corey Jr., Liuget got news he never expected: his son was born with a heart defect.

‚ÄúHe had an Atrial Septal Defect (ASD) and a Ventricular Septal Defect (VSD),‚Äù Liuget said.  ‚ÄúHe had holes on the bottom of his heart and the top of his heart was open.  They did the surgery when he was six weeks old‚Ä¶.  To have a surgery that young, to have (my son‚Äôs) ribcage cracked open, so the doctors can go in and operate kind of scares you.  I was in awe and I was shocked at first.  When I first found out that my first child was going to have a heart condition, it caught me off guard.  To be completely honest, it scared the heck out of me.‚Äù

Liuget said the defect was discovered after his son was born and wasn‚Äôt hereditary.

Now at four years old, Corey Jr. is happy and healthy.  Despite going in for periodic checkups, Liuget‚Äôs son can live life without any limitations.

‚ÄúIt‚Äôs so rewarding to know I have a healthy, young son who is active.  I don‚Äôt have to be in the hospital with him; he‚Äôs not ill.  Some parents go through that every day and sit in the hospital with their kids.  (I‚Äôm lucky) because my son is at home and playing around in the yard.  I‚Äôm so thankful, blessed and fortunate that my child is okay and I don‚Äôt have to be a parent who‚Äôs concerned about seeing my child in the hospital every day.‚Äù

Content.title: LINK IN BIO My son had a heart condition at birth and it was one of the scariest and most difficult times for myself and my family.  That is why I've partnered with the American Heart Association to raise funds and awareness for heart disease research. Please join me in my goal to reach $20,000 for the #executivechallenge. Let's go!! #sandiego @chargers #bolts @american_start

That is why I've partnered with the American Heart Association to raise funds and awareness for heart disease research. Please join me in my goal to reach $20,000 for the #executivechallenge. Let's go!! #sandiego @chargers #bolts @american_start

A post shared by Corey Liuget (@coreyliuget94) on Jun 21, 2016 at 1:20pm PDT

Body.Content:
Through the tough time, Liuget learned a lot about himself as a person and as a father.  Since Corey Jr.‚Äôs birth, he‚Äôs welcomed two daughters and has gained an appreciation for being present in the moment because you never know when life can change.

‚ÄúIt‚Äôs given me a big appreciation for life because no one wants to see their child go through anything like that. To see him in so much pain and know that I couldn‚Äôt help him was the worst part.  You‚Äôd rather be in their position and let them sit where you‚Äôre at.  You‚Äôd rather take their place, feelings and everything they‚Äôre going through and let them be the one who is healthy, fine and living life.‚Äù

Despite facing adversity, Liuget has become an advocate for ending heart disease.  This season, he‚Äôs teamed up with the San Diego Chapter of the American Heart Association for the 25
HTML NO SUPPORTED : <sup>th</sup>

anniversary Heart & Stroke Walk.

‚ÄúI‚Äôm teaming up with people who care about the future.  They care about tackling this cardiovascular disease that is affecting a lot of America‚Äôs youth and older people.  It just means a lot to me that we care about this problem and they‚Äôre attacking this problem and trying to solve it.‚Äù 

In addition, Liuget is using his play on the field to help those off of it.  For every sack he gets this season, he will donate an AED Machine and CPR training class to a local school in San Diego and he hopes to give out EKGs to local schools as well.

[Click here](http://www.sdheartwalk.org/) for more information on the San Diego Heart & Stroke Walk.

Title: Defense dominates as Jags turnover game to Chargers
Headline: San Diego celebrated a 25-point win at Qualcomm Stadium on Sunday with a defense that banned Jacksonville from the end zone for 59 minutes and utilizing a host of headliners on offense.

Body.Content:
SAN DIEGO ‚Äì Home can be a comforting place.

With the California sun shining and the crowd backing the Chargers, San Diego avenged a season-opening loss at Kansas City.

Antonio Gates caught two touchdown passes, the Chargers (1-1) forced six Jaguars turnovers and coasted to a 38-13 win Sunday at Qualcomm Stadium.

‚ÄúDefensively, we just kept bailing (ourselves) out in the first half,‚Äù Head Coach Norv Turner said. ‚ÄúThe things I wanted to see from our team were a physical presence and the ability to pressure the quarterback, create turnovers and the ability to run the football

‚ÄúIf we can keep getting better at those things, we can be the type of team I‚Äôve been talking about.‚Äù

Less than a week after slogging through torrential rain during an emotional loss that ended at the 6, the Week 2 outcome became like hardened cement soon after halftime.

The breaking point came earlier than that for Jacksonville.

Darren Sproles secured a dump pass, shirked a tackler and skittered down the sideline for a 43-yard gain that jump-started a two-minute drive. Gates finished it with his second touchdown catch as San Diego snatched a two-score lead seconds before halftime.

‚ÄúWe did find a way to score points obviously,‚Äù Turner said. ‚ÄúWe got in a rhythm. We had a great two-minute drive at the end of the half.‚Äù

Jacksonville (1-1) never threatened in the second half after a turnover ended their initial drive deep in San Diego territory. Malcom Floyd‚Äôs 54-yard touchdown catch with 8:06 left punctuated a home opener and put the Chargers two points shy of the 40 they hung on Tennessee in 2006, the year they finished 14-2.

The Chargers have at least two losses in their first four games the last three years but made the playoffs each time. Sunday‚Äôs win ensures San Diego can dodge talk of a slow start for another week and has a chance to rid themselves of the reputation with a few more wins.

Gates, constantly doubled at Kansas City, found room to operate against Jacksonville. He nabbed a nine-yard touchdown catch across the middle that gave San Diego a 14-6 lead and had another pass bounce off his outstretched hands that led to a David Jones interception in the end zone.

‚ÄúYou learn that you‚Äôve got to put things behind you and move on,‚Äù Gates said. ‚ÄúObviously I was able to get a chance to redeem myself.‚Äù

The second half became the Mike Tolbert show. The 5-foot-9, 243-pound running back pinballed off Jaguars defenders and even bounced outside for a 29-yard gain to open the fourth quarter.

When Tolbert barged into the end zone for a 1-yard touchdown with 13:18 left, standing on top of the football and flexing, the outcome was all but sealed.

‚ÄúIt‚Äôs a great feeling any time you control the tempo. We dictated the pace of the game. It‚Äôs a hell of a feeling,‚Äù Louis Vasquez said about playing with a comfortable advantage. ‚ÄúPretty much we‚Äôre just big bullies out there pushing them around. They really don‚Äôt want to be out there and we know it, so we can move them out of the way and let the backs go run.‚Äù

The powerful special teams force and fullback Tolbert carried twice for 26 yards against Kansas City but saw the ball more Sunday as Ryan Mathews left the game with an ankle injury in the second quarter.

‚ÄúThe guys rolled over on me and I tweaked it,‚Äù Mathews said. Everything is fine. I feel like I could‚Äôve returned, but the coaches didn‚Äôt want to risk anything.‚Äù

The teams played an elaborate game of hot potato during the first half, combining for seven turnovers by the time Brandon Siler intercepted David Garrard with 8:31 left in the second quarter.

‚ÄúHonestly, it was kind of like a circus,‚Äù Gates said. ‚ÄúThat‚Äôs something that we definitely will address.‚Äù

Antoine Cason was involved with three. He intercepted a Garrard deep pass at the San Diego 6 on Jacksonville‚Äôs initial drive, secured a pass tipped by Shaun Phillips for his second and stripped Mike Sims-Walker, which led to a Kevin Burnett fumble recovery.

‚ÄúI think our defense won this football game for us,‚Äù Gates said. ‚ÄúThey kept giving us opportunities to score. They kept giving us second chances and we were able to capitalize on some of those.‚Äù

Said Tolbert: ‚ÄúThe crowd fed off our defense. I‚Äôve been here two and a half years and I‚Äôve never seen our defense play that good. I‚Äôm super happy for them because they did a tremendous job.‚Äù

Title: All in
Headline: Corey Liuget marked the eighth and final draft pick to sign with the Chargers. Inserted into practice Thursday, he started preparing immediately for the regular season.

Content.title: Liuget's First Day
Content.html: <iframe width="560" height="315" src="https://www.youtube.com/embed/R8GrmcjVKEc?feature=oembed" frameborder="0" allowfullscreen></iframe>

Body.PartPreview: <iframe width="560" height="315" src="https://www.youtube.com/embed/R8GrmcjVKEc?feature=oembed" frameborder="0" allowfullscreen></iframe>

Body.Content:
**SAN DIEGO ‚Äì** Corey Liuget survived a gauntlet of good-natured ribbing and his first organized football practice in about eight months.

On the same day he signed a four-year contract with the Chargers, Liuget worked alongside Luis Castillo, Jacques Cesaire and the other defensive ends under close watch from Head Coach Norv Turner, the defensive coaching staff, the fans and the media.

‚ÄúIt‚Äôs a privilege to wear one of these jerseys,‚Äù Liuget said, pointing to his Chargers‚Äô No. 94. ‚ÄúNot a lot of people get to do it, so it definitely feels great.‚Äù

Liuget won‚Äôt be expected to carry the load at defensive end, with Castillo, Cesaire and a thinner Vaughn Martin also in a position to contribute.

Despite keeping in shape and studying his playbook throughout the summer, the sudden jolt into football at NFL speed left Liuget with a knowing grin.

Liuget made 12.5 tackles for loss, 4.5 sacks and 10 quarterback hurries as a junior in 2010, earning second-team All-Big Ten honors. Now he‚Äôll get to test himself against the best in football.

‚ÄúIt‚Äôs definitely fast-paced. It‚Äôs not college,‚Äù Liuget said. ‚ÄúI definitely just want to show guys I belong here.‚Äù

Said Head Coach Norv Turner: ‚ÄúI‚Äôm sure things felt real fast for him. I‚Äôm sure his head‚Äôs spinning coming in and trying to get caught up. You know he‚Äôs athletic. He‚Äôs got great quickness. He‚Äôs a very physical player, so tomorrow we‚Äôll get the pads on and we‚Äôll give him another day.‚Äù

A college defensive tackle, Liuget traded his old No. 93 for No. 94 with the Bolts in honor of his late father, who died in ‚Äô94. He took a moment after his first NFL practice to reflect.
 ‚ÄúI know (my dad) is proud,‚Äù Liuget said. ‚ÄúHe‚Äôs looking at me right now.‚Äù

Title: Second-half surge powers Bolts past Vikings
Headline: Three Mike Tolbert touchdowns and a 40-yard Mike Scifres field goal helped the Chargers to a 24-17 comeback win Sunday at Qualcomm Stadium.

Content.title: Locker Room Quick Hits
Content.html: <iframe width="560" height="315" src="https://www.youtube.com/embed/yZp9boBmVik?feature=oembed" frameborder="0" allowfullscreen></iframe>

Body.PartPreview: <iframe width="560" height="315" src="https://www.youtube.com/embed/yZp9boBmVik?feature=oembed" frameborder="0" allowfullscreen></iframe>

Body.Content:
**SAN DIEGO ‚Äì** The Chargers faced a 10-point halftime deficit and the onset of d√©j√† vu during Sunday‚Äôs regular-season opener at Qualcomm Stadium.

San Diego obliterated that notion with a dominant second half. A 40-yard Mike Scifres field goal and Mike Tolbert‚Äôs third touchdown gave the Bolts (1-0) a 24-17 comeback win against Minnesota (0-1).

‚ÄúI like the mindset of our football team because we obviously were in some games like that last year where things weren‚Äôt going the way we wanted,‚Äù Head Coach Norv Turner said. ‚ÄúToday we found a way to win. Every win in this league is precious because this is a competitive, competitive league.‚Äù

The Chargers shut out the Vikings after halftime, scoring 17 consecutive points to seize control late in the fourth quarter.

With the game tied 17-17, Philip Rivers avoided Jared Allen, scrambled left and shot-putted a pass to Mike Tolbert, who skimmed into the end zone for a 19-yard touchdown that sent a crowd of 66,716 into hysteria.

The Chargers held Adrian Peterson to 24 rushing yards in the second half and Antwan Barnes struck the final blow, bear-crawling to a sack on third-and-10 on the ensuing drive. Three first downs later, San Diego was able to run out the clock.

Tolbert also secured a 1-yard touchdown catch in the first quarter and scored again on a 7-yard run, turning himself into a human pinball and allowing his 243-pound frame to ricochet off defenders.

‚ÄúThe guy played fullback the first two years. Last year he was the bruiser and now he‚Äôs the third down back,‚Äù Jacob Hester said of Tolbert. ‚ÄúHe‚Äôs one of the most athletic guys I‚Äôve ever seen. Basketball, soccer, he can play it. His development‚Äôs unbelievable.‚Äù

Minnesota‚Äôs defense appeared determined to keep Rivers from finding Vincent Jackson or Malcom Floyd deep, dropping two safeties most of the game and blitzing on nearly every play.

Rivers found a groove by hitting Tolbert and Antonio Gates underneath for a combined 17 catches and 132 yards. The offensive line, helped at times by Hester and Randy McMichael, limited Minnesota to two sacks.

‚ÄúThere for a little bit it turned into a blitz-a-thon. It seemed like they were bringing an extra guy every time,‚Äù Hester said. ‚ÄúThat slowed down a little bit when we hit a couple plays, but they brought a lot of guys.‚Äù

Percy Harvin ran the game‚Äôs opening kickoff 103 yards for a touchdown and the Chargers‚Äô offense went three-and-out, an ominous start to the 2011 season.

Then the defense, playing with five new starters, got a takeaway on their first play. Shaun Phillips tipped a screen pass to himself for an interception and Tolbert cruised uncovered into the corner of the West end zone three plays later.

San Diego‚Äôs defense seemed to be doing a decent job containing Adrian Peterson, but the Minnesota running back broke free for a 46-yard run to set up a 3-yard Michael Jenkins touchdown catch in the second quarter, affording the Vikings a 17-7 lead. Minnesota didn‚Äôt cross midfield the rest of the game.

‚ÄúIn the preseason, everybody was talking about how (little) playing time we had together,‚Äù  Antonio Garay said of the defense. ‚ÄúWe got all the horses out there, got the kinks worked out early and the second half speaks for itself.‚Äù

The Bolts‚Äô two-minute offense moved the ball before halftime, but Antoine Winfield intercepted a pass after Rivers‚Äô arm got whacked during his delivery. The Chargers responded by moving the first drive of the second half 69 yards for a touchdown. Nearly a quarter later, San Diego faced a fourth-and-13 from the Minnesota 22-yard line.

Enter Scifres for his first NFL field goal attempt, a 40-yarder he placed between the uprights to tie the game. Less than five minutes later, Tolbert gave the Chargers their first lead.

‚ÄúEven though we‚Äôre not where we want to be, we‚Äôre winning,‚Äù Bob Sanders said. ‚ÄúThat‚Äôs a positive thing.‚Äù

Said Rivers: ‚ÄúI would‚Äôve loved not to have thrown any interceptions and we‚Äôd have loved not to have a kickoff run back and let it just be smooth and easy, but it‚Äôs these kinds of wins that you really grow (from) because you have to fight through some adversity and do it together.‚Äù

**TWEET THE HEADLINE **

*Congratulations to @**RyZilla124** for your [winning Tweet the Headline submission](http://twitter.com/#!/RyZilla124/status/113029147286192128) **used in this article.*

*The San Diego Chargers and Motorola are giving Chargers fans around the world a chance to show support for their team when they "Tweet the Headline" for every Chargers home game during the 2010 season. Fans can **[submit their headline here](/fans/promotions/motorola.html) ****at the conclusion of each Chargers home game. One winning submission will be selected to headline a story on the Chargers' official website, **Chargers.com**. The headline will also be featured on the Chargers' official Twitter and Facebook pages. The person who submits the winning headline will receive a Chargers gift bag.  At the end of the season one lucky winner will receive a Motorola XOOM.*

Title: Ultimate Instagramer Contest and Instameet
Headline: To celebrate the start of training camp, we're hosting a Instagram contest and Instameet on Sunday, July 28 at 3 p.m.

Content.title:

Some of the most creative submissions to be featured in a gallery on our website. Out of these top photos, we will select one lucky fan to join us on the field for our pre-game warm ups and coin toss on Aug. 8. Details at http://chargers.com

Spread the word! #InstameetChargers

A post shared by Los Angeles Chargers (@chargers) on Jul 14, 2013 at 2:54pm PDT

Body.Content:
Do you love Instagram? We do too!  

San Diego is home to a thriving Instagram community with frequent InstaMeets and photo walks. So we partnered with the good people over at [IGers San Diego](http://instagram.com/IGerssandiego) to hold a [Chargers Training Camp](/schedule/training-camp-schedule.html) InstaMeet on **Sunday, July 28, 2013 at 3 p.m**.   

It‚Äôs easy and fun for all. Just grab some Instagram friends, come down to Chargers Park, share the photos you take during practice with one another using hashtag **#ChargersInstameet**. It's that easy!  

To add a little incentive, we'll select some of the most creative submissions to be featured in a gallery on Chargers.com. Out of these top photos, we will select one lucky fan to join us on the field to be the Exclusive Instagramer at our pre-game warm ups and coin toss for our pre-season opener against the Seattle Seahawks.   

**Ultimate Instagramer Contest Rules:**

(1) Photograph must be taken on location and must be GeoTagged (San Diego Chargers)  
(2) Must tag [@Chargers](http://instagram.com/chargers) AND [@IGersSanDiego](http://instagram.com/IGerssandiego)  
(3) Photograph must be yours and taken on July 28th with a Smart Phone ONLY (Camera pictures will be disqualified)  
(4) Must be tagged **#ChargersInstameet**

Need suggestions for what to shoot? The sky‚Äôs the limit, but here are a few ideas:

*   "Selfies" with the practice field in the background
*   Football scenery
*   Fan Passion
*   Players practicing
*   Coaches and Trainers
*   Perspective Shots 

We look forward to seeing all you Instagramers shooting pictures at training camp in a few short weeks!

**Related:**

*   [General Information for Fans visiting Training Camp](/schedule/training-camp-schedule.html)
*   [Training Camp Dates Open to Public Announced](/node/89851)

Title: Pagano: Monday Night is about the Team
Headline: Defensive Coordinator John Pagano talks about facing the Indianapolis Colts, led by his brother, Chuck Pagano.

Body.Content:
John Pagano talks with his brother, Indianapolis Head Coach Chuck Pagano, regularly as the two are extremely close.  But in the days leading up to Monday night‚Äôs match against the Colts, it‚Äôs radio silent between the two.

‚ÄúThere‚Äôs no communication between us right now,‚Äù he said. ‚ÄúNo text messages.  No phone calls.  I spoke to him once maybe last week.  We had a quick conversation.  But as this game gets closer, all communication ceases.  We cut it all off until the moments before the game when we say hello, take a photo and then after the game we‚Äôll wish each other the best of luck and stay healthy.  Once the game is over it‚Äôs back to normal.  The communication goes full swing again.  But right now there is no communication.‚Äù

ExtendedFields.Description: ed3d9bdf-0532-4aea-aebc-0d9db5f9279a
ed3d9bdf-0532-4aea-aebc-0d9db5f9279a

Body.Content:
The two brothers won‚Äôt be the only Paganos in attendance Monday night.  Their parents will be at Qualcomm to watch their two sons square off.

‚ÄúMy mom and dad are going to be there,‚Äù Pagano said, ‚ÄúTimes we‚Äôve played against each other before, I know my dad‚Äôs gone for walks.  He doesn‚Äôt even really watch the game.  He‚Äôs more inclined that he‚Äôs been here before and knows that at the end of the day someone is going to be happy and someone‚Äôs going to be sad.  My parents will be happy for whoever wins and they are there to pick up the other guy and cheer up whoever loses.  They‚Äôve grown accustomed to this game.‚Äù

Still, the Chargers defensive coordinator  is routinely quick to emphasize how at the end of the day, it‚Äôs about the players on the field and not about him and his brother.  Every game in the NFL is important, and Pagano agrees that this Monday is no exception.   His hope is that his defense feeds off of playing in front of a raucous Qualcomm Stadium.

‚ÄúThe number one thing is going out and getting a victory against an AFC opponent and getting a win in front of our home crowd,‚Äù he explained. ‚ÄúI‚Äôm excited, especially against a high-powered offense, of any change we can get of crowd noise that we can use to our advantage.‚Äù

Pagano is also focused on getting his defense to get the better of the Colts offense.  One way of doing that is to play a strong 60 minutes of football.  The first couple games of the year they started out strong before faltering down the stretch, but the last two games showed a Bolts defense that played tough in the second half.  . 

‚ÄúIt‚Äôs almost been a roller coaster ride for us,‚Äù Pagano admitted.  ‚ÄúWe‚Äôve started fast in games and haven‚Äôt finished strong, and then recently we didn‚Äôt start fast but finished strong.  So it‚Äôs about going out and playing a complete game.  We need to put four quarters together and not lose the mindset or focus defensively to go out there and play a full 60 minute game.  That doesn‚Äôt change.  The game is never won in the first quarter, so we have to start fast and finish strong.  That‚Äôs the mentality.  We have to go out and put a good 60 minutes together.‚Äù      

While it will be special to coach against his older brother, John Pagano is steadfast that the focus should remain on the players.  They are the ones who go out, execute the game plan, make the tackles and deserve all the praise.

‚ÄúWe‚Äôve faced each other so many times, it‚Äôs more about the team and the guys out on the field playing than it is about us,‚Äù he said. ‚ÄúTo me, it‚Äôs an honor to be able to coach a game against him as a head coach.  It‚Äôs pretty cool looking across to the other sideline and having a family member standing there, looking at you and giving the tip of the cap before the game.  It‚Äôs pretty cool.  That to me is most important. But at the end of the day it‚Äôs about the guys that go out there and play.  We‚Äôre not the ones out there tackling, running around, blocking and catching.‚Äù 

Tickets still remain for Monday night‚Äôs game.  [Click here to purchase](/tickets/single-game-tickets.html).

Title: Dabo Swinney: Brandon Thomas 'an Absolute Steal' for 49ers
Headline: To examine the San Francisco 49ers 12-man NFL Draft class, 49ers.com checked in with a college coach of each pick. We continue our series with a promising offensive lineman.

Body.Content: *To examine the San Francisco 49ers 12-man NFL Draft class, 49ers.com checked in with a college coach of each pick. We continue our series with‚Ä¶* [Brandon Thomas![](http://prod.static.49ers.clubs.nfl.com/assets/nflimg/icon-article-link.gif)](/team/roster/brandon-thomas/65f7d6d4-20fa-4515-9d18-200b9ebc1744/ "Brandon Thomas") will not play for the San Francisco 49ers in 2014. But Thomas could play for the 49ers for many years beyond this one. Thomas, the team‚Äôs third-round NFL Draft pick last May, tore the ACL in his right knee during an April workout for the New Orleans Saints. As a result of his injury, the offensive lineman predictably slid down draft boards. But Thomas‚Äô college coach said he thinks his former left tackle will be ‚Äúan absolute steal‚Äù for San Francisco. ‚ÄúI‚Äôm excited because I felt like he was going to be a definite, easy second-rounder and unfortunate that he got hurt,‚Äù Clemson head coach Dabo Swinney told 49ers.com over the phone from South Carolina. ‚ÄúFor the 49ers, I think it speaks volumes of them to be confident enough in their evaluations to still take him early in the third round with his injury. Coach (Jim) Harbaugh and his staff are going to really love Brandon Thomas once he gets back out onto the field.‚Äù Swinney also had this to say about the bright if beleaguered prospect‚Ä¶ ************First Impressions **********************‚ÄúBrandon is a very reserved, simple, quiet guy,‚Äù Swinney said. ‚ÄúWhen you see him, you look at him with his glasses on ‚Äì he looks like he just walked out of a library. Always clean-cut, very well dressed, very well spoken. Loves his mom and his sister. He‚Äôs not a rah-rah guy. He just goes about his business. To be honest, you would never even notice him. He‚Äôs a fly on the wall, but you notice him when he gets on the field. ‚ÄúWe knew when he was in high school that he was special. He actually played a lot of tight end then. We were just blown away by his speed and athleticism and his ability to run.‚Äù ************College Improvements**********************

ExtendedFields.Author: eric.stark
ExtendedFields.Description: Watch Clemson OL Brandon Thomas work out at the 2014 NFL Scouting Combine.

Title: Eric Reid and Lawrence Okoye Host Social Takeover
Headline: San Francisco 49ers safety Eric Reid and defensive lineman Lawrence Okoye took over the 49ers and NFL UK social accounts during FC Barcelona versus Manchester United.

ExtendedFields.Author: scott.kegley
ExtendedFields.Description: Eric Reid and Lawrence Okoye spent some time with three players from Manchester United - Chris Smalling, Jesse Lingard and Tyler Blackett.

ExtendedFields.Author: scott.kegley
ExtendedFields.Description: Eric Reid and Lawrence Okoye spent some time with three players from Manchester United - Chris Smalling, Jesse Lingard and Tyler Blackett.

Body.Content: During a matchup of international soccer heavyweights FC Barcelona and Manchester United, San Francisco 49ers safety [Eric Reid![](http://prod.static.49ers.clubs.nfl.com/assets/nflimg/icon-article-link.gif)](/team/roster/eric-reid/1e053d38-f272-41c8-9eab-d631973cdaaa/ "Eric Reid") and defensive lineman [Lawrence Okoye![](http://prod.static.49ers.clubs.nfl.com/assets/nflimg/icon-article-link.gif)](/team/roster/lawrence-okoye/3f7ab3b8-81d5-4a5b-b6d6-794c1c4794f8/ "Lawrence Okoye") let their allegiances be known. Reid, whose younger brother Ryan is a Manchester United fan, supported Barcelona. Okoye stayed true to his English routes, cheering for Man United. And if you follow the 49ers on social media, you most likely saw their reaction to the matchup at Levi‚Äôs¬Æ Stadium live. Reid took over the 49ers [Twitter](https://twitter.com/49ers), [Facebook](https://www.facebook.com/SANFRANCISCO49ERS) and ‚ÄúofficialSF49ers‚Äù Snapchat accounts while Okoye ran the show for [NFL UK](https://twitter.com/nfl_uk). Manchester United earned a 3-1 victory thanks to goals by Wayne Rooney, Jesse Lingard and Adnan Januzaj, but there were plenty of highlights on Saturday, as well as the rest of the week. The 49ers met several players from Manchester United and FC Barcelona just days before their match. Offensive lineman [Joe Staley![](http://prod.static.49ers.clubs.nfl.com/assets/nflimg/icon-article-link.gif)](/team/roster/joe-staley/fa308b6d-c61d-4bbb-8e67-8ddb8dc89901/ "Joe Staley") also participated in the meet and greet with the winners of the UEFA Champions League, assisting his soccer counterparts with a helmet fitting. That was followed by a brief skills competition on the field‚Ä¶ or pitch. Enjoy these highlights from the week.

Title: Pagano: Monday Night is about the Team
Headline: Defensive Coordinator John Pagano talks about facing the Indianapolis Colts, led by his brother, Chuck Pagano.

Body.Content:
[wysifield-embedded_photo|eid="233771"|type="embedded_photo"|view_mode="full"]
John Pagano talks with his brother, Indianapolis Head Coach Chuck Pagano, regularly as the two are extremely close. But in the days leading up to Monday night‚Äôs match against the Colts, it‚Äôs radio silent between the two. ‚ÄúThere‚Äôs no communication between us right now,‚Äù he said. ‚ÄúNo text messages. No phone calls. I spoke to him once maybe last week. We had a quick conversation. But as this game gets closer, all communication ceases. We cut it all off until the moments before the game when we say hello, take a photo and then after the game we‚Äôll wish each other the best of luck and stay healthy. Once the game is over it‚Äôs back to normal. The communication goes full swing again. But right now there is no communication.‚Äù[wysifield-embedded_video|eid="233776"|type="embedded_video"|view_mode="full"] The two brothers won‚Äôt be the only Paganos in attendance Monday night. Their parents will be at Qualcomm to watch their two sons square off. ‚ÄúMy mom and dad are going to be there,‚Äù Pagano said, ‚ÄúTimes we‚Äôve played against each other before, I know my dad‚Äôs gone for walks. He doesn‚Äôt even really watch the game. He‚Äôs more inclined that he‚Äôs been here before and knows that at the end of the day someone is going to be happy and someone‚Äôs going to be sad. My parents will be happy for whoever wins and they are there to pick up the other guy and cheer up whoever loses. They‚Äôve grown accustomed to this game.‚Äù Still, the Chargers defensive coordinator is routinely quick to emphasize how at the end of the day, it‚Äôs about the players on the field and not about him and his brother. Every game in the NFL is important, and Pagano agrees that this Monday is no exception. His hope is that his defense feeds off of playing in front of a raucous Qualcomm Stadium. ‚ÄúThe number one thing is going out and getting a victory against an AFC opponent and getting a win in front of our home crowd,‚Äù he explained. ‚ÄúI‚Äôm excited, especially against a high-powered offense, of any change we can get of crowd noise that we can use to our advantage.‚Äù Pagano is also focused on getting his defense to get the better of the Colts offense. One way of doing that is to play a strong 60 minutes of football. The first couple games of the year they started out strong before faltering down the stretch, but the last two games showed a Bolts defense that played tough in the second half. . ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs almost been a roller coaster ride for us,‚Äù Pagano admitted. ‚ÄúWe‚Äôve started fast in games and haven‚Äôt finished strong, and then recently we didn‚Äôt start fast but finished strong. So it‚Äôs about going out and playing a complete game. We need to put four quarters together and not lose the mindset or focus defensively to go out there and play a full 60 minute game. That doesn‚Äôt change. The game is never won in the first quarter, so we have to start fast and finish strong. That‚Äôs the mentality. We have to go out and put a good 60 minutes together.‚Äù While it will be special to coach against his older brother, John Pagano is steadfast that the focus should remain on the players. They are the ones who go out, execute the game plan, make the tackles and deserve all the praise. ‚ÄúWe‚Äôve faced each other so many times, it‚Äôs more about the team and the guys out on the field playing than it is about us,‚Äù he said. ‚ÄúTo me, it‚Äôs an honor to be able to coach a game against him as a head coach. It‚Äôs pretty cool looking across to the other sideline and having a family member standing there, looking at you and giving the tip of the cap before the game. It‚Äôs pretty cool. That to me is most important. But at the end of the day it‚Äôs about the guys that go out there and play. We‚Äôre not the ones out there tackling, running around, blocking and catching.‚Äù Tickets still remain for Monday night‚Äôs game. [Click here to purchase](/tickets/single-game-tickets.html).

Title: Draft Panel: Best Wide Receiver Prospect, Mike Williams or Corey Davis?
Headline: Four of the most prominent draft experts around the country share their take on the best receiver prospect in this year's class.

Album.Title: 49ers 2017 Free Agent Additions in Photos
Album.Description: View images of the 49ers 2017 free-agent acquisitions.

NeutralAlbum.Title: 49ers 2017 Free Agent Additions in Photos
NeutralAlbum.Description: View images of the 49ers 2017 free-agent acquisitions.

Body.Content: With six weeks until the 2017 NFL Draft, our panel of NFL Draft experts is back to share their take on another pressing topic. Who is the top wide receiver prospect in the 2017 NFL Draft? The two leading candidates are Clemson's Mike Williams and Western Michigan's Corey Davis. The San Francisco 49ers added three wide receivers in free agency last week: [Pierre Gar√ßon![](http://prod.static.49ers.clubs.nfl.com/assets/nflimg/icon-article-link.gif)](/team/roster/pierre-garon/d613e1a6-f54b-4888-918b-85cccd5e2eee/ "Pierre Gar√ßon"), [Marquise Goodwin![](http://prod.static.49ers.clubs.nfl.com/assets/nflimg/icon-article-link.gif)](/team/roster/marquise-goodwin/ae413cd1-ccca-44e0-a45a-5cf7869d6cf8/ "Marquise Goodwin") and [Aldrick Robinson![](http://prod.static.49ers.clubs.nfl.com/assets/nflimg/icon-article-link.gif)](/team/roster/aldrick-robinson/08dd480e-3502-4be9-a4cc-473666b3c75e/ "Aldrick Robinson"). That said, it shouldn't be assumed that the 49ers won't target a receiving threat on Draft Day. Williams won a national championship in 2016 with the Tigers. He caught eight passes for 94 yards and one touchdown in the title game against Alabama. For the season, Williams posted 98 receptions for 1,361 yards and 11 touchdowns, all of which were career-highs. Davis set career-highs in 2016 as well, racking up 97 receptions for 1,500 receiving yards and 19 touchdowns as a senior with the Broncos. Both Williams and Davis have plenty of size, each standing 6-foot-3. Here's what our experts had to say regarding their choice between the two.** Daniel Jeremiah, NFL Network: Corey Davis ** ‚ÄúI love both of them, but I have Corey Davis as my top guy. I think they‚Äôre both No. 1 guys. When people ask, ‚ÄòWhat‚Äôs the definition of a No. 1 receiver?‚Äô I say that it‚Äôs on third down or in the red zone, when everyone in the whole stadium knows where it‚Äôs going, and the defense can‚Äôt do anything about it. I think both of those guys fit that description. I think they‚Äôre ready to come in and make an immediate impact on Day 1."** Matt Bowen, ESPN: Mike Williams** ‚ÄúI think it‚Äôs Mike Williams right now. A good comparison for him is Alshon Jeffrey, with a little more explosive-play ability and athleticism. Corey Davis reminds me of a Brandon Marshall. He‚Äôs physical, he‚Äôs strong, he can run inside-breaking routes all day. He can produce after the catch. You can make an argument that he‚Äôs No. 1, too. You can‚Äôt go wrong. They‚Äôre both size/speed guys with natural ability. I think with Williams, you get a little more at the point of attack, talking 50/50 throws down the field.‚Äù** Will Brinson, CBS Sports: Corey Davis** ‚ÄúMike Williams has the pedigree. Clemson produces consistent NFL-caliber wide receivers. That being said, Corey Davis has probably been a more complete receiver in terms of how his game has developed. It doesn‚Äôt bother me at all to have a guy who played lower level competition. I don‚Äôt think that will hinder Davis. He‚Äôs my guy.‚Äù** Dane Brugler, CBS Sports: Mike Williams** ‚ÄúI lean towards Mike Williams. He‚Äôs bigger. He‚Äôs probably not the same caliber of athlete, but I feel more comfortable with him down the field in contested situations. He can climb the ladder. I like Corey Davis quite a bit, too. He can do a little bit of everything. He reminds me a lot of (New Orleans Saints wide receiver) Michael Thomas. Back to Williams, he‚Äôs got something special. You just throw it in his zip code and he finds a way to come down with it. He feels like a combination of A.J. Green and Michael Floyd.‚Äù

Title: Torrey Smith Goes Fishing, Catches Hammerhead Shark
Headline: While deep-sea fishing with a few friends for tuna, Smith managed to hook a ferocious predator instead.

Body.Content:
We‚Äôve all been there.

One minute you‚Äôre reeling in a fish and the next a hammerhead shark is on the line.

OK, maybe that‚Äôs not such a common occurrence. But that‚Äôs what happened to Niners wide receiver Torrey Smith on Thursday.

While deep-sea fishing with a few friends for tuna, Smith managed to hook a ferocious predator instead.

‚ÄúThat thing is huge!‚Äù Smith can be heard saying in a video posted to his [Facebook account](https://www.facebook.com/TorreySmithWR/). ‚ÄúDo you see this?‚Äù

Smith and his fellow fishermen eventually cut the shark loose, but not before documenting their unusual catch on film.

‚ÄúThat was fun,‚Äù Smith said. ‚ÄúLet‚Äôs see what else we can catch.‚Äù
